If men and women labor all day, exhausting their spirits and sapping their strength, alternating between hunger and satiety, experiencing joy and anger, worry and thought, suffering from cold and drinking cold liquids, and indulging in their desires, it is said in the "Suwen": today, many people are weakened before reaching the age of fifty, treating wine as a common drink, regarding indulgence as normal, getting drunk and entering bedrooms for desires that exhaust their essence and dissipate their true energy. The source of this leads to emptiness and depletion, so how can the five organs and six viscera not become weak? The "Five Labors," "Six Extreme Weaknesses," and "Seven Injuries" all begin from here.

What are the Five Labors? Heart labor leads to blood loss; liver labor harms the spirit; spleen labor damages food intake; lung labor diminishes vital energy; kidney labor destroys essence. The "Six Extremes" refer to the exhaustion of tendons, sinews, muscles, skin, and bones. The "Seven Injuries," as detailed in the "Nanjing," injure the form and the vital energy, and can be summarized under the concept of emptiness. Generally speaking, the five elements and six energies identify water as only one-fifth of the whole. If one water is depleted, can it possibly overcome the five fires? Symptoms of weakness and exhaustion therefore arise in abundance. Those who are physically weak are most susceptible to evil energies; the first step is to harmonize and relieve them, applying minimal herbs and treating them with gentleness, then gradually adjusting.

If a physician does not recognize that evil energy has latched onto the body and has not been removed, yet proceeds with tonifying supplements, then the evil energy receives nourishment, enters the meridians, leading to an untreatable condition resulting in death; such mistakes occur to countless individuals, which is truly lamentable! The "Neijing" originally doesn't mention labor as a diagnosis but states that labor is meant to nourish. What is deficient should be supplemented with tastes from grains, meats, vegetables, and fruits—all serve as nourishment.[76p]

今之医者不通其法，唯知热补之道，轻则当归、鹿茸、雄、附，重则乳石、丹砂，加之以灼艾补燥其水，水得热愈涸，生火转甚，小而成嗽，痰血潮热，烦渴喜冷，此则热证明矣。重则失音，断不可救。犹且峻补不已，如此死者，医杀之耳。及遇良工治验，而以清剂解之，不合病人之意，反行怪责。及闻发表攻里之说，畏而不从，甘死于庸工热补之手，虽死不悔，深可悯也！夫凉剂能养水清火，热剂能燥水补火。天下之事，无出乎理，理既明，何患疾之不安？劳为热证明矣，还可补乎？惟无邪无热无积之人，脉举按无力而弱者，方可补之。又必察其胃中及右肾二火亏而用之。心虚，则动悸恍惚，忧烦少色舌强，宜养荣汤、琥珀定神丸之类以益其心血。脾虚，面黄肌瘦，吐利清冷，腹胀肠鸣，四肢无力，饮食不进，宜快胃汤、进食丸之类以调其饮食。肝虚，目昏筋脉拘挛，面青，恐惧如人将捕之状，宜牛膝益中汤、虎骨丹之类以养助其筋脉。[77p]

Today’s physicians do not understand their principles; they only know the method of treating with heating tonics. For mild cases, they use Angelica root, deer antler, and various other invigorating substances; for severe cases, they resort to milk stone and cinnabar, using moxa to heat and dry out the body’s fluids. When the fluids are heated, they dry up, leading to excessive heat, resulting in dry coughs, phlegm, blood, and a clammy fever, along with thirst and a preference for cold; this indicates excessive heat. In severe cases, one may lose their voice, which is irreparable. Yet they continue to administer harsh tonics, causing the death of the patient; the physician then becomes the cause of death.

When a skilled practitioner applies cleansing remedies, and they do not align with the patient’s condition, they are met with unwarranted criticism. Moreover, when they hear of treatments targeting the interior, they hesitate and do not follow, willingly accepting death at the hands of inept practitioners who use heating tonics. Even in death, they do not regret this; it is truly lamentable!

Cooling remedies can nourish fluids and clear heat, while heating remedies can dry fluids and bolster heat. Matters in the world all adhere to principles; once the principles are clear, what worry is there about the illness not resolving? If labor manifests as evidence of heat, can it still be supplemented? Only those without pathogens, heat, or accumulated issues, whose pulses are weak and feeble, may be supplemented. It is also essential to observe whether their stomach and right kidney fire are deficient before proceeding.

If the heart is deficient, there will be palpitations, confusion, anxiety with a pale tongue, and they should use nourishing decoctions or amber pills to enrich their heart blood. If the spleen is deficient, there will be a sallow complexion, thinness, clear vomiting or diarrhea, abdominal distension, rumbling intestines, weakness in the limbs, and a lack of appetite; in this case, they should use stomach tonics or appetite-promoting pills to regulate their diet. If the liver is deficient, there could be blurred vision, muscular cramps, a pale complexion, and a state of fearfulness resembling someone about to be captured; for this, they should use Cow Knee Decoction or Tiger Bone Pills to nourish and assist the sinews.[77p]

肺虚，呼吸少气喘乏，咳嗽嗌干，宜枳实汤加人参、黄芪、阿胶、苏子以调其气。肾虚，腰背脊膝厥逆而痛，神困耳鸣，小便频数精漏，宜八味丸加五味子、鹿茸，去附子用山药等丸以生其精。　　劳瘵兼痰积，其证腹胁常热，手足头面则于寅卯时分乍有凉时者是也。若顽痰胶固难治者，必以吐法吐之，或沉香滚痰丸、透膈丹之类下之。又甚者或用倒仓法。若痰积闭塞经脉，则太冲脉与冲阳寸口脉数而不相应者，极难治。　　虚损复受邪热，皆宜用柴胡。《衍义》云：柴胡《本经》并无一字治劳，今人方中治劳鲜有不用者，误人甚多。常原病劳有一种真脏虚损，复受邪热，因虚而致劳。故曰劳者牢也，当斟酌之。如经验方治劳热，青蒿煎丸用柴胡正宜，服之，无不效，热去即须急已。若无邪热，得此愈甚，虽至死，人亦不怨。王海藏云：苟无实热，医取用之，不死何待？用之者宜审诸。又大忌芩、连、蘗，骤用纯苦寒药，反泻其阳。[78p]

If there is lung deficiency, characterized by shortness of breath, coughing, a dry throat, it is advisable to use a decoction of bitter orange combined with ginseng, astragalus, donkey-hide gelatin, and perilla seeds to regulate the qi. In cases of kidney deficiency with pain in the lower back and knees, fatigue, tinnitus, and frequent urination with leakage, it is advisable to take an eight-ingredient pill combined with schisandra and deer antler, avoiding aconite and using yam to nourish the essence.

For consumption combined with phlegm accumulation, the symptoms include persistent heat in the abdomen and flanks, while hands and feet may occasionally feel cool around the hours of Yin and Yang. If stubborn phlegm is difficult to treat, it is essential to use an emetic method, or to administer drugs like agarwood phlegm pills or penetrating partition pills. In more severe cases, reverse warehouse methods may be employed. If phlegm accumulation obstructs the meridians, it is extremely difficult to treat when the Taichong pulse and the inch pulse of Chongyang are rapid and do not correspond.

For deficiency disorders followed by pathogenic heat, Chaihu should be used. The "Extended Meaning" states: in the "Classic," Chaihu is not mentioned for treating consumption, yet in modern formulas it is rarely omitted for this purpose, which can mislead many. The fundamental cause of consumption is often true organ deficiency that has become affected by pathogenic heat, leading to consumption as a result of deficiency. Therefore, consumption signifies stagnation, and one should carefully consider this.

In familiar formulas for treating consumption heat, Qinghao decoction with Chaihu is appropriate. Upon taking it, there are no exceptions; the heat must be addressed urgently. If there is no pathogenic heat, the treatment can indeed worsen the condition. Even to death, a person would bear no complaint. Wang Haizang stated: if there is no true heat, and a doctor uses it, what is there to wait for if not death? Those who use it should be careful. Additionally, one must avoid using Qín, Lián, or Bó hastily with pure cold bitter medicines, as this will counteract the yang.[78p]

但当用琼玉膏之类，大助阳气，使其复还寅卯之位，微加泻阴火之药是也。　　葛洪云：鬼疰者，是五尸之一疰。又按诸鬼邪为害，其变动乃有三十六种至九十九种，大略使人淋漓，沉沉默默，的不知其所苦，而无处不恶，累年积月，渐就顿滞，以致于死，传于旁人，乃至灭门。觉知是候者，急治獭肝一具，阴干取末，水服方寸匕，日三服效。未知再服。此方神良。天庆观一法师行考校极精严，时一妇人投状述患人有所附，须臾乃附语云：非我所祸，别是一鬼，亦自病人命衰为祟耳。今已成形，在患人肺中为虫，食其肺系，故令吐血声嘶。师掠之曰：此虫还得长生否？久而无语。再掠之，良久云：唯畏獭爪屑，为末以酒服之则去矣。患家如其言得愈，此予所目见也。究其患亦相似。獭爪者，獭肝之类欤？　　传尸蛊瘵之证，父子兄弟互相传染，甚者绝户。此乃祖父寃债，或风水所系，虽有符文法水下虫之法，然虫去人亡，亦未为全美，若能平素保养则自愈矣。[79p]

To use substances like fragrant ointment, greatly helps the Yang energy, allowing it to return to its rightful position. It is also necessary to slightly reduce the Yin fire with some medicine. Ge Hong says: Ghost afflictions are one of the five types of afflictions. Furthermore, among the various malevolent spirits, their transformations can range from thirty-six to ninety-nine kinds, generally causing people to feel sluggish, silent, not knowing their suffering, leading to evil everywhere. Over the years, this accumulation can result in stagnation and ultimately death, affecting others to the point of family extinction.

If one becomes aware of the afflicted state, they should urgently treat with a fresh otter liver, dry it in the shade, powder it, and ingest the powder with water using a small spoon, three times a day until effective. If results are unknown after the first course, further dosages are advised. This remedy is remarkably effective. A master at the Tianqing Temple, through strict examination, encountered a woman who submitted a request stating that the afflicted person was possessed. Shortly thereafter, it was revealed: "It is not my fault; it is another spirit causing trouble, stemming from the patient's weakened life force." It had already taken form in the afflicted person's lungs as a worm, eating away at the lung tissues, causing hemoptysis and a hoarse voice. The master questioned the worm: "Can you still achieve longevity?" After a long silence, when questioned again, it eventually replied: "Only fearing the powdered claw of the otter, if taken with wine, I will leave." The afflicted family found that following its words led to recovery; this is what I have personally witnessed.

The affliction is indeed similar. Is the otter claw similar to the otter liver? The transmission of dead body afflictions, such as diseases, can pass between family members, sometimes leading to complete family destruction. This is often tied to ancestral debts or linked to geographical factors. Although talismans, incantations, and methods of dispelling with water can remove the ailment, it does not guarantee complete wellness, but if one can regularly maintain their health, healing will naturally occur.[79p]

　　　　医宗必读 【明　李中梓】

　　　　　虚劳证治

　　按《内经》之言虚劳，惟是气血两端，至巢氏《病源》始分五脏之劳，七情之伤，甚而分气血筋骨肌精之六极，又分脑髓、玉房、胞络、骨、血、筋、脉、肝、心、脾、肺、肾、膀胱、胆、胃、三焦、大小肠、肉、肤、皮、气之二十三蒸。《本事方》更分传尸鬼疰至于九十九种，其凿空附合，重出复见，固无论矣，使学者惑于多岐，用方错杂，伊谁之咎乎？盍以《内经》为式，但于脾肾分主气血，约而该，确而可守也。夫人之虚，不属于气即属于血，五脏六腑莫能外焉。而独举脾肾者，水为万物之元，土为万物之母，二脏安和，一身皆治，百疾不生。夫脾具土德，脾安则上为金母，金实水源，且土不凌水，水安其位，故脾安则肾愈安也。肾兼水火，肾安则水不挟肝上泛而凌土湿，火能益土运行而化精微，故肾安则脾愈安也。孙思邈云：补脾不如补肾。许学士云：补肾不如补脾。[80p]

Medical Canon Must-Read
(Ming - Li Zhongzi)

Treatment of Deficiency Syndrome

According to the "Inner Classic," deficiency syndrome primarily concerns both Qi and blood. It was not until the work of Chao Shi in "Sources of Diseases" that the five organs' deficiencies and the seven emotions' injuries were distinguished. It even further categorized the six elements of Qi, blood, tendons, bones, muscles, and essence, and divided them into twenty-three components including brain, marrow, uterus, vessels, blood, tendons, meridians, liver, heart, spleen, lungs, kidneys, bladder, gallbladder, stomach, triple energizer, large and small intestines, flesh, skin, and Qi. The "Principles of Therapy" further divides the causes of disease into as many as ninety-nine types. With this intricate categorization, scholars have become confused by the myriad paths, leading to the erroneous use of formulas, blurring the lines of culpability. Why not adhere to the "Inner Classic"? It succinctly delineates the spleen and kidneys as the governing organs of Qi and blood, making it straightforward and reliable.

In humans, deficiency lies either in Qi or blood, and all five organs must be considered. The reason for emphasizing the spleen and kidneys is that water is the source of all things, and earth is the mother of all things. When these two organs are in harmony, the whole body is treated, and myriad diseases do not arise. The spleen possesses the qualities of earth; when the spleen is stabilized, it nurtures the mother of metal above, where metal strengthens the source of water. Moreover, earth should not overshadow water; when water holds its position, the spleen is stabilized, which in turn leads to the kidneys' harmony. Furthermore, the kidneys encompass both water and fire; when the kidneys are stable, water does not overwhelm the liver and invade the dampness of earth. Fire can also aid earth in transformation and refinement. Therefore, with the kidneys stable, the spleen will likewise be secure. Sun Simiao stated: "Nourishing the spleen is superior to nourishing the kidneys." Scholar Xu stated: "Nourishing the kidneys is inferior to nourishing the spleen."[80p]

两先生深知二脏为生人之根本，又知二脏有相赞之功能，故其说似背，其旨实同也。救肾者，必本于阴血。血主濡之，血属阴，主下降。虚则上升，当敛而抑，六味丸是也。救脾者，必本于阳气。气主煦之，气为阳，主上升。虚则下陷，当升而举，补中益气汤是也。近世治劳，专以四物汤加黄蘗、知母，不知四物皆阴，行秋冬之气，非所以生万物者也。且血药常滞，非痰多食少者所宜。血药常润，久行必致滑肠。黄蘗、知母，其性苦寒，能泻实火。名曰滋阴，其实燥而损血；名曰降火，其实苦先入心，久而增气，反能助火。至其败胃，所不待言。丹溪有言：实火可泻，虚火可补。劳证之火，虚乎实乎？泻之可乎？矫其偏者，辄以桂、附为家常茶饭，此惟火衰者宜之。若血气燥热之人，能无助火为害哉？大抵虚劳之证，疑难不少，如补脾保肺，法当兼行。然脾喜温燥，肺喜清润。保肺则碍脾，补脾则碍肺。[81p]

The two masters deeply understand that the kidneys are the foundation of life, and they also recognize the mutually supportive functions of the two organs. Thus, although their statements seem contradictory, their essence is actually the same. To nourish the kidneys, one must start with yin blood. Blood governs moisture and belongs to yin, which is associated with descent. When deficient, it tends to rise; it should be gathered and suppressed, thus the use of Liu Wei Di Huang Wan. To nourish the spleen, one must start with yang energy. Qi governs warmth and is associated with yang, which promotes ascent. When deficient, it tends to sink; it should be uplifted and raised, thus the use of Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang.

In recent years, the treatment for labor deficiencies has relied on Si Wu Tang with additions of Huang Lian and Zhi Mu, without realizing that all four ingredients are yin and operate under the influences of autumn and winter, which are not conducive to generating all forms of life. Moreover, blood medicines are often stagnant and are not suitable for those suffering from phlegm and poor appetite. Blood medicines tend to be moistening, and prolonged use can lead to loose stools. Huang Lian and Zhi Mu, being bitter and cold by nature, can drain excess heat. It is named for nourishing yin, but in truth, it is drying and detrimental to blood; it is deemed to clear heat, yet it bitterly enters the heart first, and over time can increase qi, which ultimately can assist heat. As for its damaging effect on the stomach, there is no need to elaborate.

Dan Xi stated: Excess heat can be drained, while deficient heat can be replenished. In cases of labor-related heat, is it deficient or excess? Can it be drained? Those who correct their imbalances often use Gui Zhi and Fu Zi as daily remedies, which are only suitable for those with weak fire. However, for individuals with dry heat in blood and qi, can they avoid the harm of assisting fire? Generally, symptoms of deficiency and labor are often complex; for nourishing the spleen and protecting the lungs, one must consider both approaches. Yet the spleen prefers warmth and dryness, while the lungs prefer clarity and moisture. Protecting the lungs may impede the spleen, and nourishing the spleen may obstruct the lungs.[81p]

惟燥热而甚，能食而不泻者，润肺当急，而补脾之药亦不可缺也。倘虚羸而甚，食少泻多，虽喘嗽不宁，但以补脾为急，而清润之品宜戒矣。脾有生肺之能，肺无扶脾之力，故补脾之药，尤要于保肺也。尝见劳证之死，多死于泄泻；泄泻之因，多因于清润。司命者能不为之兢兢耶？又补肾理脾，法当兼行。然方欲以甘寒补肾，其人减食，又恐不利于脾；方欲以辛温快脾，其人阴伤，又恐愈耗其水。两者并衡而较重脾者，以脾土上交于心，下交于肾故也。若肾大虚而势困笃者，又不可拘。要知滋肾之中佐以砂仁、沉香，壮脾之中参以五味、肉桂，随时活法可耳。又如无阳则阴无以生，无阴则阳无以化，宜不可偏也。然东垣曰：甘温能除大热。又曰：血脱补气。又曰：独阴不长。春夏之温，可以发育；秋冬之寒，不能生长。虚者必补以人参之甘温，阳生阴长之理也。且虚劳证受补者可治，不受补者不治。[82p]

In cases of severe dryness and heat, where one can eat without experiencing diarrhea, it is essential to moisten the lungs urgently, and medicine to tonify the spleen cannot be omitted. If the condition is severely weak, with little eating and excessive diarrhea, though there are signs of wheezing and coughing, it is urgent to tonify the spleen, while cooling and moistening substances should be avoided. The spleen has the capacity to generate the lungs, while the lungs lack the power to support the spleen; thus, medicines to tonify the spleen are particularly important for preserving the lungs. I have often seen patients with exhaustion die mostly from diarrhea; the cause of diarrhea is often due to cooling and moistening. Can those in charge of fate not be wary of this? Additionally, tonifying the kidneys and regulating the spleen should be done simultaneously. However, if one intends to use sweet and cold substances to tonify the kidneys, yet the person reduces their food intake, it may not benefit the spleen; conversely, if one wants to use pungent and warming substances to invigorate the spleen, but the person's yin is damaged, it may further deplete their fluids. Both aspects must be balanced, with emphasis on the spleen because the spleen (earth) connects upward to the heart and downward to the kidneys. If there is severe deficiency in the kidneys and the condition is dire, one should not be overly restrictive. It is important to know that nourishing the kidneys should incorporate cardamom and sandalwood, while strengthening the spleen should include ingredients like five-flavor fruit and cinnamon, adjusting according to the time and method. Furthermore, without yang, yin cannot thrive; without yin, yang cannot transform, indicating it must not be one-sided. However, Dong Yuan said: sweet and warm substances can eliminate great heat. He also stated: blood loss requires replenishing qi. And again: solely yin cannot sustain growth. The warmth of spring and summer can promote development; the cold of autumn and winter cannot support growth. Those who are deficient must be supplemented with the sweet warmth of ginseng, aligning with the principle that yang generates yin. Moreover, those with deficiency due to exhaustion can be treated with supplementation; those who do not accept supplementation cannot be treated.[82p]

故葛可久治劳，神良素着，所垂十方，用参者七。丹溪专主滋阴，所述治劳方案，用参者亦十之七。不用参者，非其新伤，必其轻浅者耳。自好古肺热伤肺、节斋服参必死之说，印定后人眼目，甘用苦寒，直至上呕下泄，犹不悔悟，良可悲已。幸李濒湖、汪石山详为之辨，而宿习难返，贻祸未已。不知肺经自有热者，肺脉按之而实，与参诚不相宜。若火来乘金者，肺脉按之而虚，金气大伤，非参不保。[83p]

Therefore, the use of astragalus can indeed treat fatigue effectively. Its properties are primarily nourishing, and in all methodologies, it is employed in seven of the ten cases. Danxi emphasizes nourishing the yin, and his treatment plans for fatigue also utilize astragalus in seven out of ten cases. In situations where astragalus is not used, it is either because the injury is fresh or the condition is milder.

Those who stubbornly believe that lung heat damages the lungs and that abstaining from food while taking astragalus will lead to death have influenced subsequent generations, leading them to willingly adopt harsh and cold treatments. This often results in severe vomiting and diarrhea, yet they remain unrepentant, which is truly lamentable.

Fortunately, Li Binhai and Wang Shishan have provided detailed explanations for this issue, but old habits are hard to break, and disasters continue to follow. They do not realize that the lung meridian can have heat, and when the lung pulse is pressed, it may feel solid; in such cases, astragalus is genuinely inappropriate. When fire invades metal, the lung pulse feels weak, the lung qi is significantly damaged, and only astragalus can offer protection.[83p]

前哲有言曰：土旺而金生，勿拘拘于保肺；水壮而火熄，毋汲汲于清心。可谓洞达《内经》之旨，深窥根本之治者也。　　虚劳热毒，积久则生恶虫，食人脏腑，其证蒸热咳嗽，胸闷背痛，两目不明，四肢无力，腰膝酸疼，卧而不寐，或面色脱白，或两颊时红，常怀忿怒，梦与鬼交，同气连枝，多遭传染，甚至灭门，大可畏也。法当补虚以复其元，杀虫以绝其根。能杀其虫，虽病者不生，亦可绝其传疰耳。凡近视此病者，不宜饥饿。虚者须服补药，宜佩安息香及麝香，则虫鬼不敢侵也。[84p]

The ancients have said: When the earth is strong, metal is produced; do not be overly strict about preserving the lungs. When water is abundant, fire is extinguished; do not be excessively concerned with a serene heart. This can be said to comprehend the essence of the "Inner Canon" and to deeply understand the principles of treatment.

Chronic exhaustion and heat toxins can lead to the generation of harmful insects that consume one’s internal organs, resulting in symptoms such as steaming heat cough, chest tightness and back pain, unclear vision, weakness in the limbs, and soreness in the lower back and knees, with inability to sleep when lying down. One may also display pale complexion or red cheeks, often harboring anger, dreaming of encounters with spirits, sharing afflictions closely, suffering from multiple infections, and even facing total ruin—this is certainly to be feared. The treatment must focus on replenishing the deficiency to restore the original state and eliminating the insects to eradicate the root cause. If the insects are exterminated, the patient, though ill, will not suffer further contagion. Those who are near to this ailment should not be hungry. The deficient ones must take tonics; it is advisable to wear the calming incense and musk, for then the pestilence will not dare to invade.[84p]

　　　　古今医统 【明　徐春甫】

　　　　　论五劳六极七伤之由

　　五劳者，心肝脾肺肾也。劳于心者则神耗而血衰，惊悸之疾，亦因之而作矣。劳于肝者则怒多而火盛，泪外泄而目昏，或胁肋刺痛，筋惫不能久立远行。劳于肺者，因过忧而耗气，则燥胜而液枯，干咳声哑，二便秘濇，皆由此而作也。劳于脾者，劳倦伤脾，发热恶寒，呕吐不食，四肢无力，好卧倦言，渐而致于肾惫阴虚，则成怯证。劳于肾者，色欲过度，淋浊遗精，阴不上升，阳不下降，肾水既不升荣，心肺皆无所荫，咳嗽吐红咯血之证作也。今世之所谓劳者，皆无出于此。六极者，风寒暑湿燥火，靡不冒触，极甚而即病之重而不可救者有矣。或有医之愈而终为淫气所伤，元气有损，莫之能完复也，致为终身之损者盖多矣。七伤者，喜怒忧思悲恐惊七情过伤是也。惟过于思者，寖成痨瘵。今之劳瘵而多起于脾肾之劳，忧思之过者也。先哲所谓五劳六极七伤，盖因证而言之。[85p]

Discussion on the Causes of the Five Labors, Six Extremes, and Seven Injuries

The Five Labors refer to the heart, liver, spleen, lungs, and kidneys. Laboring the heart leads to depletion of spirit and blood, resulting in ailments like palpitations. Laboring the liver results in excessive anger and fiery disposition, causing tears and blurred vision, and potentially leading to rib pain and fatigue, making it difficult to stand or travel. Laboring the lungs, due to excessive worry, depletes qi, leading to dryness and lack of fluids, resulting in dry cough, hoarseness, and constipation. Laboring the spleen from fatigue injures it, causing fever, aversion to cold, vomiting, loss of appetite, and weakness in limbs, leading to lethargy and an inclination to lie down, eventually tiring the kidneys and resulting in yin deficiency, manifesting as cowardice. Laboring the kidneys through excessive desire, producing cloudy discharge and loss of essence, leads to problems where yin fails to ascend and yang fails to descend. If kidney water does not rise, the heart and lungs lack nourishment, causing symptoms like cough with blood. The so-called labors of today originate from these.

The Six Extremes refer to wind, cold, heat, dampness, dryness, and fire. Each can elicit disease when excessively encountered. Some may recover through medicine but ultimately suffer long-term damage from indulgent influences, compromising their fundamental energy, leading to lifelong detriment.

The Seven Injuries refer to the emotional states of joy, anger, worry, thought, sadness, fear, and shock, which, when excessive, can cause harm. Specifically, excessive thought can gradually lead to consumption-related diseases. Many contemporary ailments stem from the labors of the spleen and kidneys, especially those from excessive worry and thought. The ancient sages spoke of the Five Labors, Six Extremes, and Seven Injuries to illustrate these conditions.[85p]

　　　　　久则生虫

　　虚劳热毒，积久则生异物恶虫，食人脏腑精华，变生诸般奇状，诚可惊骇。劳伤肝胆者，则为毛虫，如刺猬瓦蛆之状，食人筋膜。劳伤心与小肠者，则为羽虫，如灯蛾蚊蝱禽鸟之形，食人血脉。劳伤脾胃者，则为倮虫，或如婴儿蚯蚓之类，食人肌肉。劳伤肺与大肠者，则为介虫，如龟鳖虾蟹之属，食人肤膏。劳伤肾与膀胱者，则为鳞虫，如鱼龙蛟鲤之形，食人骨髓。或挟相火之势，亦如羽虫之酷，鸥枭之类，为状不一，不可胜纪。凡人有此证，便宜早治，缓则不及事矣。治之之法，一则补其虚以复其真元，一则杀其虫以绝其根本。能杀其虫，则虽不生，亦可以绝后人之传疰耳。[86p]

Long-term Illness Leads to Parasites

Chronic weakness and heat toxins, if accumulated over time, can give rise to strange and harmful creatures that consume the essence of the internal organs, transforming into various frightening forms. This is indeed alarming. When the liver and gallbladder are damaged, it manifests as hairy larvae, resembling the shape of a hedgehog or maggot, consuming the fascia. Damage to the heart and small intestine leads to winged insects, resembling moths or mosquitoes, feasting on blood vessels. Injury to the spleen and stomach results in worm-like creatures, similar to infant earthworms, that consume muscle tissue. Damage to the lungs and large intestine presents as shell-like insects, akin to turtles, shrimps, or crabs, which eat the skin's moisture. If the kidneys and bladder are affected, scaly creatures appear, resembling fish, dragons, or carp, devouring the bone marrow. There may also be fiery manifestations, akin to terrifying winged insects or owls, with diverse forms that are countless. Whenever a person exhibits these signs, timely treatment is advisable; delay may result in irreparable consequences. The methods of treatment involve firstly replenishing the deficiency to restore the true essence, and secondly exterminating the parasites to eliminate the root cause. If the parasites can be killed, then even if new ones do not arise, it can prevent future generations from suffering from this affliction.[86p]

　　　　　虫候有九

　　劳瘵九虫者：一曰伏虫，长四寸，为群虫之长；二曰蛔虫，长一尺，贯人心则杀人；三曰寸白虫，长一寸，子孙繁生，长至四五尺，亦能杀人；四曰肉虫，状若烂杏，令人烦满；五曰肺虫，状如蚕，令人咳嗽；六曰胃虫，状如虾蟆，令人呕逆吐哕；七曰弱虫，又名鬲虫，状如瓜瓣，令人多唾；八曰赤虫，状若生肉，令人肠鸣；九曰蛲虫，至微细，形似菜虫，居回肠，多则为痔，极则为痢，及生痈疽癣疥痿瘑龋齿，无不为也。凡此诸虫，依人肠胃之间，脏腑实则害人脏腑，脏腑虚则蚀人脏腑血髓，变成诸患，至于不疗。[87p]

There are nine types of parasitic insects.

The nine parasitic insects that cause suffering are: First, the伏虫 (fú chóng), measuring four inches long, is the leader of the group; Second, the蛔虫 (huái chóng), measuring one foot long, can kill by piercing the heart; Third, the寸白虫 (cùn bái chóng), one inch long, reproduces rapidly and can grow up to four or five feet long, also capable of killing; Fourth, the肉虫 (ròu chóng), resembling rotten apricots, causes discomfort; Fifth, the肺虫 (fèi chóng), looking like silkworms, leads to coughing; Sixth, the胃虫 (wèi chóng), resembling frogs, causes nausea and vomiting; Seventh, the弱虫 (ruò chóng), also known as鬲虫 (gé chóng), shaped like melon seeds, induces excessive salivation; Eighth, the赤虫 (chì chóng), resembling raw meat, makes the intestines rumble; Ninth, the蛲虫 (náo chóng), very tiny and resembling cabbage worms, resides in the large intestine, often leading to hemorrhoids, and in severe cases, dysentery, as well as causing boils, sores, scabs, weakness, and dental decay.

All these insects reside within the human intestines and stomachs; if the organs are full, they harm them, and if they are weak, they erode the organs and the blood marrow, transforming into various afflictions, to the point of being incurable.[87p]

人将气绝，则从九窍肤腠，飞梭而出，着于怯弱之人，月久亦成劳瘵之证，此所谓传尸也。凡人平素保养元气，爱惜精血，瘵不可得而传。惟夫纵欲多淫，苦不自觉，精血内耗，邪气外乘，是不特男子有伤，女人亦不免矣。然而气虚血痿，最不可入劳瘵之门。吊丧问疾，衣服器用中皆能乘虚而染触。间有妇人入患者之房，患人见之思想，则其劳气随入，染患日久，莫不化而为虫。故凡亲近之人不能回避，须要饮食适宜，不可着饿。体若虚者，可服补药，身边可带安息香，大能杀劳虫。内有麝香，尤能辟恶，医者不可须臾无也。[88p]

When a person's vital energy is about to be extinguished, it escapes through the nine orifices and pores, striking those who are timid and weak, and after some time, it manifests as signs of illness. This is known as "transmitting the corpse." If a person regularly preserves their vital energy and cherishes their essence and blood, the illness cannot be transmitted. However, those who indulge in excessive desires and are unaware of their suffering will deplete their essence and blood, allowing malevolent energy to invade; this is true not only for men but also for women. Yet, those with weak energy and depleted blood are the most susceptible to illness. In mourning and during inquiries about ailments, clothing and utensils can transmit illness if one is not careful. If a woman enters the room of a patient, the patient, seeing her and thinking of her, can have their vital energy drawn in, causing sickness over time to transform into parasites. Therefore, those close to the afflicted must avoid contact, ensure that their food and drink are appropriate, and not be overly hungry. For those whose bodies are weak, nourishing medicine can be taken, and keeping a piece of benzoin nearby can effectively eliminate parasites. If it contains musk, it can prevent malevolent influences; physicians should never be without it.[88p]

　　　　　附上清紫庭追劳方论

　　传尸劳瘵，皆心受病，气血凝结，故有成虫者。盖由饮食酒色，忧思丧真，遂至于此。凡虫以血凝而气养之，气血在胞即为正气，气凝即为瘕块，凝在心部即为虫，悉由不正其心，懮思业缘所致。三尸九虫之为害，治者不可不知其详。九虫之内，而六虫传于六代，三虫不传者，谓蛔、寸、白也。其六虫或脏种毒而生，或亲属习染而传。疾之初觉，精神恍惚，气候不调，切在戒忌酒色，调节饮食。[89p]

Attached is a discussion on the pursuit of labor by the Qing Ziting.

Transmission of suffering and pestilence arises from the heart being afflicted. When qi and blood are stagnant, this results in the formation of parasites. This is primarily caused by indulgence in food, drink, and lust, along with worries and the loss of genuine essence, leading to such conditions. All parasites thrive on stagnant blood nourished by qi; in the body, the qi and blood represent the vital essence. When qi stagnates, it manifests as masses; when it becomes stagnant in the heart, it results in parasites. All these issues stem from improper thoughts and the afflictions caused by worry. The harms of the Three Corpses and Nine Parasites are matters of significance for practitioners to understand in detail. Among the Nine Parasites, six are transmitted through six generations, while the three that do not transmit are the roundworm, tapeworm, and threadworm. The six parasites may arise from poisonous substances within the organs or may be transmitted through familial habits. At the onset of these ailments, one may experience confusion of spirit and imbalances in qi. It is essential to refrain from indulgence in wine and lust and to regulate one’s diet carefully.[89p]

如或不然，五心烦热，寝汗忪悸，如此十日，顿成骨瘦，面黄光润，此其证也。妄信邪师，祈禳求福，庸医用药，延蔓岁时，方知病重，苟非警戒，祸福反掌。此人死后，兄弟子孙，骨肉亲属，绵绵相传，以至灭族。大抵六虫一句之中，遍行四穴，周而复始，病经遇木气而生，立春一日后方食起，三日一食，五日一退，方其作苦，百节皆痛。虫之食也，退即还穴醉睡，一醉五日，其病乍静。俟其退醉时，乃可投符用药。不然，虫熟睡于符药之后，不能治也。一虫在身中占十二穴，六虫共占七十二穴。[90p]

If it is otherwise, with five hearts troubled and heated, and experiencing night sweats and palpitations, after ten days one will become emaciated, with a sallow complexion and a glossy appearance. This is the symptom. If one blindly trusts in false masters, prays and seeks blessings, and relies on inept doctors and their medications, the condition will worsen over time. Only then will one realize the severity of the illness. If not careful, fortune and misfortune may turn on a dime. After this person passes away, their brothers, descendants, and relatives will pass it down through generations, potentially leading to the extinction of their family. Generally speaking, within the phrase 'six worms', they circulate throughout four cavities, repeating in cycles. The disease occurs when the wood qi is met, beginning to take hold a day after the start of spring, feasting every three days and retreating every five days, causing suffering and pain throughout the body. As for the 'food' of the worms, when they retreat, they return to their cavities and deeply sleep, intoxicated for five days, giving the appearance of temporary tranquility. It is only when they awaken that one may use charms and medication. Otherwise, if the worms are still deeply asleep under charms and medicine, healing cannot occur. One worm occupies twelve holes in the body, and six worms together occupy seventy-two holes.[90p]

一月之中，上十日，虫头向上，从心至头游四穴；中十日，虫头向内，从心至脐游四穴；下十日，虫头向下，从脐至足游四穴。盖虫性已通灵，切在精审。其或取虫不补，即学浅妄行，徒费赀财，终无去病之理，可不悲哉！师曰：治传尸劳者，先须知正气与毒气并行，故脏腑有凝，即成虫状。遇阳日长雄，阴日长雌，其先食脏腑脂膏，故其色白。五脏六腑，一经食损，即皮聚毛脱，妇人即月信不行，血脉皆损，不能荣五脏六腑也。七十日后，食人血肉尽，故其虫黄赤；损于肌肉，故变瘦劣，饮食不能为肌肤，筋缓不能收持。[91p]

In the first ten days of the month, with the insect's head facing upward, it travels through four points from the heart to the head; in the middle ten days, with the insect's head facing inward, it moves through four points from the heart to the navel; in the last ten days, with the insect's head facing downward, it traverses four points from the navel to the feet. The nature of the insect is already spiritualized, and it is essential to be precise in examination. If one collects the insect without replenishing, it indicates a shallow understanding and reckless behavior, merely wasting resources and ultimately failing to alleviate one’s illness—how tragic this is! The master said: To treat those exhausted by the influx of possession, one must first understand that the righteous and toxic energies coexist; therefore, when the organs become congested, they take on the form of insects. On sunny days, male insects grow longer, while on cloudy days, female insects do. They initially consume the fats of the organs, hence their white color. When the five organs and six entrails are depleted from being consumed, the skin gathers and hair falls out; for women, their menstrual cycles stop; blood vessels are all damaged, and they cannot nourish the five organs and six entrails. After seventy days, when they have consumed all the human blood and flesh, the insects become yellow and red; due to the damage to the muscles, they become emaciated and unable to sustain skin and flesh, and the tendons weaken and cannot hold firm.[91p]

一百二十日外，血肉食尽，故其虫紫，即食精髓；传于肾中食精，故其虫色黑。食髓即骨痿，不能起于床。诸虫久即生毛，毛色杂花，锺孕五脏五行之气，传之三人，即自能飞，其状如禽，亦多品类。传入肾经，不可救治。法之所载者，利药下虫后，其虫色白，可三十日服药补；其虫黄赤，可六十日服药补；其虫紫黑，此病已极，可百二十日服药补。又云：虫头赤者，食患人肉，可治；头口白者，食患人髓，其病难治，只宜断后。故经曰：六十日内，治者十得七八；八十日内，治者十得三四。过此以往，未知生全，但可为子孙除害耳。今以六代所传，虫状病证，详着于后。[92p]

After one hundred and twenty days, when flesh and blood have been consumed, the worms turn purple, and they begin to feed on essence; transmitted into the kidneys, they then appear black. Feeding on marrow leads to bone atrophy, making it impossible for one to rise from bed. When the worms exist for a long time, they grow hair, which has a mottled color, drawing in the energies of the five organs and five elements, and when transmitted to three individuals, they can fly, resembling birds with many varieties. Once they enter the kidney meridian, they cannot be treated. According to the texts, taking effective medicine after the worms appear, if the worms are white, one can take medicine for thirty days to supplement; if they are yellow or red, one can take medicine for sixty days; if they are purple or black, the disease has reached its limit, and one can take medicine for one hundred and twenty days to supplement. Furthermore, it is said: if the worms have a red head, they feed on the flesh of the afflicted person, and one can treat them; if the head and mouth are white, they feed on the marrow of the afflicted person, making the illness difficult to treat, and it is best to cut it off thereafter. Thus, the text states: within sixty days, those who treat have a success rate of seven or eight out of ten; within eighty days, the success drops to three or four out of ten. Beyond this period, it is unknown whether one can recover completely, but it may help remove harm for one's descendants. Now, based on the transmission from six generations, the conditions and symptoms of these worms are detailed below.[92p]

　　　　　第一代虫状病证游食日治法

　　其虫形如婴儿，长三寸，背有毛，或形如鬼状动走脏腑，或形如虾(虫麻)变动脏腑之中。凡人受病之后，顿觉憔悴，令人梦寐颠倒，魂魄飞扬，精神离散，饮食减少，形容渐瘦，四肢百节疼痛，憎寒壮热，背膊拘急，口苦舌干，面无颜色，鼻流清涕，虚汗常多。其虫遇丙丁日食起，醉归心俞穴中，四穴轮转，周而复始。俟虫大醉，方可医治。取出虫后，用药补心，宜服守灵散。
　　　　　第二代虫状病证游食日治法

　　其虫形如乱发，长三寸许，或形如蜈蚣，或似守宫，或形如虾蟹，俱在人脏腑之中。凡劳瘵若患此虫，令人神色如醉，夜梦不祥，梦与亡人为侣，心胸饱闷，四体不和，骨节枯槁，日渐瘦弱，酢心呕酸，咽干鼻塞，背脊酸疼，腰膝无力，唾吐脓血，头目不利，胸膈多痰，盗汗发热等证。其虫遇庚申日食起，醉归肺俞穴中，俟虫大醉，方可医治。取出虫后，补肺则瘥，宜服虚成散。[93p]

First Generation of Worm-like Illness Treatment Method

The worms resemble infants, about three inches long, with hair on their backs. They may take the form of spirits moving within the organs or resemble shrimp (insect hemp), shifting within the viscera. After being afflicted, individuals feel immediately weak, experience disturbed dreams, their spirits seem to fly away, and their energy becomes scattered. They eat less, appear gradually thinner, suffer pain in limbs and joints, dislike cold and feel overheated, experience tightness in the back, have a bitter mouth and dry tongue, show no color in the face, and have a runny nose with frequent copious sweat. The worms awaken on days of Bing and Ding, drunkenly returning to the heart's source points, with cycles repeating. Treatment can only commence once the worms are thoroughly intoxicated. After removal of the worms, tonify the heart, and it is advisable to take Shou Ling Powder.

Second Generation of Worm-like Illness Treatment Method

The worms appear like tangled hair, approximately three inches long, or resemble centipedes, lizards, or shrimp and crabs, all found within human organs. Symptoms from this worm-induced illness include a drunken appearance, ominous dreams involving deceased relatives, a feeling of heaviness in the chest, discord in the limbs, brittle bones, gradual weakness, sour ascension from the stomach, dry throat with nasal congestion, back pain, weakness in the lower back and knees, expectoration of purulent blood, head and eyes feeling unwell, and phlegm in the chest with night sweats and fever. The worms awaken on days of Geng and Shen, drunkenly returning to the lung source points, and treatment can only commence once the worms are thoroughly intoxicated. After removal of the worms, tonifying the lungs aids recovery, and it is advisable to take Xu Cheng Powder.[93p]

　　　　　第三代虫状病证游食日治法

　　其虫形如蚊蚁类，或如螳螂，或如碎血片，或如刺猬，或如毛虫，俱在人脏腑之中。劳证若有此虫，令人三焦多昏，日常思睡，呕吐苦汁，或吐清水粘涎，腹胀肠鸣，口鼻生疮，唇黑面青，日渐消瘦，精神恍惚，口燥咽干，目多昏泪。其虫庚寅日食起，醉归厥阴穴中四穴，俟虫大醉，方可治之。取虫之后，补气即愈。
　　　　　第四代虫状病证游食日治法

　　其虫形如乱丝，或如蛴螬虫，或如猪肝肺，或如蜩蝉，或如蛇虺，往来五脏之中。凡病此虫，令人脏腑虚鸣，呕逆，肠中痃癖气块，憎寒壮热，肚大筋青，咳嗽气促，口苦舌干，要吃酸咸之物。其虫遇戊己日食起，醉归脾俞穴中四穴，俟虫大醉，方可治之。取虫后，补脾即愈，宜服魂停散。[94p]

Third Generation Treatment Method for Insect-like Diseases

The insects resemble mosquitoes and ants, or resemble mantises, or appear as fragments of blood, or like hedgehogs, or like caterpillars, residing within the internal organs of the human body. Those suffering from this condition may exhibit symptoms such as dizziness in the three warmer regions, excessive drowsiness throughout the day, vomiting of bitter bile or clear water mixed with phlegm, abdominal distension and intestinal sounds, sores in the mouth and nose, black lips and a blue complexion, gradual weight loss, mental confusion, dry mouth and throat, and excessive tears. These insects emerge on the Gengyin day of the lunar calendar, intoxicated, returning to the four acupoints of the Jueyin channel. Once the insects become greatly intoxicated, treatment can begin. After the insects are expelled, replenishing Qi will lead to recovery.

Fourth Generation Treatment Method for Insect-like Diseases

The insects appear like tangled threads, or like grubs, or resemble pig liver or lungs, or like cicadas, or like snakes, moving within the five internal organs. Those afflicted with these insects may experience disturbances in their internal organs, vomiting, obstruction or gas accumulation in the intestines, aversion to cold and intense heat, a distended abdomen with taut muscles, coughing accompanied by shortness of breath, a bitter mouth and dry tongue, and a craving for sour and salty foods. These insects emerge on the Wujiyi day of the lunar calendar, intoxicated, returning to the four acupoints of the Spleen. Once the insects become greatly intoxicated, treatment can begin. After the insects are expelled, replenishing the Spleen will lead to recovery, and it is advisable to take Hun Ting San (an herbal formula).[94p]

　　　　　第五代虫状病证游食日治法

　　其虫形如鼠无毛，或有头无足，或有足无头，或如精血片。凡患此虫，入肝经而归肾，得血而更变也。令人多怒气逆，四肢解散，饮食减少，或面红润如平人，或时通灵而言未来事，或着床枕不起，有似中风，肢体顽麻，腹内多痛。其虫遇壬癸日食起，醉归肝俞穴中四穴，俟虫大醉，方可治之。取虫后，补肝即愈，宜服金明散。
　　　　　第六代虫状病证游食日治法

　　其虫有翅足全者，千里传疰，所谓飞尸，形如马尾，或有两条，一雌一雄，或如龟鳖，在人五脏之中，或如烂面，或如飞禽，或长或短。凡患此虫，令人思食百物，身体尫羸，腰膝无力，眼暗耳鸣，喘嗽不定，心腹闷乱。其虫遇丑亥日食起，醉归肾俞穴四穴，俟虫大醉，方可治之。取虫出，补肾填髓愈，宜服育婴散。[95p]

Fifth Generation Treatment Method for Worm-like Diseases

The worm resembles a hairless rat, or may have a head without limbs, or limbs without a head, or looks like fragments of essence and blood. Those suffering from this worm find it enters the liver meridian and returns to the kidneys, transforming upon encountering blood. This results in excessive anger, limb weakness, decreased appetite, and the face may appear flushed like a healthy person. Some may occasionally speak of future events while in a trance, or be bedridden with symptoms resembling a stroke, experiencing numbness and abdominal pain. The worm arises during the solar eclipses on the days of Ren and Gui, becoming intoxicated in the four Liver Shu points. Only when the worm is thoroughly intoxicated can it be treated. After extracting the worm, nourishing the liver will lead to recovery; it is advisable to take Jinming San.

Sixth Generation Treatment Method for Worm-like Diseases

The worm possesses wings and limbs, often referred to as "flying corpses," resembling a horse’s tail, sometimes with two, one male and one female, or like a tortoise, found within the five organs of a person, resembling rotten surface or birds, either long or short. Those afflicted by this worm will experience an insatiable desire for food, physical weakness, lack of strength in the waist and knees, dim eyesight, tinnitus, and irregular coughing. The worm arises during the solar eclipses on the days of Chou and Hai, becoming intoxicated in the four Kidney Shu points. Only when the worm is thoroughly intoxicated can it be treated. After extracting the worm, nourishing the kidneys and replenishing the marrow will lead to recovery; it is advisable to take Yuying San.[95p]

　　　　　苏游论

　　论曰：大抵传尸之候，在心胸胁满闷，臂膊烦疼，两目不明，四肢无力，虽欲寝卧，睡常不寐，脊膂急痛，腰膝酸疼，多卧少起，状如佯病。每至早旦，精神尚存，有如无病；日午之后，四体微热，面无颜色。喜见人过，常怀含怒，终不称意，即多嗔恚，行立脚弱，夜卧盗汗，梦与鬼交，或见先亡，或多惊怖，有时气息，有时咳嗽，虽思饮食，不能多餐，死在须臾，精神尚存，或时微利，两胁虚胀，口燥鼻干，常多粘唾，有时欲睡，渐觉沉羸，犹如涸鱼不觉死也。　　又曰：传尸之候，本起无端，莫问老少男女，皆有此疾。[96p]

On the Transmission of Corpse Symptoms

It is said: Generally, the signs of the transmission of corpse symptoms manifest as a feeling of fullness and discomfort in the chest, pain in the arms, unclear vision, weakness in the extremities, and despite the desire to sleep, one often cannot. There is sharp pain in the back, pain in the waist and knees, a tendency to lie down excessively while seldom getting up, presenting a condition resembling feigned illness. Every morning, the spirit seems intact, appearing as if one is well; however, after midday, the body feels slightly warm and the face lacks color. There is joy in seeing people pass by, yet one often harbors suppressed anger, remaining dissatisfied, leading to frequent irritability. The legs feel weak when standing or walking, there is night sweating during sleep, dreams involving spirits, encounters with the deceased, or numerous frightening experiences. At times, there may be shortness of breath or coughing. Although there is an urge for food, one cannot eat much; death might occur unexpectedly while the spirit lingers. Occasionally, there may be mild benefits, a feeling of emptiness and bloating in the sides, dry mouth and nose, excessive sticky saliva, an occasional desire for sleep, and a growing sense of weakness, similar to a dried fish that fails to perceive its death. Furthermore, it is noted: The symptoms of corpse transmission arise without discernible cause, and it matters not if one is old or young, male or female; all may suffer from this affliction.[96p]

大抵五行相克而生，先内传毒气，周遍五脏，渐热羸瘦以至于死。死讫，又传家亲一人，故曰传尸，亦名传疰。以其初传半卧半起，号曰殗殜。气息嗽者，名曰肺痿疾。骨髓疼，身中热，称为骨蒸。内传五脏，名曰伏连。不解疗者，乃至灭门。假如男女虚损得之，名曰劳极。吴楚乃名淋沥，巴蜀亦名劳极。其源先从肾起，初受之气，两胫酸疼，腰背拘急，行立脚弱，饮食减少，两耳飕飕，直似风声，夜卧遗泄，阴汗痿弱。肾既受讫，次传于心，心初受气，夜卧心惊，或多恐悸，心悬乏气，吸吸欲尽，梦见先亡，有时盗汗，饮食无味，口内生疮，心气烦热，惟欲眠卧，朝轻夕重，两颊口唇，悉皆红赤，如傅胭脂，或时手足五心烦热。[97p]

Generally, the five elements interact with and counteract each other, first transmitting toxic gas internally, spreading throughout the five organs, gradually causing heat and emaciation until death occurs. After death, it further spreads to a family member, hence called "transmitting the corpse" or "transmitting illness." Since it initially presents as half lying down and half sitting up, it is referred to as "the state of sickness." Those who experience coughing breath are called "lung wasting disease." Bone and marrow pain accompanied by internal heat is known as "bone steaming." When it transmits to the five organs, it is called "hidden connection." If treatment is not resolved, it may lead to extinction of the family. When men and women suffer from weakness, it is referred to as "exhaustion." In Wu and Chu, it is named "dripping," and in Ba and Shu, it is also called "exhaustion." Its origin first arises from the kidneys; at first, the energy causes the legs to feel sore, the lower back stiff, with weakness in standing and walking, diminished appetite, a whistling sound in both ears resembling wind, nighttime leakage, and weakness with sweating. Once the kidneys are affected, it next transmits to the heart. When the heart initially receives the energy, it causes nighttime panic, frequent palpitations, a feeling of suffocation, and dreams of those who have passed away. Sometimes it leads to night sweats, tastelessness in food, sores in the mouth, a hot and irritable heart, a strong desire to sleep, feeling light in the morning and heavy in the evening, with both cheeks and lips appearing red as if painted with rouge, and at times, the hands and feet feel hot and restless.[97p]

心受已讫，次传于肺，肺初受气，咳嗽，气力微痛，有时气喘，卧则更甚，鼻口干燥，不闻香臭，如或忽闻，惟觉朽腐恶气，有时恶心，愦愦欲吐，肌肤枯燥，时或疼痛，或似虫行，干皮细起，状若麸片。肺既受已，次传于肝，肝初受气，两目(目巟)(目巟)，面无血色，常欲颦眉，眼视不远，目常干濇，又时赤痛，或复睛黄，朝昏暮愦，常欲合眼，及时睡卧，常睡不着。肝既受已，次传于脾，脾初受气，两胁虚胀，食不消化，又时泻痢，水谷生虫，有时肚痛，腹胀雷鸣，唇口焦干，或生疮肿，毛发干耸，无有光润，或时上气，撑肩喘息，痢赤黑汁，见此证者，则不治也。[98p]

Once the heart has been affected, it is next transmitted to the lungs. The lungs, upon initially receiving the air, may induce coughing, with a slight pain in the breath, occasional shortness of breath that worsens when lying down, dryness in the nose and mouth, an inability to smell fragrances or odors, and when there are sudden scents, only the unpleasant smell of decay is perceived. Sometimes there may be nausea, a feeling of impending vomiting, dry skin that may hurt intermittently, or sensations like insects crawling, with dry, thin skin resembling flour sheets. Once the lungs are affected, the condition moves to the liver. The liver, upon initially receiving the air, presents with dull eyes, a pale face, a tendency to frown, limited vision, dry eyes, occasional redness and pain in the eyes, a persistent feeling of heaviness leading to a desire to close the eyes and sleep, yet often struggling to maintain sleep. Once the liver is affected, the condition shifts to the spleen. The spleen, initially receiving the air, leads to a feeling of emptiness and bloating in the sides, indigestion of food, occasional diarrhea, possibly resulting in water and grain becoming parasitic, and at times abdominal pain with rumbling in the belly, dry and cracked lips or sores, dry hair that lacks luster, occasional shortness of breath with shoulder tension, bloody diarrhea with blackish fluid. If such symptoms are observed, they are deemed untreatable.[98p]

　　夫骨蒸、殗殜、复连、尸疰、虫疰、毒疰、热疰、冷疰、食疰、鬼疰等，皆曰传尸者，以疰者注也，病自上疰也，与人相似，故曰疰。其变有二十二种，或三十六种，或九十九种。大略令人寒热盗汗，梦与鬼交，遗精白浊，发干而耸，或腹内有块，或脑后两边有小结，复连数个，或聚或散，沉沉默默，咳嗽痰涎，或咯脓血，如肺痿肺痈状，或复下痢，羸瘦困乏，不自胜持，积月累年，以至于死，死复传疰，易传亲人，乃至灭门者是也。更有蜚虫、遁尸、寒尸、丧尸、尸疰等，谓之五尸，及大小附着等证，不的知其所苦，无处不恶，乃挟诸鬼邪而害人，其证多端，传变推迁，难以推测。故自古及今，愈此病者，十不一得。所谓狸骨、獭肝、天灵盖、铜锁鼻，徒有其说，未尝取效。惟膏肓俞崔氏穴法，若早灸之，可否几半，晚亦不济也。[99p]

There are various ailments such as bone steaming, sudden death, recurring illnesses, corpse-related conditions, insect-related ailments, toxic influences, heat-related sicknesses, cold-related illnesses, food-related disorders, and ghost-related afflictions, all referred to as "transmitted illnesses" due to their similar manifestations in the sick. These conditions arise from above, resembling each other, hence termed “illness.” There are approximately twenty-two, thirty-six, or even ninety-nine variations. Generally, they lead to symptoms of cold, heat, and sweat theft, dreams involving spirits, nocturnal emissions, dry and erect hair, abdominal lumps, small nodules on either side of the head, recurring clusters, whether gathered or scattered, heavy and silent conditions, coughing up phlegm, purulent blood resembling lung tuberculosis or lung abscesses, or recurring dysentery, leading to emaciation and fatigue, overwhelming individuals until death occurs, which may also be transmitted after death, easily affecting family members, leading sometimes to the extinction of a household. Furthermore, there are ailments involving flying insects, evasion of corpses, cold corpses, loss of life, and corpse-related illnesses referred to as the “five corpses,” along with signs of minor and major afflictions. Without knowing the source of suffering, there is no escape from evil, and these ailments may involve various malevolent spirits, causing complex symptoms that are difficult to predict. Thus, from ancient times to the present, only one in ten recover from these diseases. The so-called remedies like badger bones, otter livers, heavenly lids, and copper locks for the nose are merely spoken of and have yet to show any efficacy. Only the methods targeting the "Gao Huang" and the "Cui" acupoints, if treated promptly with moxibustion, may offer some hope; delaying treatment yields little benefit.[99p]

　　　　医贯 【明　赵献可】

　　　　　阴虚发热论

　　世间发热类伤寒者数种，治各不同。伤寒伤风及寒疫也，则用仲景法；温病及瘟疫也，则用河间法。此皆论外感者也。今人一见发热，皆认作伤寒，率用汗药以发其表，汗后不解，又用表药以凉其肌，柴胡、凉膈、白虎、双解等汤，杂然并进。若是虚证，岂不殆哉！自东垣出而发内伤补中益气之论，此用气药以补气之不足者也。至于劳心好色，内伤真阴，真阴既伤，则阳无所附，故亦发热，其人必面赤烦躁，口渴引饮，骨痛脉数而大，或尺数而无力者是也。惟丹溪发明补阴之说，以四物汤加黄蘗、知母，此用血药以补血之不足者也。世俗相因，屡用不效何耶？盖因阴字认不真，误以血为阴耳。[100p]

On the Heat from Yin Deficiency

In the world, there are various types of febrile diseases akin to typhoid, and their treatments differ. For typhoid, cold-induced ailments, and cold epidemics, the methods of Zhongjing are used; for warm diseases and plagues, those of Hejian are employed. These discuss exterior pathogenic influences. Nowadays, when people see a fever, they immediately diagnose it as typhoid and generally use sweating medications to release the exterior. If the fever does not resolve after sweating, they then employ exterior-cooling medicines like Chaihu, Liangge, Baihu, and Shuangle. If this is a deficiency syndrome, is this not perilous? Emerging from Dongyuan’s theory, the discussion centers on internal injuries and the supplementation of qi. This use of qi tonics addresses the insufficiency of qi. As for indulging in excessive thinking and sexual desires, it can harm the true yin; when the true yin is depleted, the yang has nothing to rely on, thus it also causes fever. Such individuals will surely have flushed faces, irritability, thirst, pain in the bones, and rapid, strong pulses; some may have a weak and slow pulse. Danxi elucidated the principle of nourishing yin, using a concoction of the Four Substance Decoction with Huangbai and Zhimu, thereby employing blood tonics to replenish the deficiency of blood. Why do common practices often yield no effect? It is because the concept of yin is misunderstood, confusing blood for yin.[100p]

当作肾中之真阴，即先天也。《内经》曰：诸寒之而热者取之阴，诸热之而寒者取之阳，所谓求其属也。王太仆先生注云：大寒而盛，热之不热，是无火也；大热而盛，寒之不寒，是无水也。又云：倏忽往来，时发时止，是无火也；昼见夜伏，夜见昼止，时节而动，是无水也。当求其属而主之。无火者，宜益火之源，以消阴翳；无水者，宜壮水之主，以镇阳光。必须六味、八味二丸，出入增减，以补真阴，屡用屡效。若泥黄蘗、知母苦寒之说，必致损伤脾阴而毙者，不可胜举。大抵病热作渴，饮冷便秘，此属实热，人皆知之。或恶寒发热，引衣蜷卧，四肢逆冷，大便清利，此属真寒，人亦易知。[101p]

When considering the true yin within the kidneys, this refers to the original essence. The "Huangdi Neijing" states: those who are cold and then heated tend to draw from yin, while those who are hot and then cold tend to draw from yang; this is what is meant by seeking its true nature. Mr. Wang Taifu notes: great cold yet vibrant, heated without heat, signifies an absence of fire; great heat yet vibrant, cold without cold, signifies an absence of water. He further notes: sudden back-and-forth, at times appearing and at times stopping, indicates an absence of fire; appearing by day and hidden by night, revealed again by day, moving with the seasons, indicates an absence of water. Therefore, one must seek its true nature and govern it. Where there is no fire, one should nourish the source of fire to dispel the obscuring yin; where there is no water, one should strengthen the master of water to settle the yang light. It is essential to use the Six Flavors and Eight Flavors pills, adjusting their intake to replenish the true yin, yielding repeated effectiveness. However, following theories of bitter cold substances like mud yellow bracken and Anemarrhena may lead to damage of the spleen yin and numerous consequences. As a general principle, when illness presents as heat causing thirst, and drinking cold leads to constipation, this signifies true heat, which is widely recognized. Conversely, when one experiences aversion to cold with fever, pulling clothes tightly and curling up, with limbs feeling cold and clear stools, this indicates true cold, which is also easily recognized.[101p]

至于烦扰狂越，不欲近衣，欲坐卧泥水中，此属假热之证。其甚者，烦极发躁，渴饮不绝，舌如芒刺，两唇[唇：原作「肾」，据《医贯》卷四阴虚发热论改。]燥裂，面如涂朱，身如焚燎，足心如烙，吐痰如涌，喘急，大便秘结，小便淋沥，三部脉洪大而无伦。当是时也，却似承气证，承气入口即毙；却似白虎证，白虎下咽即亡。若用二丸，缓不济事。急以加减八味丸料一斤，内肉桂一两，以水顿煎五六碗，冰冷与饮，诸证自退。翊日，必畏寒脉脱，是无火也，当补其阳，急以附子八味丸料煎服自愈。此证与脉俱变其常，而不以常法治之者也。若有产后及大失血后，阴血暴伤，必大发热，亦名阴虚发热，此阴字正谓气血之阴。[102p]

As for the disturbances of extreme heat and restlessness, where one does not wish to wear clothes and desires to sit or lie in mud and water, this indicates a false heat condition. In severe cases, there is intense agitation, incessant thirst, a tongue like a thorn, dry and cracked lips, a face resembling red paint, the body feeling as if burned, soles of the feet feeling as if seared, expectoration resembling a surge, labored breathing, constipation, and painful urination, with the three pulse positions large and chaotic. At this time, it resembles the symptoms of purgation syndrome, where purgation leads to immediate danger; it also resembles the symptoms of the White Tiger syndrome, where ingestion leads to demise. If using mere pills, the condition will not improve. Instead, one must urgently prepare a modified Eight Flavor Formula, with one pound of ingredients, including one tael of cinnamon, boiled with water to make five or six bowls, and given chilled for drinking; all symptoms will subside. The next day, one must fear a cold pulse deficit, indicating lack of fire, thus needing to replenish Yang urgently with Aconite Eight Flavor Pills to recover. This condition and pulse deviate from the norm, and one must not treat it with conventional methods. In cases following childbirth or significant blood loss, where Yin blood is severely damaged, one will inevitably experience intense fever, also known as Yin deficiency fever; the term "Yin" here specifically refers to the Yin of Qi and blood.[102p]

若以凉药正治立毙，正所谓象白虎汤证，悞服白虎汤必死。当此之时，偏不用四物汤。盖有形之血不能速化，几希之气所宜急固，须用独参汤，或当归补血汤，使无形生出有形来，此阳生阴长之妙用，不可不知也。或问曰：子之论则详矣，气虚血虚，均是内伤，何以辨之？予曰：悉乎子之问也！盖阴虚者面必赤，无根之火戴于上也。若是阳证，火入于内，面必不赤。其口渴者，肾水干枯，引水自救也。，但口虽渴而舌必滑，脉虽数而尺必无力，甚者尺虽洪数而按之必不鼓，此为辨耳。虽然，若问其人曾服过凉药，脉亦有力而鼓指矣。戴复庵云：服凉药而脉反加数者，火郁也，宜升宜补，切忌寒凉，犯之必死。临证之工，更宜详辨。毫厘之差，枉人性命。慎哉！慎哉！
　　　　医门法律 【清　喻昌】[103p]

If a person is treated with cool herbs and inevitably dies, it is just like the case with the Bai Hu Decoction; taking Bai Hu Decoction will certainly lead to death. At such a time, one must not use Si Wu Decoction. The reason is that the physical blood cannot be transformed quickly, while the ethereal essence requires urgent reinforcement. One must use Du Shen Decoction or Dang Gui Blood Supplement Decoction to ensure the formless gives birth to the form. This is the subtle use of Yang giving birth to Yin and must not be overlooked.

Someone might ask: Your discussion is detailed. Both Qi deficiency and blood deficiency are internal injuries; how do you differentiate them? I respond: Your question is entirely appropriate! Indeed, if Yin is deficient, the face must be red, indicating a rootless fire above. If it is a Yang syndrome, the fire would enter within, and the face would not be red. If there is thirst, it means the kidney water is depleted, and one craves water as a means of self-rescue. However, though the mouth is thirsty, the tongue must be slippery, and although the pulse may be rapid, the pulse at the wrist must lack strength. In severe cases, even if the pulse at the wrist is strong and rapid, pressing it will not yield a hearty beat; this is how to differentiate.

Nevertheless, if one questions a person who has taken cool herbs and finds that the pulse is strong and buoyant, it indicates accumulated fire; they should be lifted and supplemented, carefully avoiding coldness as violating this will certainly lead to death. Practitioners at the bedside should further differentiate with care; a slight mistake could cost someone their life. Be cautious! Be cautious![103p]

　　　　　总论

　　虚劳之证，《金匮》叙于血痹之下，可见劳则必劳其精血也。营血伤则内热起，五心常热，目中生花见火，耳内蛙聒蝉鸣，口舌糜烂，不知正味，鼻孔干燥，呼吸不利；乃至饮食不为肌肤，怠惰嗜卧，骨软足酸，营行日迟，卫行日疾，营血为卫气所迫，不能内守而脱出于外，或吐或衄，或出二阴之窍，血出既多，火热迸入，逼迫煎熬，漫无休止，营血有立尽而已，不死何待耶？更有劳之之极，而血痹不行者，血不脱于外，而但畜于内，畜之日久，周身血走之隧道，悉痹不流，惟就干涸，皮鲜滑泽，面无荣润，于是气之所过，血不为动，徒蒸血为热，或日晡、或子午，始必干热，俟蒸气散，微汗而热解，热蒸不已，瘵病成焉，不死又何待耶？亦有始因脱血，后遂血痹者，血虚血少，艰于流布，发热致痹，尤易易也。《内经》凡言虚病，不及于劳。然于大肉枯槁，大骨陷下，胸中气高，五脏各见危证，则固已言之。[104p]

General Discussion

The signs of deficiency caused by exertion are described in the "Golden Coffer" under blood stagnation, indicating that exertion must harm one's essence and blood. When the nutritive blood is harmed, internal heat arises, leading to a constant feeling of heat in the five hearts, visions of flowers and fire in the eyes, croaking of frogs and chirping of cicadas in the ears, deterioration of the tongue and mouth, loss of taste, dryness of the nostrils, and difficulty in breathing. This results in food not benefiting the skin, lethargy and excessive sleeping, weak bones and sore feet, slow movement of the nutritive qi, and rapid movement of the defensive qi, as the nutritive blood is pressured by the defensive qi, unable to remain inside and instead escapes outside—either through vomiting or nosebleeds, or from the two lower orifices. When blood loss is significant and fiery heat rushes in relentlessly, the suffering is unending; when the nutritive blood is entirely depleted, what is left but death?

Moreover, there are cases where extreme exertion leads to stagnation without blood loss; here, blood does not escape outside but is merely accumulated within. Over time, this stagnation prevents normal flow throughout the body's blood vessels, leading to dryness and a lack of vitality in the skin, devoid of luster and moisture. Thus, where the qi flows, the blood remains unmoved, merely accumulating heat as steam, either during the day or at noon, causing intense dryness and heat. Once the steam disperses, a slight sweat may relieve the heat, but if the steam persists, illness may worsen—what more is needed but death? There are also cases where blood is initially lost, later leading to stagnation; when blood is deficient and scarce, circulation becomes difficult, and heat induces stagnation, which is particularly easy to develop.

The "Inner Canon" speaks of deficiency diseases without addressing exertion. Yet, when large amounts of meat become shriveled, when major bones sink, when the qi in the chest rises, and when the five organs each show signs of danger, this too has been well noted.[104p]

未有劳之之极，而真脏脉不见者也。然枯槁已极，即真脏脉不见，亦宁有不死者乎？秦越人始发虚损之论，谓虚而感寒则损其阳，阳虚则阴盛，损则自上而下。一损损于肺，皮聚而毛落；二损损于心，血脉不能荣养脏腑；三损损于胃，饮食不为肌肤。虚而感热则损其阴，阴虚则阳盛，损则自下而上。一损损于肾，骨痿不起于床；二损损于肝，筋缓不能自收持；三损损于脾，饮食不能消化。[105p]

When there is no extreme exhaustion, the true organs and pulses may not be visible. However, when withered and depleted to the utmost, indeed the true organs and pulses will not be seen; could there be anyone who does not die? The Qin Yue people began to discuss the theory of deficiency, stating that when one is deficient and encounters cold, it depletes the yang. When the yang is deficient, the yin becomes excessive, leading to damage that descends from above. First, damage to the lungs causes the skin to gather, leading to hair loss; second, damage to the heart prevents the blood vessels from nourishing the organs; third, damage to the stomach results in food not benefiting the skin. Conversely, when deficient and encountering heat, it depletes the yin, and when the yin is deficient, the yang becomes excessive, leading to damage that ascends from below. First, damage to the kidneys causes weakness in the bones, preventing one from getting out of bed; second, damage to the liver causes the tendons to loosen, making it unable to contract; third, damage to the spleen prevents food from being digested.[105p]

自上而下者，过于胃则不可治；自下而上者，过于脾则不可治。盖饮食多，自能生血，饮食少则血不生，血不生则阴不足以配阳，势必五脏齐损。越人归重脾胃，旨哉言矣！至仲景，《金匮》之文，昌细会其大意，谓精生于谷，谷入少而不生其血，血自不能化精。《内经》于精不足者必补之以味。味者，五谷之味也。补以味而节其劳，则积贮渐富，大命不倾。设以鸡口之入，为牛后之出，欲其不成虚势，宁可得乎？所以垂训十则，皆以无病男子精血两虚为言，而虚劳之候，焕若指掌矣。[106p]

Those who approach from above, if they overindulge in food, cannot be cured; those who approach from below, if they neglect the spleen, also cannot be cured. This is because excessive eating can naturally produce blood, while insufficient eating means blood cannot be generated. Without the production of blood, the yin cannot adequately support the yang, leading to damage to all five organs. The people of Yue emphasize the importance of the spleen and stomach—how insightful this is! Regarding Zhongjing, the texts of the "Golden Coffer" summarize its main ideas, stating that essence is produced from grain, and if grain intake is low, blood will not be produced, thus the blood cannot transform into essence. The "Inner Canon" states that if there is insufficient essence, it must be replenished with flavors. Flavors refer to the tastes of the five grains. By supplementing with flavors and moderating effort, the reserves gradually become abundant, and great misfortune is avoided. If one uses a small mouth of a chicken for the output of a large cow, can one expect it to not become weak? Thus, the ten teachings emphasize the dual deficiency of vital energy and blood in healthy men, illustrating the signs of deficiency labor as clear as a finger pointing.[106p]

夫男子平人但知纵欲劳精，抑孰知阴精日损，饮食无味，转劳转虚，转虚转劳，脉从内变，色不外华，津液衰而口渴小便少，甚则目瞑衄血，阴精不交自走，盗汗淋漓，身体振摇，心胆惊怯者，比比然也，故血不化精则血痹矣。血痹则新血不生，并素有之血，亦瘀积不行。血瘀则营虚，营虚则发热，热久则蒸其所瘀之血，化而为虫，遂成传尸瘵证。穷凶极厉，竭人之神气，养虫之神气，人死则虫亦死。[107p]

Men, in their pursuit of desires, often overlook the loss of essence. They indulge without recognizing that their vitality diminishes daily. Their food loses flavor, and as they grow weary, they also grow weaker. This cycle of labor and exhaustion affects their pulse, their complexion lacks luster, and their bodily fluids decrease, leading to thirst and diminished urination. In severe cases, they may experience blurred vision, nosebleeds, and involuntary emissions; they sweat profusely and tremble, filled with fear and anxiety. When the blood fails to transform into essence, it leads to blood stagnation. This stagnation prevents the generation of new blood and causes the already existing blood to become stagnant and uncirculated. As blood stagnates, the nutrients become deficient, resulting in fever. Prolonged heat then steams the stagnated blood, transforming it into parasites, ultimately leading to consumptive illnesses. Extreme conditions exhaust a person's vitality, nourishing the parasites; when a person dies, the parasites also perish.[107p]

其游魂之不死者，传亲近之一脉，附入血隧，似有如无，其后虫日荣长，人日雕悴，阅三传而虫之为灵，非符药所能制矣。医和视晋平公疾曰：是近女室，晦而生内热惑蛊之疾，非鬼非食，不可为也。惑即下唇有疮，虫食其肛，其名为惑之蛊[蛊：原作「或　虫」，据《医门法律》卷六虚劳论改。]。蛊字取义，三虫共载一器，非鬼非食，明指虫之为厉，不为尊者讳也。以故狐惑之证声哑嗄，劳瘵之证亦声哑嗄，是则声哑者，气管为虫所蚀明矣。男子前车之覆，古今不知几千亿人矣。[108p]

The wandering souls that do not die are said to be connected to a lineage of ancestors, attached to the blood pathways, appearing as if they exist and yet do not. Subsequently, the worms thrive and grow, while humanity withers over time. After three generations, the essence of the worm becomes spiritual; it cannot be controlled by talismans or medicines.

When the physician He examined Duke Ping of Jin's illness, he said: it is due to being close to women’s quarters, concealed and resulting in internal heat causing bewildering ailments; it is neither ghost nor food, and cannot be treated. The 'bewilderment' refers to sores on the lower lip, and worms consuming the rectum, which is called the 'bewilderment worm' (the original text had "或虫," but was corrected according to "Medical Laws," volume six, on hypochondria).

The term for 'worm' here signifies that three worms inhabit one vessel; it is neither ghost nor food, explicitly indicating the malevolence of the worm, not avoiding mention for the sake of the noble. Hence, the symptoms of fox bewilderment include hoarseness and huskiness, and the symptoms of consumption also include hoarseness and huskiness; this indicates that when the voice is hoarse, the trachea is gnawed by the worm.

The lessons of past failures in men are innumerable, with countless billions across the ages.[108p]

巢氏《病源》不察，谓有虚劳、有蒸病、有注病，劳有五劳六极七伤，蒸有五蒸二十四蒸，注有三十六种、九十九种，另各分门异治。后人以歧路之多，茫然莫知所适，且讳其名曰痰火，而梦梦者遂谓痰火有虚有实，乃至充栋诸方，妄云肺虚用某药，肺实用某药，以及心肝脾肾，咸出虚实两治之法，是于虚损虚劳中，添出实损实劳矣，鄙陋何至是耶！仲景于男子平人谆谆致戒，无非谓荣卫之道，纳谷为宝。居常调荣卫以安其谷，寿命之本，积精自刚，居常节嗜欲以生其精。至病之甫成，脉才见端，惟恃建中、复脉为主治。[109p]

The text discusses the views of the Chao family in "Sources of Illness," which mistakenly identifies various conditions such as consumption, steaming illnesses, and obstructive diseases. It categorizes labor into five types of exhaustion, six extremes, and seven injuries; steaming into five types and twenty-four varieties; and obstruction into thirty-six or ninety-nine kinds, each with different treatments. Consequently, later generations faced confusion due to the multitude of paths available, leaving them unsure of what to follow. They even referred to it as phlegm and fire, leading to misguided notions about phlegm and fire being either deficient or excessive, resulting in an abundance of prescriptions that misapply treatments for lung deficiency and lung excess, as well as for the heart, liver, spleen, and kidneys. This led to the erroneous addition of real damage to the discussion of deficiency and exhaustion, displaying a lamentable ignorance. Zhang Zhongjing cautioned men about the importance of nourishing and protecting one's vitality, emphasizing that grains are treasures. By continually regulating nourishment and safeguarding one's essence, one ensures longevity. One should accumulate energy firmly and practice moderation in desires to sustain this essence. When illness first manifests and the pulse begins to show signs, relying on the principles of regulating the center and restoring the pulse becomes the primary treatment.[109p]

夫建中、复脉，皆稼穑作甘之善药，一遵精不足者补之以味之旨也。岂有泉之竭矣，不云自中之理哉？后人补肾诸方，千蹊万径，以治虚劳，何反十无一全？岂非依样壶卢，徒资话柄耶？及其血痹不行，仲景亟驱其旧，生其新，几希于劳瘵将成未成之间，诚有一无二之圣法，但牵常者不能用耳。试观童子脏腑脆嫩，才有寒热积滞，易于结癖成疳，待其血痹不行，气蒸发热，即不可为。女子血干经闭，发热不止，劳瘵之候更多，待其势成，纵有良法，治之无及。倘能服膺仲景几先之哲，吃力于男子童子女子瘵病将成未成之界，其活人之功，皆是起白骨而予以生，全为彼苍所眷注矣。[110p]

The methods of Jianzhong and Fumai are both excellent remedies for cultivating sweetness in crops. They adhere to the principle that what is lacking in essence must be supplemented by flavor. How could it be that the spring has dried up without the principle being understood? Those who follow the remedies for kidney supplementation in later generations, along countless paths, in treating deficiency and fatigue, rarely achieve completeness. Is it not merely copying others and providing empty talk? When the blood stagnates and does not flow, Zhongjing urgently seeks to drive out the old and generate the new, hoping to catch the moment before fatigue and illness fully develop. There may indeed be profound methods, but common practices cannot apply them. Observe how a young person's organs are delicate. With a mere accumulation of cold and heat, it becomes easy for them to develop lumps and consumptive lesions. Once blood stagnates and does not flow, and vitality vaporizes with heat, intervention becomes impossible. For women, if the blood is deficient and the menses cease, and fever persists, the signs of fatigue and illness become more pronounced. Waiting until this condition solidifies, even with effective methods, they cannot be treated. If only one could internalize the wisdom of Zhongjing and the ancients, striving at the threshold of sickness in men, women, and children, before it fully manifests, the ability to restore life would be like raising the bones of the deceased to give them life again, all dependent on the concern of the heavens.[110p]

　　　　　论脉

　　虚劳之脉，皆不足之候，为精气内夺，与邪气外入之实脉，常相反也。黄帝问何谓重虚？岐伯对以脉气上虚尺虚，是谓重虚，谓其上下皆虚也。气虚者言无常也，谓其脉之无常也。尺虚者行步恇然，谓其步履之不正也。脉虚者不象阴也，谓其脉全不似手太阴脉之充盛也。皆易明也。独脉之无常，从来谓是上焦阳气虚，故其脉无常。果尔则下焦阴气虚，脉更无常矣。观下文云如此者滑则生，濇则死。濇脉且主死，而寸脉之无常，宁复有人理哉？故气虚者，言无常也。此一语明谓上气之虚，由胸中宗气之虚，故其动之应手者无常耳。乃知无常之脉，指左乳下之动脉为言。有常则宗气不虚，无常则宗气大虚，而上焦之气，始厌厌不足也。后之论脉者，失此一段精微，但宗越人所述损脉，而引伸触类，曰脉来软者为虚，缓者为虚，滞为虚，芤为中虚，弦为中虚，脉来细而微者血气俱虚，脉小者血气俱少，脉沉小迟者脱气。[111p]

On Pulse Diagnosis

The pulse of deficiency in "Xu Lao" (虚劳, Xu syndrome) reflects an insufficiency, as it indicates an internal loss of essence and energy, contrasting the solid pulse from external pathogenic influences. The Yellow Emperor asked, what is "heavy deficiency"? Qi Bo replied that it refers to the pulse being weak, with both the superficial and deep aspects being deficient. When the qi is deficient, it is said to be irregular, meaning the pulse is without consistency. When the pulse is weak, it indicates unstable movement, suggesting that one’s gait is unsteady. The weak pulse does not resemble the fullness of the Taiyin pulse in the hand; this concept is easy to understand.

The irregularity of the pulse has traditionally been attributed to a deficiency of Yang energy in the upper jiao, resulting in an unstable pulse. If this is the case, then a deficiency of Yin energy in the lower jiao leads to even greater irregularities. The subsequent text states that a slippery pulse indicates vitality, while a choppy pulse suggests death. A choppy pulse signifies that death is imminent, and if the cun pulse is also irregular, how can it signify life? Therefore, the term referring to qi deficiency indicates irregularity. This specifically points to the artery under the left breast.

Where there is regularity, the ancestral qi is not deficient; where there is irregularity, the ancestral qi is greatly deficient, and thus the qi of the upper jiao becomes increasingly insufficient. Later discussions on pulse diagnosis neglect this subtlety, merely refining upon the observations of previous scholars regarding the pulse, asserting that a soft pulse is deficient, a slow pulse indicates deficiency, a stagnant pulse suggests deficiency, a wiry pulse indicates a moderate deficiency, and a thin pulse suggests both blood and qi are deficient. A small pulse suggests low blood and qi, while a heavy, small, and delayed pulse indicates an escape of qi.[111p]

虚损之脉，似可一言而毕，实未足以尽其底里。赖仲景更其名为虚劳，虚劳之脉，多兼浮大，当于前人论脉，合参浮大与否。所以谓：男子平人脉大为劳，极虚亦为劳。又谓：脉浮者里虚。又谓：劳之为病其脉浮大，手足烦，春夏剧，秋冬瘥。男子脉浮弱而濇为无子。脉得诸芤动微紧，男子失精，女子梦交。脉极虚芤迟为清谷亡血失精。脉虚弱细微者，善盗汗。而总结其义曰：脉弦而大，弦则为减，大则为芤，减则为寒，芤则为虚，虚寒相搏，此名为革，妇人则半产漏下，男子则亡血失精。可见浮大弦紧，外象有余，其实中藏不足，不颛泥迟缓微弱一端以验脉。而脉之情状，莫能逃于指下，即病之疑似，莫不炫于胸中。仲景之承前启后，岂苟焉而已哉？昌不揣愚陋，已着大气论于卷首，发明胸中大气宗气所关之重，因辨岐伯所指脉气上虚为宗气之虚，以见重虚之脉，乳下宗气在所当诊，固堂下指陈，未必堂上首肯，然不可谓门外汉也。[112p]

The pulse of deficiency and damage can be summarized in a few words, yet it cannot fully express its depth. It is thanks to Zhongjing that it has been named "deficiency labor." The pulse of deficiency labor is often characterized by being floating and large, which should be considered alongside whether it is floating and large in previous discussions on pulse. Therefore, it is said: a man with a large, floating pulse indicates labor, and extreme deficiency also indicates labor. Moreover, a floating pulse suggests internal deficiency. It is stated that the illness of labor presents a floating and large pulse, accompanied by restlessness in the hands and feet, worsening in spring and summer, but recovering in autumn and winter. A man with a floating, weak, and slack pulse may suffer from infertility. If the pulse is knotted and slightly tense, it suggests the man has lost essence or that a woman dreams of unions. An extremely weak and slack pulse may indicate loss of essence due to depletion of blood. A weak and thin pulse is conducive to spontaneous sweating. In summary, it is stated: a pulse that is tight and large signifies reduction; a large pulse indicates vacuity; reduction signifies coldness; and vacuity indicates deficiency. When deficiency and cold combat each other, this is termed as "reform." For women, this can lead to abnormal discharge after childbirth; for men, it implies loss of blood and essence. It is evident that a large and floating pulse appears well outwardly but actually hides a lack internally. One cannot escape the nuances beneath the fingers, and the symptoms of diseases cannot help but reflect back in one's chest. Zhongjing's continuance from the past to the present is not merely casual. Though I, Chang, may be foolish and incapable, I have placed the discussion of vital energy at the scroll's beginning, elaborating the significance concerning the essence and energy of the chest. This was in response to Qibo's indication of the pulse as being vacuous, highlighting the importance of recognizing the severity of the vacuous pulse; the essence beneath the breast certainly warrants diagnosis. Thus, the indications may be expressed beneath the hall, yet it is not necessarily endorsed by those above, but one cannot dismiss it as a novice outside the door.[112p]

　　　　　杂论

　　《针经》云：形气不足，病气不足，此阴阳俱不足也，不可刺之。刺之重不足，重不足则阴阳俱竭，气血皆虚，五脏空虚，筋骨髓枯，老者绝灭，壮者不复矣。按形者，形骸也；气者，口鼻呼吸之气也。形骸消灭，视壮盛者迥殊。气息喘促，或短而不足以息，视劳役形体气不急促者迥殊。病气不足，懒语困弱，是正气内亏，视外邪暗助精神反增者迥殊。此不可刺，宜补之以甘药。甘药正稼穑作甘，培补中央，以灌输脏腑百脉之良药。此法惟仲景遵之；其次则东垣、丹溪亦宗之。但东垣引以证内伤而不及外感，丹溪引以证阴虚而不及阳损，此圣域贤关之分量也。[113p]

　　　　　Mixed Discussions

The "Classic of Acupuncture" states: When the form and qi are both insufficient, it is inadequate to use acupuncture. If one were to puncture despite this deficiency, it would exhaust both yin and yang, leading to a depletion of qi and blood, emptying of the five organs, and withering of the bones and marrow. The elderly would be completely extinguished, and the young would not recover. The "form" refers to the physical body; "qi" refers to the breath inhaled through the mouth and nose. When the physical body diminishes, those who appear strong and robust are starkly different. When breathing is labored and short, insufficient to sustain life, it is distinctly different from someone whose body and energy are not hurried by toil. Insufficient pathogenic qi leads to lethargy and weakness, indicating a deficiency of the righteous qi inside, markedly different from external evils that darken the spirit and cause an increase in symptoms. In such cases, acupuncture should not be employed; instead, one should supplement it with sweet herbs. Sweet herbs are used to nourish and support the center, providing good medicine to nourish the organs and enable the circulation of blood. This method is strictly observed by Zhongjing; others like Dongyuan and Danxi also follow this principle. However, Dongyuan corroborates it with internal injuries rather than external influences, while Danxi supports it in cases of yin deficiency, not addressing the loss of yang. This distinction is the weight of the learned and the worthy within the sacred domain.[113p]

　　秦越人发明虚损一证，优入圣域，虽无方可考，然其论治损之法，损其肺者益其气，损其心者调其荣卫，损其脾者调其饮食适其寒温，损其肝者缓其中，损其肾者益其精，即此便是正法眼藏。使八十一难，俱仿此言治，何患后人无具耶？　　原气虚与虚损不同，原气虚可复，虚损难复也。至虚损病亦有易复难复两候：因病致虚者，缓调自复；因虚致损者，虚上加虚，卒难复也。[114p]

The people of Qin and Yue invented a theory of deficiency and damage, granted access to the sacred domain. Although there are no specific texts to consult, their methods for treating deficiencies involve: for lung deficiency, enhancing qi; for heart deficiency, regulating the flow of nourishment and defense; for spleen deficiency, adjusting diet according to cold and heat; for liver deficiency, alleviating internal issues; and for kidney deficiency, enriching essence. This is indeed the essence of the rightful teachings. If the eighty-one difficulties are all treated in this manner, what concern is there that future generations will lack resources?

The original qi deficiency differs from damage due to deficiency; original qi deficiency can be restored, while damage is difficult to recover from. There are also two types of deficiency diseases: those caused by illness leading to deficiency can recover with gentle adjustments, whereas those where deficiency leads to damage result in compounding deficiencies, making recovery extremely difficult.[114p]

故因病致虚，东垣、丹溪法在所必用；若虚上加虚，而至于损，原气索然，丹溪每用人参膏至十余斤，多有得生者，其见似出东垣之右。然则丹溪补阴之论，不过救世人偏于补阳之弊耳，岂遇阳虚之病而不捷于转环耶？　　饮食劳倦，为内伤元气，真阳下陷，内生虚热，束垣发补中益气之论，用人参、黄芪等甘温之药，大补其气而提其下陷，此用气药以补气之不足也。若劳心好色，内伤真阴，阴血既伤，则阳气偏盛而变为火矣，是谓阴虚火旺劳瘵之证。故丹溪发阳有余阴不足之论，用四物加知母、黄蘗补其阴而火自降，此用血药以补血之不足也。[115p]

Therefore, when illness leads to deficiency, the methods of Dongyuan and Danxi are essential; if deficiency accumulates further, it will result in damage, and the original qi will be profoundly depleted. Danxi often uses ginseng paste up to ten or more pounds, with many recovering, which seems to align closely with Dongyuan’s approach. Thus, Danxi's theory of nourishing yin is merely addressing the tendency of saving people to be overly focused on nourishing yang; how could one encounter yang deficiency and not find relief through rotation (of treatments)?

Diet and overexertion are the causes of internal injury to original qi, resulting in true yang descending and the internal generation of vacuous heat. The theory of Shuyang enhancing middle qi recommends the use of herbs like ginseng and astragalus, which are sweet and warm, to greatly replenish qi and elevate what has fallen—this is the use of qi tonics to replenish what is deficient in qi. On the other hand, if one exhausts their mind with passions, injuring true yin, the yin blood will be harmed, leading to an excess of yang qi that transforms into fire; this is termed the syndrome of yin deficiency and excess fire, which manifests as chronic fatigue or consumption.

Hence, Danxi’s theory on excess yang and insufficient yin proposes using Siwu Decoction, supplemented with Zhimu and Huangbai, to replenish yin, thereby reducing fire; this is the application of blood tonics to replenish what is deficient in blood.[115p]

益气补阴，一则因阳气之下陷而补其气以升提之，一则因阳火之上升而滋其阴以降下之。一升一降，迥然不同，亦医学之两大法门，不可不究悉之也。　　丹溪论劳瘵主乎阴虚者，盖自子至巳属阳，自午至亥属阴，阴虚则热在午后子前；寤属阳，寐属阴，阴虚则汗从寐时盗出也；升属阳，降属阴，阴虚则气不降，气不降则痰涎上逆而连绵不绝也；脉浮属阳，沉属阴，阴虚则浮之洪大，沉之空虚也。此皆阴虚之证，用四物汤加黄蘗、知母主之。然用之多不效，何哉？盖阴既虚矣，火必上炎，而当归、川芎，皆气辛味大温，非滋阴降火之药。又川芎上窜，尤非虚炎短乏者所宜；地黄泥膈，非胃热食少痰多者所宜。黄蘗、知母苦辛大寒，虽曰滋阴，其实燥而损血；虽曰降火，其实苦先入心，久而增气，反能助火，至其败胃，所不待言。[116p]

To benefit qi and nourish yin, one method addresses the descent of yang qi to replenish it for elevation, while the other deals with the ascent of yang fire to nourish yin for descent. The elevation and descent are distinctly different, representing two major approaches in medicine that must be thoroughly understood.

Danxi discusses that labor and consumption are primarily due to yin deficiency. From the Zi (Rat) to Si (Snake) hours is yang, and from Wu (Horse) to Hai (Pig) is yin. When yin is deficient, heat appears from late morning to early night; wakefulness is yang and sleep is yin, leading to sweating that happens at night due to yin deficiency; elevation is yang and descent is yin, so if yin is deficient, the qi does not descend, causing phlegm and fluids to rise endlessly; a floating pulse is yang and a deep pulse is yin, with yin deficiency leading to a floating pulse that is large and a deep pulse that is empty. These are all signs of yin deficiency, treated with the Si Wu Decoction, augmented with Huangbo and Zhimu.

However, frequent use is ineffective; why is that? It is because the yin is already deficient, causing the fire to flare up.
