Angelica and Chuanxiong both have warming properties and are not suitable for nourishing yin and descending fire. Moreover, Chuanxiong's upward movement is particularly inappropriate for those suffering from a deficiency of fire. Rehmannia mud obstructs the diaphragm and is unsuitable for those with stomach heat and excessive phlegm. Huangbo and Zhimu, though described as nourishing yin, actually have a drying effect and harm blood; even though they claim to descend fire, their bitterness first enters the heart, which over time increases qi, thereby potentially supporting fire until it damages the stomach, which goes without saying.[116p]

不若用薏苡仁、百合、天冬、麦冬、桑白皮、地骨皮、牡丹皮、枇杷叶、五味子、酸枣仁之属，佐以生地黄汁、藕汁、人乳汁、童便等。如咳嗽则多用桑白皮、枇杷叶；有痰则增贝母；有血则多用薏苡仁、百合，增阿胶；热盛则多用地骨皮；食少则用薏苡仁至七八钱。而麦冬常为之主，以保肺金而滋生化之源，往往应手而效。盖诸药皆禀燥降收之气，气之薄者为阳中之阴，气薄则发泄，辛甘淡平寒凉是也。[117p]

It is better to use ingredients such as coix seed, lily, tian dong (asparagus), mai dong (ophiopogon), mulberry bark, earth bone peel, peony root, loquat leaves, schisandra, and sour jujube seed, along with fresh juice of rehmannia, lotus root, human milk, and children's urine. If there is a cough, emphasize mulberry bark and loquat leaves; if there is phlegm, increase fritillaria; if there is blood, use more coix seed and lily, and increase ejiao (donkey-hide gelatin); if there is a strong heat, use more earth bone peel; if there is little food intake, use coix seed up to seven or eight qian. Mai dong is often the main ingredient, as it preserves the lung's essence and nourishes the source of transformation, often yielding quick results. All these medicines possess a drying, descending, and astringent nature; those with a lighter energy are the yin within the yang, where light energy leads to release. The flavors are pungent, sweet, bland, neutral, and cool.[117p]

以施于阴虚火动之证，犹当溽暑伊郁之时，而商飙一动，炎歊如失矣。与治暑热用白虎汤同意。然彼是外感，外感为有余，故用寒沉藏之药，而后能补其偏。此是内伤，内伤为不足，但用燥降收之剂，而已得其平矣。此用药之权舆也。　　虚劳之疾，百脉空虚，非粘腻之物填之，不能实也。精血枯涸，非滋湿之物濡之，不能润也。宜用人参、黄芪、地黄、二冬、枸杞、五味之属，各煎膏；另用青蒿以童便熬膏，及生地汁、白莲藕汁、乳汁、薄荷汁，隔汤炼过，酌定多少，并麋角胶、霞天膏合和成剂，每用一匙，汤化服之。[118p]

For treating the symptoms of yin deficiency and active fire, one should administer remedies especially during the oppressive heat of summer. When a sudden cold wind arises, it feels as if heat has been lost. This is similar to using Bai Hu Decoction for dealing with summer heat. However, that situation involves external pathogen invasion, which is considered excess, thus requiring cooling and suppressive medicine to balance it. In contrast, this condition stems from internal injury, characterized by deficiency, and can be addressed by using drying and descending agents to achieve equilibrium.

For the affliction of deficiency and exhaustion, where the hundred channels are vacuous, it cannot be remedied by filling them with thick and greasy substances. When essence and blood are depleted, they cannot be nourished without moistening agents. One should use ingredients such as Ren Shen (ginseng), Huang Qi (astragalus), Di Huang (rehmannia), the two Dong (winter herbs), Gou Qi (goji berries), and Wu Wei Zi (five-flavor fruit), each prepared as a thick decoction. Additionally, Qing Hao (sweet wormwood) can be boiled with child urine to make a concentrate, along with fresh juices from Di Huang (rehmannia), white lotus root, milk, and mint, processed separately and combined in appropriate amounts with antler glue and gossamer cream to form a cohesive remedy. Each time, one spoonful is to be dissolved in soup and taken.[118p]

如欲行瘀血，加入酢制大黄末、元明粉、桃仁泥、韭汁之属；欲止血，加入京墨之属；欲行痰，加入竹沥之属；欲降火，加入童便之属。　　凡虚劳之证，大抵心下引胁俱疼，盖滞血不消，新血无以养之，尤宜用膏子加韭汁、桃仁泥。　　呼吸少气，懒言语，无力动作，目无精光，面色晄白，皆兼气虚，用麦冬、人参各三钱，陈皮、桔梗、炙甘草各半两，五味子二十一粒为极细末，水浸蒸饼为丸如鸡头子大，每服一丸，细嚼津唾咽下，名补气丸。　　气虚则生脉散，不言白朮；血虚则三才丸，不言四物。前言薏苡仁之属治肺虚，后言参芪地黄膏子之类治肾虚。盖肝心属阳，肺肾属阴，阴虚则肺肾虚矣，故补肺肾即是补阴，非四物、黄蘗、知母之谓也。　　劳瘵兼痰积，其证腹胁常热，头面手足则于寅卯时分乍有凉时，宜以霞天膏入竹沥，加少姜汁，调元明粉行之。[119p]

If you wish to move stagnant blood, add powdered rhubarb, Yuanming powder, peach kernel paste, and leek juice. To stop bleeding, add ingredients related to Jing ink. To resolve phlegm, add bamboo juice. To reduce fire, add childhood urine.

In general, the signs of deficiency and labor involve pain in the chest and ribs, due to stagnant blood not being dispelled and new blood unable to nourish it. It is especially suitable to use an ointment with leek juice and peach kernel paste.

Symptoms of shortness of breath, reluctance to speak, weak actions, lack of spirit in the eyes, and a pale complexion, all indicate qi deficiency. Use three taels each of Ophiopogon and ginseng, half a tael each of dried tangerine peel, balloon flower, and fried licorice, and twenty-one grains of schisandra ground into a very fine powder, mixed with water to form pills the size of a chick's head. Take one pill each time, chew it well with saliva before swallowing; this is called the Qi Tonifying Pill.

For qi deficiency, use the Shengmai Powder, excluding Bai Zhu; for blood deficiency, use the San Cai Pill, excluding Si Wu. The previously mentioned coix seed treats lung deficiency, while the later mentioned ginseng, astragalus, and Rehmannia ointment treat kidney deficiency. The liver and heart belong to yang, while the lungs and kidneys belong to yin; if yin is deficient, then the lungs and kidneys are also deficient. Therefore, nourishing the lungs and kidneys is synonymous with nourishing yin, which should not be confused with the Four Substances or ingredients like Huanglian and Zhimu.

In cases of consumption complicated with phlegm accumulation, characterized by constant heat in the abdomen and ribs, and occasional coolness in the head, face, hands, and feet during the yin and yang hours, it is advisable to use Xiatiang Ointment with bamboo juice, adding a bit of ginger juice and mixing in Yuanming powder to promote its effects.[119p]

若顽痰在膈上，胶固难治者，必以吐法吐之，或沉香滚痰丸、透膈丹之类下之，甚则用倒仓法。若肝有积痰瘀血结热而劳瘵者，其太冲脉必与冲阳脉不相应，宜以补阴药吞当归龙荟丸。　　古方柴胡饮子、防风当归饮子、麦煎散，皆用大黄，盖能折炎上之势，而引之下行，莫速乎此。然惟大便实者乃可。若溏泄则虽地黄之属，亦不宜，况大黄乎？　　病劳有一种真脏虚损，复受邪热者，如经验方中治劳热青蒿煎丸用柴胡正合宜耳。热去即须急已，若无邪热，不死何待？又大忌芩、连、蘗，骤用纯苦寒药，反泻其阳。但当用琼玉膏之类，大助阳气，使其复还寅卯之位，微加泻阴火之药是也。　　有重阴复其阳，火不得伸，或洒洒恶寒，或志意不乐，或脉弦数，四肢五心烦热者，火郁汤柴胡升麻汤。病去即已，不可过剂。　　服寒凉药，证虽大减，脉反加数者，阳郁也，宜升宜补。大忌寒凉，犯之必死。[120p]

If stubborn phlegm is lodged in the diaphragm and is difficult to treat, it must be expelled using the vomiting method, or by administering pills like Shenxiang Guantan Wan or Toge Dan, and in severe cases, employing the倒仓 method. If the liver has accumulated phlegm and stagnant blood causing heat and fatigue, the Taichong pulse will surely be out of sync with the Chongyang pulse. Gui-yin herbs should be taken along with Danggui Longhui Wan.

Classic formulas such as Chaihu Yinzi, Fangfeng Danggui Yinzi, and Mai Jiansan all use Dahuang, which can reduce the inflamed condition and facilitate downward movement, achieving swift results. However, this is only applicable if the stool is firm. If there is diarrhea, even with herbs like Dihuang, it is inadvisable, let alone Dahuang.

There is a type of illness where the true internal organs are weakened and additionally affected by pathogenic heat. In such cases, formulas like Qinghao Jianwan with Chaihu are quite suitable. Once the heat is removed, urgent attention must be given; if there is no pathogenic heat, what need is there for treatment? Additionally, it is critical to avoid Qinko, Lian, and Puhuang, as abrupt use of purely bitter and cold herbs would further weaken yang. Instead, one should use classes like Qiongyu Gao to bolster yang energy and restore it to its rightful position while slightly adding herbs to drain yin fire.

In cases where heavy yin is restored and yang cannot extend, accompanied by chills, discontent, or a rapid wiry pulse with four limbs and five hearts feeling hot, one should use Huoyujing Tang or Chaihu Shengma Tang. The illness should cease promptly; one must not exceed the dosage.

When taking cold and cooling herbs, if symptoms have significantly decreased but the pulse has become more rapid, this indicates the repression of yang, thus it is necessary to help it rise and be replenished. Cold and cool substances are to be rigorously avoided, as transgressing them could lead to death.[120p]

　　治法当以脾肾二脏为要，肾乃系元气者也，脾乃养形体者也。经曰：形不足者，温之以气。气谓真气，有少火之温，以生育形体。然此火不可使之热，热则壮，壮则反耗真气也。候其火之少壮，皆在两肾间。经又曰：精不足者，补之以味。五味入胃，各从所喜之脏而归之，以生津液，输纳于肾者。若五味一有过节，反成其脏有余，胜克之祸起矣。候其五味之寒热，初在脾胃，次在其所归之脏，即当补其不足，泻其有余，谨守精气，谓其阴阳。夫是故天枢开发而胃和脉生矣。　　劳疾久而嗽血，咽疼无声，此为下传上。若不嗽不疼，久而溺浊脱精，此为上传下，皆死证也。　　夫传尸劳者，男子自肾传心、心而肺、肺而肝、肝而脾，女子自心传肺、肺而肝、肝而脾、脾而肾，五脏复传六腑而死矣。虽有诸候，其实不离乎心阳肾阴也，若明阴阳用药，可以起死回生。　　苏游论曰：传尸之候，先从肾起。[121p]

The treatment should focus on the spleen and kidneys, as the kidneys are the source of vital energy and the spleen nourishes the body. The classics say: "When the body is deficient, it should be warmed by vital energy." This vital energy refers to the true qi, which has a mild warmth that nourishes the body. However, this warmth should not be allowed to become excessive; if it becomes too hot, it can strengthen the body but ultimately deplete the true qi. The excess warmth is found between the two kidneys. The classics further state: "When essence is deficient, it should be replenished by flavors." The five flavors enter the stomach, each returning to their preferred organ to generate bodily fluids, which are then transported to the kidneys. If any flavor is taken in excess, it may lead to an excess in the organs, resulting in disharmony. The balance of the five flavors, initially affects the spleen and stomach, and then the organs they correspond to. One should replenish what is lacking and drain what is in excess, carefully maintaining the essence and energy, referring to yin and yang. Thus, when the heavenly pivot is opened, it leads to a harmonious stomach and the generation of veins.

In cases of long-term labor disease causing coughing blood and throat pain without sound, this indicates a transmission from below to above. If there is no cough or pain, but instead turbid urination and loss of essence over time, this indicates a transmission from above to below, both of which are signs of mortality.

The signs of transmitted illness for men begin with the kidneys, affecting the heart, then the lungs, then the liver, and finally the spleen. For women, it starts from the heart, affecting the lungs, then the liver, then the spleen, and then the kidneys. The five organs can also affect the six bowels, leading to death. Although various signs may appear, they ultimately do not stray from the yang of the heart and the yin of the kidneys. If one understands how to use medicine based on the principles of yin and yang, it can bring the dead back to life.

Su You Lun states: The signs of transmitted illness primarily originate from the kidneys.[121p]

初受之，两胫酸疼，腰背拘急，行立脚弱，饮食减少，两耳飕飕直似风声，夜卧遗泄，阴汗痿弱。肾既受讫，次传于心。心初受气，夜卧心惊，或多恐怖，心悬悬，气吸吸欲尽，梦见先亡，有时盗汗，饮食无味，口内生疮，心气烦热，惟欲眠卧，朝轻夕重，两颊口唇，悉皆纹赤，如傅胭脂，有时手足五心烦热。心既受巳，次传于肺。肺初受气，咳嗽上气喘，卧益甚，鼻口干燥，不闻香臭，如或忽闻，惟觉朽腐气，有时恶心欲吐，肌肤枯燥，时或疼痛，或似虫行，干皮细起，状如麸片。肺既受已，次传于肝。肝初受气，两目(目巟)(目巟)，面无血色，常欲颦眉，视不能远，目常干濇，又时赤痛，或复睛黄，常欲合眼，及时睡卧不着。肝既受已，次传于脾。脾初受气，两胁虚胀，食不消化，又时泻利，水谷生虫，有时肚痛，腹胀雷鸣，唇口焦干，或生疮肿，毛发干耸，无有光润，或时上气，撑肩喘息，利赤黑汁，见此证者，乃不治也。[122p]

Upon first receiving it, the legs feel sore and painful, the waist and back are stiff, it’s weak to stand or walk, appetite decreases, and the ears whistle as if they hear the wind. At night, there are involuntary leaks, and there is a weakness with dampness. Once the kidneys are affected, the impact next reaches the heart. When the heart first receives the ailment, there are nighttime fears, or excessive terror; the heart feels anxious, breath shortens and seems close to exhaustion, dreams of the dead arise, sometimes accompanied by night sweats, tastelessness in food, mouth sores, a feeling of heat in the heart, a desire only to sleep, feeling light in the morning and heavy in the evening. The cheeks and lips are all marked red, like wearing rouge, and at times, the hands and feet feel hot and restless. Once the heart is affected, it then transfers to the lungs. When the lungs are first affected, there is coughing and wheezing, worsening at night, dryness in the nose and mouth, not able to smell anything—only detecting a foul odor, sometimes nausea and a desire to vomit, skin becoming dry, occasionally feeling pain, resembling insects crawling, with the skin wrinkled and dry like flaky dough. Once the lungs are affected, it then transmits to the liver. Initially, the liver shows symptoms with the eyes appearing hollow, the face lacking color, often frowning, unable to see far, the eyes always dry, sometimes red and painful, or the whites turning yellow, with a constant desire to close the eyes and difficulty sleeping. Once the liver is affected, it then moves to the spleen. Initially, the spleen shows weakness in the sides, poor digestion of food, sometimes leading to diarrhea, with water and grain producing worms, and sometimes belly pain, swelling, and rumbling in the abdomen, dry and scorched lips, or sores and swelling, hair becoming dry and lackluster, and sometimes feeling short of breath, shoulders feeling heavy and labored; if these symptoms appear, then it is regarded as untreatable.[122p]

　　　　　论方

　　按天雄散，一方用桂枝汤调其荣卫羁迟；脉道虚衰，加龙骨牡蛎，濇止其清谷，亡血失精。一方而两扼其要，诚足宝也。《小品》又云：虚羸浮热汗出者，除桂加白薇、附子各三分，故曰二加龙骨汤，得此一加减法，后之用是方者，更思过半矣。可见桂枝虽调荣卫所首重，倘其人虚阳浮越于外，即当加附子、白薇，以回阳而助其收濇，桂枝又在所不取也。后一方以上中二焦之阳虚，须用天雄以补其上，白朮以固其中，用桂枝领药，行荣卫上焦，并建回阳之功。方下虽未述证，其治法指掌易见，然则去桂枝加白薇、附子，得非仿此以治中下二焦之阳虚欲脱耶？精矣！　　按虚劳病而至于亡血失精，消耗精液，枯槁四出，难为力矣。[123p]

On Formulas

According to the Tianxiong Powder, one formula uses Guizhi Decoction to regulate the nutritive and defensive qi; when the pulse is weak and deficient, add Longgu and Muli to stop the clear fluids, causing loss of blood and essence. With one formula addressing both essential points, it is indeed valuable. The "Xiaopin" also states: for those with deficiency, emaciation, floating heat, and sweating, remove Guizhi and add Bawei and Fuzhu, each three fen, hence it is called the Erjia Longgu Decoction. Understanding this method of addition and subtraction is already a significant step for future practitioners of this formula.

It can be seen that while Guizhi primarily regulates the nutritive and defensive qi, if a person has floating yang deficiency, one should indeed add Fuzhu and Bawei to restore the yang and assist in retaining the clear fluids, making Guizhi no longer necessary. The latter formula, focusing on the yang deficiency in the upper and middle jiao, must use Tianxiong to replenish the upper part, and Baizhu to secure the middle, employing Guizhi to lead the herbs, facilitating the nutritive and defensive qi in the upper jiao while also having the function of restoring yang. Although the lower section does not mention evidence, its treatment method is easy to discern. Therefore, removing Guizhi and adding Bawei and Fuzhu can indeed be seen as a treatment for the yang deficiency in the middle and lower jiao to prevent collapse. This is indeed refined!

It should be noted that with deficiency and labor, to the point of losing blood and essence, consuming essence and fluids, leading to extreme emaciation and exhaustion, it is difficult to find strength.[123p]

《内经》于针药所莫治者调以甘药，《金匮》遵之而用小建中汤、黄芪建中汤，急建其中气，俾饮食增而津液旺，以至充血生精而复其真阴之不足，但取稼穑作甘之本味，而酸辛咸苦，在所不用，盖舍此别无良法也。然用法者，贵立于无过之地，宁但呕苦，不可用建中之甘。即服甘药，微觉气阻气滞，更当虑甘药太过，令人中满，早用橘皮、砂仁以行之可也。[124p]

In the "Inner Canon," it is stated that when there is no remedy for acupuncture and medicine, one should adjust with sweet herbs. The "Golden Chamber" follows this principle and uses Xiao Jianzhong Decoction and Huangqi Jianzhong Decoction to urgently bolster the vital energy of Jianzhong, allowing for an increase in food intake and vitality of bodily fluids, ultimately replenishing blood and essence to restore insufficient true yin. One should focus on the sweet essence derived from grain and avoid sour, pungent, salty, and bitter tastes, as there are no other effective methods. Moreover, when applying this method, it is crucial to avoid excess; it is better to induce some bitterness than to use the sweet in Jianzhong. If sweet herbs are consumed and there is a slight sensation of obstruction or stagnation, it is necessary to consider whether the sweetness has been overused, as it can cause fullness. Early use of tangerine peel or cardamom can help to move things along.[124p]

不然，甘药又不可恃，更将何所恃哉？后人多用乐令建中汤、十四味建中汤，虽无过甘之弊，然乐令方中，前胡、细辛为君，意在退热，而阴虚之热则不可退；十四味方中，用附、桂、苁蓉，意在复阳，而阴虚之阳未必可复，又在用方者之善为裁酌矣。　　《金匮》之用八味肾气丸，屡发于前矣。消渴之关门大开，水病之关门不开，用此方蒸动肾气，则关门有开有阖，如晨门者，与阳俱开，与阴俱阖，环城内外赖以安堵也。其治脚气上入少腹不仁，则借以培真阴真阳根本之地，而令浊阴潜消，不得上干清阳耳。今虚劳病，桂、附本在所不用，而腰痛、少腹拘急、小便不利三证，皆由肾中真阳内微所致，其病较阴虚发热诸证，迥乎不同，又不可不求其有而反责其无矣。[125p]

Otherwise, one cannot rely on sweet medicines; what else can one rely on? Later generations often use the prescriptions of "Lejing" Jianzhong Decoction and Shisiwei Jianzhong Decoction. Although they do not have the drawbacks of excessive sweetness, in the Lejing formula, Shenghu and Xixin are the chief ingredients, intended to dispel heat; however, the heat from yin deficiency cannot be dispelled. In the Shisiwei formula, using Fuzi, Guizhi, and Congrong aims to restore yang, yet the yang of yin deficiency may not necessarily be restored; it also depends on the skill of the practitioner in adjusting the formula.

The use of Bamei Shenqi Pill in the "Jinkui" has been mentioned repeatedly before. In cases of diabetes where the doors are wide open, and in water conditions where the doors are closed, using this formula stimulates kidney energy, thus the doors can open and close. Just like the morning doors, they open with yang and close with yin, relying on the surrounding areas for stability. For treating foot edema that ascends to the lower abdomen causing numbness, it is used to nourish the true yin and true yang at their root, allowing the turbid yin to gradually disperse without impacting the clear yang.

In current cases of deficiency labor, Guizhi and Fuzi are not utilized, but the symptoms of lower back pain, abdominal tightness, and difficulty in urination all stem from the subtle presence of true yang in the kidneys. These conditions are distinctly different from the symptoms of yin deficiency heat, and one cannot ignore these underlying factors while blaming the absence of treatment.[125p]

　　按虚劳不足之病，最易生风生气。倘风气不除，外证日见有余，中脏日见虚耗，神头鬼脸，不可方物，有速毙而已。故用薯蓣丸方，除去其风气，兼培补其空虚也。　　按《素问》云：阳气者烦劳则张，精绝僻积于夏，使人煎厥，已详论卷首问答条矣。可见虚劳虚烦为心肾不交之病，肾水不上交心火，心火无制，故烦而不得眠，不独夏月为然矣。方用酸枣仁汤，以枣仁为君，而兼知母之滋肾为佐，茯苓、甘草调和其间，芎藭入血分而解心火之躁烦也。　　按七伤，《金匮》明谓食伤、忧伤、饮食伤、房室伤、饥伤、劳伤、经络荣卫气伤及房劳伤，但居其一。后人不知何见，谓七伤者，阴寒、阴痿、里急精速、精少、阴下湿、精滑、小便苦数临事不举，似乎颛主肾伤为言。岂有五劳分主五脏，而七伤独主一脏之理？虽人生恣逞，伤肾者恒多，要不可为一定之名也。[126p]

The disorder of deficiency and fatigue is most susceptible to the invasion of wind and qi. If the wind and qi are not eliminated, external symptoms will increase over time, while internal organs gradually suffer from depletion. This can lead to symptoms that are uncontrollable, with a risk of rapid demise. Therefore, we use the Dioscorea Pill to eliminate the wind and simultaneously nourish the deficiency.

According to the "Plain Questions," it states that the yang qi becomes agitated with fatigue. During summer, the essence can become depleted and lead to a state of distress. This has been extensively discussed in the introductory questions and answers. It is evident that deficiency and fatigue stem from the lack of interaction between the heart and kidneys—where kidney water fails to ascend and interact with heart fire, leading to unease and insomnia, not solely in summer.

The prescription of Sour Jujube Seed Decoction is recommended, with the jujube seed as the chief ingredient, complemented by the Restorative Root to nourish the kidneys. Poria and licorice are used to harmonize, while Chuanxiong enters the blood to alleviate the restlessness caused by heart fire.

Regarding the seven injuries, the "Golden Cabinet" clearly states these are related to food, worry, diet, sexual relations, starvation, overexertion, and damage to the meridians and defensive qi from sexual overindulgence. However, there are claims suggesting that the seven injuries refer to issues like coldness, impotence, abdominal urgency, reduced essence, dampness below, and difficulty with urination—notions implying kidney injuries.

Is it reasonable that the Five Labors pertain to the five viscera, while the Seven Injuries pertain solely to one organ? Even though individuals may indulge, injuries to the kidneys are persistently common, thus they cannot be ascribed a fixed categorization.[126p]

所以虚劳证凡本之内伤者，有此七者之分，故虚劳发热未有不由瘀血者，而瘀血若无内伤则荣卫运行，不失其次，瘀从何起？是必饮食起居，过时失节，荣卫凝泣，先成内伤，然后随其气所阻塞之处，血为瘀积。瘀积之久，牢不可拔，新生之血，不得周灌，与日俱积，其人尚有生理乎？仲景施活人手眼，以大黄(上庶下虫)虫丸之润剂，润其血之干，以蠕动啖血之物，行死血，名之曰绥中补虚，岂非以行血去瘀，为安中补虚上着耶？然此特世俗所称干血劳之良治也。[127p]

Therefore, for those suffering from deficiency syndrome due to internal injuries, there are these seven distinctions. Hence, deficiency fever has never been without stasis of blood. If there is no internal injury, the nourishing and guarding energies flow without obstruction, so where does the stasis originate? It must be due to irregularities in diet and daily activities; when the nourishing and guarding energies stagnate and accumulate, internal injuries occur. Then, the blood gets blocked in the areas of obstruction and becomes stagnant. If this stasis persists for long, it becomes deeply entrenched, and newly produced blood cannot circulate freely, accumulating with each passing day. Can such a person still maintain their life force? Zhang Zhongjing applied a remedy known as "Reviving Human Hand and Eye," using da huang (rhubarb), insect pills, and lubricants to moisten the dry blood, promoting movement to dispel the stagnant blood. This treatment was named "Soothing the Center and Nourishing Deficiency." Is it not aimed at moving the blood to remove stasis, thereby calming the interior and replenishing deficiency? Indeed, this is regarded in our society as an excellent treatment for dry blood deficiency.[127p]

血结在内，手足脉相失者宜之，兼入琼玉膏润补之药同用尤妙。昌细参其证，肌肤甲错，面目黯黑，及羸瘦不能饮食，全是营血瘀积胃中，而发见于肌肤面目，所以五脏失中土之灌溉而虚极也。此与五神脏之本病不同，故可用其方，而导去其胃中之血，以内谷而流通荣卫耳。许州陈大夫传仲景百劳丸方云：治一切劳瘵积滞，不经药坏证者，宜服。与世俗所称干血劳，亦何以异？大夫其长于谋国欤？方用当归、乳香、没药各一钱，人参二钱，大黄四钱，蝱虫、水蛭、桃仁各十四个，浸去皮尖。[128p]

When blood coagulates internally and the pulse in the hands and feet is lost, this is the appropriate treatment. Additionally, using a medicinal ointment like Qiong Yu Gao for nourishment and replenishment is particularly effective. Examining the symptoms closely, one may find the skin and flesh disordered, the complexion darkening, accompanied by emaciation that leads to inability to eat or drink. This condition arises from the accumulation of stagnant blood in the stomach, manifesting on the skin and face, indicating a severe deficiency of the Earth's nourishment in the Five Organs. This differs from the fundamental illnesses of the Five Yin Organs, hence the prescribed method can be applied, guiding the removal of blood from the stomach to promote the flow of nourishment (Rong) and defense (Wei). Dr. Chen from Xuzhou transmitted the formula of Bai Lao Pill from Zhongjing, stating it treats all forms of consumption and stagnation due to overexertion, appropriate for those whose symptoms do not improve with medicinal intervention. Is it not akin to what is commonly referred to as Dry Blood Consumption? The doctor is perhaps adept at state affairs? The prescription includes: Dang Gui, frankincense, and myrrh, each one qian; ginseng two qian; rhubarb four qian; and fourteen pieces each of silkworms, leeches, and peach kernels, soaked and stripped of their peel.[128p]

右为细末，炼蜜为丸桐子大，都作一服可百丸，五更用百劳水下，取恶物为度。服白粥十日。百劳水，即仲景甘澜水，以杓扬百遍者也。　　按复脉汤，仲景治伤寒脉代结心动悸邪少虚多之圣方也。《金匮》不载，以《千金翼》常用此方治虚劳，则实可征信，是以得名为千金之方也。虚劳之体，多有表热夹其阴虚，所以其证汗出而闷，表之固非，即治其阴虚亦非，惟用此方得汗而脉出热解，俾其人快然，真圣法也。但虚劳之人，胃中津液素虚，匪伤寒暴病邪多虚少之比。桂枝、生姜分两之多，服之津液每随热势外越，津液既外越，难以复收，多有淋漓沾濡一昼夜者。[129p]

The above is a fine powder, refined into pills the size of sweet gum seeds. This makes up one dose of a hundred pills. In the early morning, take a hundred labor water to eliminate bad substances. Consume white porridge for ten days. The hundred labor water is, in fact, the sweet water of Zhongjing's Ganlan, stirred a hundred times with a scoop.

According to "Fu Mai Tang," Zhongjing treats the pulse disturbance from exogenous cold leading to heart palpitations, a formula of great sanctity. It is not recorded in the "Jin Gui," yet often used in "Qian Jin Yi" to treat deficiencies due to labor. This explains why it is named the formula of a thousand pieces of gold.

In cases of deficiency due to illness, there is frequently an external heat combined with internal yin deficiency, resulting in symptoms of sweating and oppression. If one merely treats the exterior without addressing the yin deficiency, true healing cannot be achieved. Only by using this formula can one induce sweating while releasing heat from the pulse, bringing comfort to the patient, which is a true method of sanctity.

However, those with deficiency often have depleted gastric fluids, unlike the violent heat of a severe cold. The use of cinnamon and ginger in significant amounts can lead to excessive heat, causing the fluids to dissipate externally. Once the fluids are lost, they are hard to regain, often leading to continued dripping and dampness for a full day and night.[129p]

透此一关，亟以本方去桂枝生姜二味，三倍加入人参，随继其后，庶几津液复生，乃致荣卫盛而诸虚尽复，岂小补哉！　　按许叔微《本事方》云：葛稚川言鬼疰者，是五尸之一。疰诸鬼邪为害，其变动不一，大约使人淋漓，沉沉默默，的不知其所苦，而无处不恶，累年积月，渐就顿滞，以致于死，传于旁人，乃至灭门。觉知是证者，急治獭肝一具，阴干取末，水服方寸匕，日三服效，未知再服。此方神良。[130p]

By passing this threshold, one should promptly remove the gui zhi (cinnamon twig) and sheng jiang (fresh ginger) from the original ingredients and triple the amount of ren shen (ginseng) instead. Follow this up, and it is hoped that bodily fluids will be restored, leading to a flourishing protective vitality and the exhaustion of any deficiencies—not a minor remedy! According to Xu Shuwei in "Ben Shi Fang," Ge Zhi Chuan states that "gui zhu" refers to one of the five corpses. The harm caused by the evil spirits manifests in various ways; it generally leaves a person languid and silent, unaware of their suffering, with malevolence present everywhere. After accumulating for years, it can gradually lead to stagnation and ultimately death, often affecting those around them to the point of extinction of their family. If one realizes this is the case, they should urgently treat with a single otter liver, dry it in the shade to a powder, and take a small spoonful with water three times a day for effect, though how often it should be taken afterward is unclear. This remedy is indeed remarkable.[130p]

再按长桑君所授越人禁方，各传其徒一人者，至华元化毙狱，其传遂泯。仲景医中之圣，诸禁方讵不尽窥底蕴。然而有其理无其事者，不足尚也。有其事无其理者，不足尚也。即有其理、有其事矣，而用意罕几先之哲，尤不足尚也。如獭肝散非不可以杀虫，而未可以行血逐瘀，所以制缓中补虚大黄(上庶下虫)虫丸一方，自出手眼，而授陈大夫，百劳丸一方加入人参，只作一服，以取顿快，盖于此时而用力，可图十全其五也。迨至束手无策，而取用獭肝以去其虫，虫去其人可独存乎？然虫亦不可不去也。
《金匮》之附《肘后》一方，岂无意哉！　　按东垣所谓饮食劳倦，内伤元气，则胃脘之阳不能升举，并心肺之气，陷入于中焦，而用补中益气治之，方中佐以柴胡、升麻二味，一从左旋，一从右旋，旋转于胃之左右，升举其上焦所陷之气，非自腹中而升举之也。其清气下入腹中久为飧泄，并可多用升柴，从腹中而升举之矣。[131p]

According to the forbidden prescriptions taught by Master Chang Sang, when each disciple passes it on to one person, it eventually becomes lost upon reaching Hua Yuan, who died in prison, leading to its disappearance. Zhongjing, the saint among doctors, must have grasped the essence of all forbidden prescriptions. Yet, those who have the theory without the practical application are not worthy of respect. Likewise, those with practical results but lacking the underlying theory are also not worthy of respect. Even if there exists both theory and practice, if few wise men have taken heed of it, it is still not worthy of esteem. For instance, while the liver of the otter can eliminate parasites, it cannot promote blood flow to dispel stagnation. Hence, with the aim of nourishing the deficiency, the recipe for Dahuang (rhubarb) pills for reducing parasites was created, originally crafted and handed to Doctor Chen, while the Hundred Labors Pill, incorporating ginseng, is designed for immediate effect. This method, when well applied, could potentially yield substantial results. However, when one is at a loss and resorts to using otter liver to eliminate the parasites, can one really survive merely by removing the parasites? Yet, it is also true that the parasites must be eradicated.

Is there not intention behind the prescriptions found in the "Jinkui" along with those in the "Zhouhou"? According to Dongyuan's principle regarding diet and exhaustive labor, injury to vital energy causes the yang of the stomach to be unable to rise, leading to the heart and lungs’ energy to fall into the middle jiao. Therefore, it is treated by tonifying the middle and augmenting qi, supplemented with Chaihu (bupleurum) and Shengma (cimicifuga), which rotate in opposite directions around the stomach to elevate the falling energy of the upper jiao; this is not accomplished by merely raising it from the abdomen. If the clear energy sinks into the abdomen for a long time leading to diarrhea, using Sheng and Chai in abundance can effectively elevate from the abdomen.[131p]

若阳气未必陷下，反升举其阴气，干犯阳位，为变岂小哉？更有阴气素惯上干清阳，而胸中之肉隆耸为(月真)，胸间之气漫散为胀者，而误施此法，天翻地覆，九道皆塞，有濒于死而坐困耳。后人相传谓此方能升清降浊，有识者亦咸信之，医事尚可言哉！夫补其中气，以听中气之自为升降，不用升柴可也，用之亦可也。若以升清之药责其降浊之能，岂不痴乎？　　按虚劳之证，阴虚者十常八九，阳虚者十之一二而已。丹溪着阳有余阴不足之论，而定大补阴丸，四物加黄蘗知母汤二方，与东垣补中益气之法，旗鼓相当。气下陷而不能升则用东垣，火上升而不能降则用丹溪。二老人理深谭，各造其极，无容议也。[132p]

If the yang energy has not necessarily descended and instead ascends to elevate its yin energy, infringing upon the position of yang, how could such a transformation be trivial? Furthermore, if the yin energy is accustomed to obstructing the clear yang above, while the flesh in the chest swells and rises (like the moon), and the qi within the chest disperses causing bloating, applying this method mistakenly could lead to an upheaval, blocking the nine pathways, leaving one on the brink of death and in dire straits. Later generations have passed down that this method can elevate the clear and descend the turbid, and many knowledgeable individuals also believe this; can we still discuss medical matters? To nourish the qi within, allowing it to rise or fall on its own, one need not necessarily use methods to elevate it; using them is also acceptable. But if one demands the ability of elevating the clear from a method meant to descend the turbid, is that not foolish?

According to the evidence of deficiency due to overexertion, those with yin deficiency are often nine out of ten, while those with yang deficiency are only one or two at most. Danxi has commented on the excess of yang and insufficiency of yin, establishing the Great Yin Nourishing Pill, along with the Four Substances Decoction plus Huangbo and Zhimu, which parallels the method of Dongyuan in tonifying the middle and benefiting qi. If the qi sinks and cannot rise, then use Dongyuan's method; if the fire ascends and cannot descend, then utilize Danxi's method. Both of these elder physicians have profound insights and have reached their extremes; there is no room for debate.[132p]

前论补中益气，能升清阳，设误用之，反升浊阴，故致其叮咛矣。而丹溪之法，用之多不效者，可不深维其故哉？昌谓立法者无过，而用法者不得法中之奥，过端四出。盖于阳常有余，阴常不足二语，未常细心推辨耳。夫阳之有余得十之七，阴之不足得十之三，此所谓真有余真不足也。阳真有余，一切补阴之药，直受之而无恐，多用之亦无害，是则补阴在所必需矣。若阴之不足者，十存其三，而阳之有余者，十存四五，亦名有余，而实则非真有余也，究亦同归不足而已。[133p]

The introduction discusses the method of補中益氣 (Buzhong Yiqi), which can raise the clear Yang. However, if misapplied, it may instead elevate the turbid Yin, hence the caution that follows. As for Danxi's method, many who use it find it ineffective—shouldn't we ponder deeply the reasons for this? Chang asserts that those who establish the law are without fault, while those who apply it may fail to grasp its essence, leading to deviations in their practice.

In essence, there is often an excess of Yang and a deficiency of Yin, yet this point is rarely examined with care. If Yin has a true deficiency at three out of ten while Yang has a true excess at seven out of ten, this is what is meant by true excess and true deficiency. When Yang is truly in excess, any remedies that supplement Yin can be taken freely without fear, and even heavy usage is harmless, thus making the supplementation of Yin necessary.

However, if Yin is genuinely deficient (three out of ten), while Yang appears to be excess (remaining four or five out of ten), it is also referred to as excess, but in reality, it is not a true excess—it ultimately results in the same outcome of deficiency.[133p]

补阴寒凉之药尚敢恣用乎？不知此义而恣用之，岂但不效，其后转成阴盛阳虚，清谷盗汗等患，究竟阴基已坏于前，即欲更补其气，其如味之不能载何？故再致叮咛，俾用昔人法，如持衡在手，较量于轻重之间可矣。虚劳之属阳虚者，十中岂无一二？严氏芪附汤、参附汤二方似不可少，其方从《金匮》朮附汤生出，投之得当，通于神明。其虚劳失血，宜之者尤多，以其善治龙雷之阴火耳。但以参芪为君，附子为佐，虽每服一两，不嫌其多，方中止用芪附各半，人参五钱，附子一两，分三服，能无倒乎？[134p]

Are we still daring to recklessly use medicines that supplement the yin and alleviate coldness? Not understanding this principle and using them indiscriminately will not only be ineffective, but will also lead to a condition of excessive yin and deficient yang, resulting in issues such as spontaneous sweating and weakness of the spleen. Ultimately, the foundation of the yin has already been compromised, and when trying to replenish qi, how can they carry it? Therefore, I reiterate the caution to follow the methods of ancient practitioners, like holding a scale in hand, to weigh and balance their use. Among those suffering from deficiency and excessive yang, is there surely not one or two cases? The formulas from the Yan family, such as Qi Fu Decoction and Ren Fu Decoction, seem indispensable. These formulas are derived from the "Jin Kui" Zhou Fu Decoction, and when used appropriately, they resonate with the spirit. For those with deficiency and loss of blood, the appropriate ones are particularly numerous as they effectively treat the yin fire of Dragon and Thunder. However, with ginseng and astragalus as the monarch and minister, although each dose may be a couple of taels, it is not considered excessive. In the formula, stop using equal parts of astragalus and fuzi; instead, use five qian of ginseng and one tael of fuzi, divided into three doses. Can this not work?[134p]

　　　　　附陈藏器用药凡例

　　虚劳头痛复热，加枸杞、萎蕤。虚而欲吐，加人参。虚而不安，亦加人参。虚而多梦纷纭，加龙骨。虚而多热，加地黄、牡蛎、地肤子、甘草。虚而冷，加当归、川芎、干姜。虚而损，加锺乳、棘刺、苁蓉、巴戟天。虚而大热，加黄芩、天冬。虚而多忘，加茯苓、远志。虚而口干，加麦冬、知母。虚而吸吸，加胡麻、覆盆子、柏子仁。虚而多气兼微咳，加五味子、大枣。虚而惊悸不安，加龙齿、沙参、紫石英、小草。若冷则用紫石英、小草，若客热则用沙参、龙齿，不冷不热皆用之。[135p]

General Guidelines for Medicinal Usage in Chen Zangqi

For fatigue and headaches with heat, add Goji berries and Lycium. If there is fatigue with a desire to vomit, add Ginseng. If there is fatigue and restlessness, also add Ginseng. For fatigue with frequent dreams, add Dragon Bone. For fatigue with excess heat, add Rehmannia, Oyster shell, Plantago seed, and Licorice. For fatigue with coldness, add Angelica, Chuanxiong, and Dried Ginger. For fatigue with depletion, add Goji berry, Cistanche, and Morinda. For fatigue with significant heat, add Scutellaria and Asparagus. For fatigue with forgetfulness, add Poria and Polygala. For fatigue with dry mouth, add Ophiopogon and Anemarrhena. For fatigue with weak breathing, add Sesame, Raspberry, and Biota seed. For fatigue with gas and slight cough, add Schisandra and Jujube. For fatigue with palpitations and restlessness, add Dragon Tooth, Adenophora, Amethyst, and Small Grass. If there is coldness, use Amethyst and Small Grass; if there is guest heat, use Adenophora and Dragon Tooth; if neither cold nor hot, use all.[135p]

虚而身强腰中不利，加磁石、杜仲。虚而多冷，加桂心、吴茱萸、附子、乌头。虚而劳小便赤，加黄芩。虚而客热，加地骨皮、黄芪。虚而冷，加黄芪。虚而痰复有气，加生姜、半夏、枳实。虚而小肠利，加桑螵蛸、龙骨、鸡(月坒)胵，虚而小肠不利，加茯苓、泽泻。虚而损溺白，加厚朴。髓竭不足，加地黄、当归。肺气不足，加二冬、五味子。心气不足，加人参、茯苓、菖蒲。肝气不足，加天麻、川芎。脾气不足，加白朮、白芍、益智。肾气不足，加熟地、远志、丹皮。胆气不足，加细辛、酸枣仁、地榆。神昏不足，加朱砂、预知子、茯神。[136p]

If there is emptiness but strength in the body and discomfort in the waist, add magnetite and eucommia. If there is emptiness and excessive cold, add cassia heart, evodia, aconite, and thunder god vine. If there is emptiness leading to difficult urination with redness, add scutellaria. If there is emptiness accompanied by excess heat, add rehmannia peel and astragalus. If there is emptiness with cold, add astragalus. If there is emptiness with phlegm and gas, add fresh ginger, pinellia, and bitter orange. If there is emptiness leading to a smooth small intestine, add silkworm feces, dragon bone, and chicken (os peclen). If there is emptiness with the small intestine causing discomfort, add poria and alisma. If there is excessive white urination due to deficiency, add magnolia bark. If the marrow is exhausted and insufficient, add rehmannia and angelica. If lung qi is lacking, add the two winters and schizandra. If heart qi is lacking, add ginseng, poria, and aromatic flag. If liver qi is lacking, add gastrodia and chuanxiong. If spleen qi is lacking, add white atractylodes, white peony, and cardamom. If kidney qi is lacking, add prepared rehmannia, responsible herb, and moutan. If gallbladder qi is lacking, add asarum, sour jujube seed, and earthworm. If spirit is dull and insufficient, add cinnabar, premonitory seed, and jujube.[136p]

古今图书集成医部全录卷三百五

虚劳门

　　　　景岳全书 【明　张介宾】

　　　　　论虚损病源

　　凡劳伤虚损，五脏各有所主，而惟心脏最多。且心为君主之官，一身生气所系，最不可伤，而人多忽之而不知何也？夫五脏之神，皆禀于心，故忧生于心，肺必应之。忧之不已，而戚戚幽幽，则阳气日索，营卫日消，劳伤及肺，弗亡弗已。如经曰：尝贵后贱，虽不中邪，病从内生，名曰脱营。尝富后贫，名曰失精，五气留连，病有所并，暴乐暴苦，始乐后苦，皆伤精气。精气竭绝，形体毁沮，故贵脱势。[137p]

The Complete Collection of Ancient and Modern Books, Volume 350

The Door of Xu Lao (Emaciation)

From the Total Compilation of Jingyue [Ming, Zhang Jiebin]

Discussion on the Origins of Xu Sun Disease

In cases of labor-induced emaciation, each of the five organs has its responsibilities, yet the heart bears the heaviest burden. The heart is the sovereign organ, upon which the vitality of the entire body depends, making it most vulnerable to harm; yet many people overlook this, unaware of its significance. The spirits of the five organs all depend on the heart; thus, when worries arise in the heart, the lungs must respond. If worry persists, leading to deep, somber feelings, the yang energy gradually depletes, and the nutritive and defensive energies diminish day by day. When labor adversely affects the lungs, this situation does not continue indefinitely. As the classic text states: "When one experiences elevated status after a period of devaluation, though not afflicted by an external pathogenic factor, illness arises from within, termed ‘loss of nutritive energy.’ When one experiences wealth after a period of poverty, it is termed ‘loss of essence,’ as the five energies become intertwined, resulting in various afflictions. Sudden joy or sudden sorrow, happiness followed by suffering—all exhaust the vital essence. When the vital essence is depleted, the body deteriorates, leading to significant losses in vitality.[137p]

虽不中邪，精神内伤，身必败亡之类，无非虑竭将来，追穷已往，而二阳并伤，但其潜消暗烁于冥冥之中，人所不觉，而不知五脏之伤，惟心为本，凡值此者，速宜舒情知命，力挽先天。要知人生在世，喜一日则得一日，忧一日则失一日，但使灵明常醒，尚何尘魔敢犯哉？及其既病，而用参、芪、归、朮、益气汤之类，亦不过后天之末着耳。知者，当知所先也。喜因欲遂而发，若乎无伤。而经曰：喜伤心；又曰：暴喜伤阳；又曰：喜乐者，神惮散而不藏；又曰：肺喜乐无极则伤魄，魄伤则狂，狂者意不存人，皮革焦，毛悴色夭，死于夏。盖心藏神，肺藏气，二阳脏也。故暴喜过甚则伤阳，而神气因以耗散；或纵喜无节，则淫荡流亡，以致精神疲竭，不可救药。[138p]

Though not influenced by external evils, if one's spirit suffers internally, their body will inevitably face defeat and demise. This is simply due to worries about the future and regret over the past, resulting in harm to both the Yang energies, which quietly diminish and flicker in the darkness, unnoticed by people, leading them to be unaware of the damage to the internal organs. The heart is fundamental; in such cases, one should promptly relieve their emotions and accept their fate, striving to restore their innate vitality.

One must understand that in life, happiness for a day equals gaining a day, while sorrow for a day means losing a day. As long as the spirit remains clear and awake, what dust and demons could dare approach? When illness occurs, using remedies like ginseng, astragalus, angelica, and various invigorating soups is merely a remedy for the aftermath. The wise should recognize what must be prioritized.

Joy arises from fulfilling desires and seems harmless. Yet, the classics state: joy can damage the heart; it also says that excessive joy harms the Yang; it further states that those who experience joy too freely have scattered spirits that cannot collect; and it says that excessive joy in the lungs leads to harm to the Po spirit, causing madness, wherein one loses their sense of self, leading to a withered appearance, pale complexion, and death in summer.

The heart houses the spirit, and the lungs house the Qi; both are organs of the Yang. Therefore, excessive unrestrained joy harms the Yang, dissipating spirit and energy. If one indulges in joy without moderation, it leads to aimless dispersion, resulting in mental exhaustion that may become irreparable.[138p]

或偶尔得志，则气盈载满，每多骄姿傲慢，自取败亡，而莫知其然者多矣。然则喜为人所忽，而犹有不可忽者如此。　　思本乎心。经曰：心怵惕思虑则伤神，神伤则恐惧自失，破(月囷)脱肉，毛悴色夭，死于冬。此伤心则然也。然思生于心，脾必应之，故思之不已，则劳伤在脾。经曰：思伤脾；又曰：思则心有所存，神有所归，正气留而不行，故气结矣。凡此为病，脾气结则为噎膈、为呕吐，而饮食不能运，食不运则血气日消，肌肉日削，精神日减，四肢不为用而生胀满泄泻等证，此伤心脾之阳也。夫人孰无思，而苦思难释，则劳伤至此，此养生者所当戒也。然思本伤脾，而忧亦伤脾。[139p]

Sometimes, when one occasionally achieves success, their heart fills with pride, leading to arrogance and self-destruction, often without realizing it. Thus, what should not be overlooked can still be ignored.

The source of thought lies in the heart. The classic text states: when the heart is anxious and troubled, it harms the spirit; when the spirit is harmed, fear and loss of self follow, leading to physical decline and premature aging, resulting in death in winter. This is how heart injury occurs. Thought arises from the heart, and the spleen must respond; therefore, persistent thinking can injure the spleen. The classic text says: thinking injures the spleen; it also states: when the heart holds onto thoughts, the spirit has a place to return, and the righteous qi remains stagnant, causing obstruction. All of this is illness; when the spleen's energy is obstructed, it leads to choking, vomiting, and an inability to digest food. When food cannot be digested, blood and energy are depleted daily, muscles deteriorate, and mental vitality diminishes, causing limbs to swell and leading to diarrhea, among other symptoms. This is the injury to the yang of the heart and spleen. Who among people is without thoughts? Yet, when overthinking causes pain, it leads to such injuries—this is something those who practice health preservation should be aware of. Furthermore, while thought primarily injures the spleen, worry also harms the spleen.[139p]

经曰：脾愁忧而不解则伤意，意伤则悗乱，四肢不举，毛悴色夭，死于春。盖人之忧思，本多兼用，而心脾肺所以并伤，故致伤上焦阳气，而二阳之病发自心脾，以渐成虚劳之证者，断由乎此。　　淫欲邪思，又与忧思不同，而损惟在肾。盖心躭欲念，肾必应之。凡君火动于上，则相火应于下。夫相火者，水中之火也，静而守位则为阳气，炽而无制则为龙雷，而涸泽燎原，无所不至。故其在肾，则为遗淋带浊；而水液渐以干枯，炎上入肝，则逼血妄行，而为吐为衄，或为营虚筋骨疼痛；又上入脾，则脾阴受伤，或为发热而饮食悉化痰涎；再上至肺，则皮毛无以扃固，而亡阳喘嗽，甚至喑哑声嘶。[140p]

The classics say: If the spleen is troubled and cannot resolve its worries, it injures the mind; when the mind is injured, the thoughts become disordered, the limbs become weak, and the complexion pales, leading to death in spring. People’s worries and thoughts are generally numerous and mixed, and thus the heart, spleen, and lungs are all damaged, resulting in harm to the yang qi of the upper burner. The diseases of the two yang originate from the heart and spleen, progressively manifesting as symptoms of deficiency, presented here.

Lustful desires and evil thoughts differ from worries and thoughts, yet they harm only the kidneys. The heart, when tempted by desires, must respond with the kidneys. When the sovereign fire moves upward, the ministerial fire responds below. This ministerial fire is the fire within water; when still and guarded, it constitutes yang qi, but when fervent and uncontrolled, it becomes like dragon thunder, scorching all. Thus, when it is in the kidneys, it results in residual heat and turbidity; as the water and liquids gradually dry up and the fire rises into the liver, it forces the blood into chaotic movement, causing vomiting or nosebleeds, or leading to deficiencies that result in pain in the sinews and bones. If it further ascends to the spleen, it injures the spleen's yin, resulting in fevers and the total transformation of food into phlegm. If it ascends to the lungs, the skin and hair lose their ability to be firm, leading to a loss of yang, causing wheezing and cough, and even leading to mute and hoarse voices.[140p]

是皆无根虚火，阳不守舍，而光焰诣天，自下而上，由肾而肺，本源渐槁，上实下虚，是诚剥极之象也。凡师尼室女失偶之辈，虽非房室之劳，而私情系恋，思想无穷，或对面千里，所愿不得，则欲火摇心，真阴日削，遂致虚损不救。凡五劳之中，莫此为甚，苟知重命，慎毋蹈之！　　七情伤肾，恐亦居多。盖恐畏在心，肾则受之。故经曰；恐伤肾；又曰：恐则精却；又曰：恐惧而不解则伤精，精伤则骨酸痿厥，精时自下。余尝诊一在官少年，因恐而致病，病稍愈而阳痿，及其病复，终不可疗。又尝见猝恐者，必阴缩或遗尿，是皆伤肾之征也。[141p]

These are all rootless, empty fires; the yang does not guard the home, and its flames reach to the heavens, rising from below, from the kidneys to the lungs. The source gradually withers, with the upper part solid and the lower part empty, truly a manifestation of extreme depletion. Among those who are unaccompanied, such as monks and female practitioners, even though they are not entangled in marital duties, their private feelings are bound in love, and their thoughts are endless. When separated by thousands of miles and their wishes unfulfilled, the fiery desire shakes their hearts, the true yin decreases daily, leading to irreparable emptiness and loss. Among the five labors, none is worse than this. If one knows to value life, they must carefully avoid it!

The seven feelings harm the kidneys, and fear is likely among them. Fear and dread reside in the heart, hence the kidneys are affected. Therefore, the scriptures say: fear harms the kidneys; it also says: fear causes the essence to retreat; and again it mentions: fear and anxiety without resolution harm the essence. When the essence is harmed, the bones ache, and there is weakness and numbness in the limbs. I once diagnosed a young official whose illness stemmed from fear; although his condition slightly improved, he became impotent, and when his illness recurred, it was ultimately incurable. I have also witnessed those who experience sudden fear; they invariably suffer from retraction of the yin or involuntary urination, all indications of kidney injury.[141p]

然恐固伤肾，而怒亦伤肾。经曰：肾盛怒而不止则伤志，志伤则喜忘其前言，腰背不可以俯仰屈伸，毛悴色夭，死于季夏。是知盛怒不惟伤肝，而肾亦受其害也。　　怒生于心，肝必应之，怒不知节，则劳伤在肝。经曰：怒伤肝；又曰：怒则气逆，甚则呕血及飧泄，故气上矣。盖肝为阴中之阳脏，故肝之为病，有在阴者，有在阳者。如火因怒动而逼血妄行，以致气逆于上而胀痛喘急者，此伤其阴者也。又或气以怒伤，而木郁无伸，以致侵脾气陷，而为呕胀泄痛，食饮不行者，此伤其阳者也。然随怒随消者，未必致病，脏气坚固者，未必致病。[142p]

However, excessive anger indeed harms the kidneys, and anger itself also damages the kidneys. The classic text states: "When the kidneys are overwhelmed by anger and do not cease, it injures the will. When the will is injured, joy forgets its previous words, the lower back cannot bend or extend, hair withers, complexion fades, and death occurs in late summer." Thus, it is understood that severe anger not only harms the liver, but also the kidneys suffer damage.

Anger arises from the heart, and the liver must respond. If anger is unrestrained, it causes labor and harm to the liver. The classic text states: "Anger injures the liver"; it also states: "Anger causes the qi to rebel, and in severe cases, leads to vomiting blood and diarrhea, which causes the qi to rise." This is because the liver is a yang organ within the yin, so liver diseases can manifest in both yin and yang aspects. For instance, if anger causes fire to surge, it forces the blood to move erratically, resulting in qi rebellion, leading to distention, pain, and shortness of breath; this injures its yin. Alternatively, if anger injures the qi, the wood element becomes stagnant and cannot extend, which adversely affects the spleen's qi, resulting in bloating, pain, and food and drink not moving well; this injures its yang. However, the occasional expression of anger does not necessarily lead to illness, and firm internal organs do not always result in disease.[142p]

惟先天禀弱而三阴易损者，使不知节，则东方之实，多致西方之败也。然怒本伤肝，而悲哀亦最伤肝。经曰：肝悲哀动中则伤魂，魂伤则狂妄不精，不精则不正当，人阴缩而筋挛，两胁骨不举，毛悴色夭，死于秋。盖怒盛伤肝，肝气实也；悲哀伤肝，肝气虚也。但实不终实，而虚则终虚耳。虚而不顾，则必至劳损，而治当察其邪正也。　　惊气本以入心，而实通于肝胆。经曰：惊则心无所依，神无所归，虑无所定，故气乱矣。又曰：东方色青，入通于肝，其病发惊骇。此所以惊能动心，而尤能伤及肝胆。[143p]

Only those who are weak in their innate constitution and easily harmed by the three yin should avoid excess without knowledge of moderation; otherwise, the abundance from the East will often lead to ruin in the West. Anger primarily injures the liver, while grief also most severely hurts the liver. The classics say: when grief moves the liver, it damages the soul; when the soul is harmed, one becomes manic and unfocused; when unfocused, one becomes imprecise. This leads to a retraction of the yin and rigidity of the tendons, the sides of the body are unsupported, the hair wanes, the complexion fades, leading to death in autumn. Indeed, excessive anger injures the liver, indicating abundant liver qi; grief injures the liver, indicating deficient liver qi. However, abundance does not last forever, whereas deficiency can lead to lasting emptiness. If deficiency is neglected, it will inevitably cause exhaustion, and treatment must focus on discerning the right from the wrong.

The shock energy originally enters the heart but indeed connects with the liver and gallbladder. The classics say: when startled, the heart has nothing to rely on, the spirit has nowhere to return, and thoughts are not settled, thus the qi becomes chaotic. Furthermore, it is said: the color associated with the East is green, which connects with the liver, and ailments arise from shock. This is why shock can disturb the heart, but especially injure the liver and gallbladder.[143p]

心为君主固不可伤，而胆以中正之官，实少阳生气所居，故十一脏阳刚之气，皆取决于胆，若或损之，则诸脏生气，因皆消索致败，其危立见。尝见微惊致病者，惟养心安神，神复则病自却。若惊畏日积，或一时大惊损胆，或致胆汁泄而通身发黄，默默无言者，皆不可救，论详疸门。　　色欲过度者，多成劳损。盖人自有生以后，惟赖后天精气以为立命之本。故精强神亦强，神强必有寿；精虚气亦虚，气虚必多夭。其有先天所禀原不甚厚者，但知自珍，而培以后天，则无不获寿。设禀赋本薄，而且姿情纵欲，再伐后天，则必成虚损。此而伤生，咎将谁委？又有年尚未冠，壬水方生，保养萌芽，正在此日，而无知孺子，遽摇女精，余见苞萼未成，而蜉蝣旦暮者多矣，良可悲也！此其责不在孺子而在父师。[144p]

The heart, as the ruler, must not be harmed; however, the gallbladder, serving as the official of middle righteousness, truly houses the vital energy of Shaoyang. Therefore, the yang essence of the eleven organs depends on the gallbladder. If it is harmed, the vital energies of the organs will dwindle, leading to inevitable defeat and danger. I have observed those who fall ill from slight fright; by nurturing the heart and calming the spirit, when the spirit is restored, the illness will dissipate. If fear accumulates over time or if a sudden fright harms the gallbladder, it can cause bile to seep, resulting in a yellowing of the entire body, leaving one silently suffering—such cases are beyond remedy, as elaborated in the discourse on jaundice.

Excessive desire for color and form often leads to depletion. Since from birth, one relies solely on the postnatal essence and energy as the foundation of life. Thus, strong essence leads to a strong spirit; a strong spirit must have longevity. Conversely, weak essence and energy result in weakness, often leading to premature death. Those who are naturally endowed but have a thin base must recognize and cultivate their postnatal essence; in doing so, longevity can be achieved. However, if one’s endowment is already weak, and yet one indulges in desires and exhausts postnatal energy, it will surely lead to depletion. In such cases, who shall be blamed for the loss of life?

Moreover, there are young ones who have not yet matured; at the time when Ren water is just beginning, nurturing their budding vitality is crucial. If ignorant youths quickly indulge in sexual desires, I have witnessed many like unfurling buds, like mayflies flickering from dawn to dusk—this is truly lamentable. The blame does not fall upon the youth but on their parents and teachers.[144p]

使不先有明诲，俾知保生之道，则彼以童心，岂识利害，而徒临期恳祷，号呼悲戚，将何济于事哉！　　劳倦不顾者，多成劳损。夫劳之于人，孰能免之？如奔走食力之夫，终日营营而未闻其病者，何也？贫贱之劳，作息有度，无关荣辱，习以为常，何病之有？惟安闲柔脆之辈，而苦竭心力，斯为害矣。故或劳于名利而不知寒暑之伤形，或劳于色欲而不知旦暮之疲困，或劳于游荡而忍饥竭力于呼卢驰骤之场，或劳于疾病而剥削伤残于无术庸医之手；或为诗书困厄，每缘萤雪成灾；或以好勇逞强，遂致绝筋乏力。[145p]

If one does not first provide clear teachings to guide them on the way to preserve life, how could a childlike heart discern between profit and loss? They would merely approach with desperate prayers and cries of sorrow; how would this be of any help? Those who neglect the strain of labor often suffer from exhaustion. Who can escape labor in this world? Like those who toil daily for their livelihood, tirelessly pursuing their work yet unaware of their ailments—how is this so? The labor of poverty and hardship, if done with moderation and detached from fame and disgrace, becomes a habit that poses no illness. It is only the idle and delicate who, in overexerting themselves, suffer harm. Thus, some labor for fame and wealth, unaware of the toll of seasons on their health; some labor for lust, oblivious to the fatigue of day and night; some labor in idleness, enduring hunger and exhaustively rushing to and fro; some labor under illness, suffering further harm at the hands of incompetent and fraudulent doctors; some are ensnared by poetry and learning, each misfortune growing from their obsession; and some, driven by a reckless bravado, ultimately become exhausted and drained of strength.[145p]

总之不知自量，而务使勉强，一应妄作妄为，皆能致损。凡劳倦之伤，虽曰在脾，而若此诸劳不同。则凡伤筋、伤骨、伤气、伤血、伤精、伤神、伤皮毛肌肉，则实兼之五脏矣。呜呼！嗜欲迷人，其害至此。其故则在但知有彼而忘其有我耳。广成子曰：无劳女形，无摇女精，乃可以长生。若此二言者，人因其简，故多易之，而不知养生之道，于此八字而尽之矣，顾可以忽之也耶？　　一少年纵酒者，多成劳损。夫酒本狂药，大损真阴，惟少饮之，未必无益，多饮之难免无伤，而躭饮之则受其害者，十之八九矣。且凡人之禀赋，脏有阴阳，而酒之性质，亦有阴阳。盖酒成于酿，其性则热；汁化于水，其质则寒。[146p]

In summary, those who do not know their own limits and strive to push themselves can easily lead to misfortune with reckless actions. The harms from labor and fatigue, although said to originate in the spleen, vary greatly. Injuries to tendons, bones, energy, blood, essence, spirit, skin, and muscles all truly involve the internal organs. Alas! Indulgence in desires can be so harmful. The reason lies in forgetting the self while being aware of the external. Guang Chengzi said: Do not labor the form, do not shake the essence; only then can one achieve longevity. These two sayings are succinct and thus often simplified by people, who do not recognize the principles of health preservation, all contained within these eight characters. Can they be overlooked?

A young person who frequently drinks wine tends to suffer from labor and damage. Wine is fundamentally an intoxicating substance that greatly harms the true essence. Drinking a little may not necessarily be harmful, but excessive drinking inevitably leads to injury, and those who indulge excessively suffer the consequences in almost all cases. Furthermore, every person's constitution has yin and yang, and the nature of wine also possesses yin and yang. Wine is made through fermentation, which gives it a hot nature; when it is diluted with water, it has a cold quality.[146p]

若以阴虚者纵饮之，则质不足以滋阴而性偏动火，故热者愈热，而病为吐血、衄血、便血、尿血、喘嗽、躁烦、狂悖等证，此酒性伤阴而然也。若阳虚者，纵饮之则性不足以扶阳，而质留为水，故寒者愈寒，而病为膨胀、泄泻、腹痛、吞酸、少食、亡阳、暴脱等证，此酒质伤阳而然也。故纵酒者既能伤阴，尤能伤阳，害有如此，人果知否？矧酒能乱性，每致因酒妄为，则凡伤精竭力，动气失机，及遇病不胜等事，无所不至，而阴受其损，多罔觉也。夫纵酒之时，固不虑其害之若此，及病至沉危，犹不知为酒困，故余详明于此，以为纵酒者之先觉云。　　一疾病误治，及失于调理者，病后多成虚损。[147p]

If those with Yin deficiency indulge excessively in drinking, their constitution is insufficient to nourish Yin, leading to a tendency to generate heat. Thus, the heat intensifies, resulting in symptoms such as vomiting blood, bloody nosebleeds, blood in stools, blood in urine, wheezing, irritability, mania, and agitation. This is because alcohol harms Yin. Conversely, if those with Yang deficiency indulge, their constitution is unable to support Yang, causing fluids to accumulate as dampness. Therefore, the cold increases, leading to symptoms such as swelling, diarrhea, abdominal pain, acid reflux, poor appetite, loss of Yang, and sudden collapse. This occurs because alcohol injures Yang. Thus, excessive drinking can harm both Yin and Yang, with such dangers present—are people aware of this? Moreover, alcohol can disrupt one's nature; it often leads to reckless behavior, resulting in damage to essence and depletion of energy, causing distress and loss of balance—encountering illness can be overwhelming. The damage to Yin goes often unnoticed. During times of excessive drinking, one does not consider the harm that can arise. When illness strikes severely, one may still be unaware that it is due to the effects of alcohol. Therefore, I have detailed these points, hoping that those who drink excessively may become more aware. A single disease mismanaged or failure in regulation often leads to chronic harm post-illness.[147p]

盖病有虚实，治有补泻。必补泻得宜，斯为上工。余见世俗之医，固不知神理为何物，而且并邪正缓急，俱不知之。故每致伐人元气，败人生机，而随药随毙者，已无从诉。其有幸而得免，而受其残剥，以致病后多成虚损而不能复振者，此何以故也？故凡医有未明，万毋轻率，是诚仁人积德之一端也。至若失于调治，致不能起，则俗云：小孔不补，大孔叫寃苦。亦自作之而自受之耳，又何尤焉？　　凡虚损之由，具道如前，无非酒色劳倦七情饮食所致。故或先伤其气，气伤必及于精；或先伤其精，精伤必及于气。但精气在人，无非谓之阴分。盖阴为天一之根，形质之祖，故凡损在形质者，总曰阴虚，此大目也。[148p]

Diseases can be classified as deficiency or excess, and treatments should either tonify or drain. Only when supplementation and draining are properly administered can one be considered a master in the field. I have observed that many practitioners do not understand the principles of healing, and they are neither aware of what is right or wrong nor understand the urgency of conditions. As a result, they often harm the vital energy of patients and disrupt their life force; those who suffer and die from the treatment have no recourse. Those who are fortunate enough to escape still suffer from the detrimental effects, leading to many cases of deficiency that cannot recover. Why is this the case? Thus, it is crucial that medical professionals approach their craft with care and avoid rashness, as this is genuinely a part of accumulating virtue for compassionate individuals.

Moreover, if there are failures in regulation and treatment leading to inability to recover, the saying goes: "If the small hole is not patched, the large hole will lament suffering." This results from one's own actions, so what more is there to criticize?

The causes of deficiency are as previously discussed and stem solely from indulgence in alcohol, pleasures, labor, emotional strains, and dietary excesses. Thus, one might first injure the vital energy, which will subsequently affect the essence; or one might first injure the essence, which will then affect the vital energy. Both vital energy and essence within a person are referred to as the yin aspect. Yin is the root of all that is heavenly, the progenitor of form and substance. Therefore, any loss related to form and substance is collectively termed as yin deficiency—this is a fundamental observation.[148p]

若分而言之，则有阴中之阴虚者，其病为发热躁烦，头红面赤，唇干舌燥，咽痛口疮，吐衄便尿血，大便燥结，小水痛濇等证。有阴中之阳虚者，其病为怯寒憔悴，气短神疲，头运目眩，呕恶食少，腹痛飧泄，二便不禁等证；甚至咳嗽吐痰遗精盗汗，气喘声喑，筋骨疼痛，心神恍惚，肌肉尽削，梦与鬼交，妇人月闭等证。则无论阴阳，凡病至极，皆所必至，总由真阴之败耳。然真阴所居，惟肾为主，盖肾为精血之海，而人之生气，即同天地之阳气，无非自下而上，所以肾为五脏之本。[149p]

If we speak of divisions, there are those with yin within yin deficiency, whose ailments include fever and irritability, a red head and face, dry lips and parched tongue, throat pain and mouth ulcers, vomiting, nosebleeds, blood in urine, hard and dry bowels, and painful and difficult urination.

There are also those with yin within yang deficiency, whose ailments include sensitivity to cold, emaciation, shortness of breath, fatigue, dizziness, nausea, poor appetite, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and incontinence. This can extend to coughing with phlegm, nocturnal emissions, night sweats, wheezing with a hushed voice, muscle and joint pain, confusion of the mind, extreme muscle wasting, dreams of encounters with ghosts, and women experiencing missed menstrual periods.

Thus, regardless of yin or yang, in severe illness, all symptoms are inevitably present, stemming from the failure of true yin. True yin resides in the kidneys, which are regarded as the sea of essence and blood, and the vital energy of a person corresponds to the yang energy of heaven and earth, flowing upward, making the kidneys the foundation of the five organs.[149p]

故肾水亏则肝失所滋而血燥生；肾水亏则水不归源而脾痰起；肾水亏则心肾不交而神色败；肾水亏则盗伤肺气而喘嗽频；肾水亏则孤阳无主而虚火炽。凡劳伤等证，使非伤入根本，何以危笃至此？故凡病甚于上者，必其竭甚于下也。余故曰：虚邪之至，害必归阴；五脏之伤，穷必及肾。穷而至此，吾末如之何也矣。所贵乎君子知其微而已。　　凡损伤元气者，本皆虚证，而古方以虚损劳瘵，各分门类，则病若有异，亦所宜辨。盖虚损之谓，或有发见于一证，或有困惫于暂时，凡在经在脏，但伤元气，则无非虚损病也。至若劳瘵之有不同者，或以骨蒸，或以干嗽，甚至吐血吐痰，营卫俱败，尫羸日甚，此其积渐有日，本末俱竭而然。但虚损之虚，有在阴分，有在阳分。[150p]

When the kidney's water is deficient, the liver lacks nourishment, leading to dryness in the blood; when the kidney's water is deficient, water does not return to its source, causing phlegm in the spleen; when the kidney's water is deficient, the heart and kidney do not interact, resulting in a decline in spirit and complexion; when the kidney's water is deficient, it harms the lung's qi, leading to frequent coughing and wheezing; when the kidney's water is deficient, solitary yang lacks a master, causing an excessive fire. In all cases of exhaustion and related symptoms, if the root is not damaged, how could there be such severe consequences? Therefore, in all illnesses more pronounced at the upper part, the depletion must be more severe at the lower part. Hence, I say: when the emptiness of malicious influences arrives, the harm must return to yin; the injuries of the five organs ultimately affect the kidney. When it reaches this point, what more can I do? What is valued is that the noble man recognizes the subtle signs.

All damages to the original qi are fundamentally empty conditions. Ancient methods distinguished these empty damages—whether from exhaustion or consumption—into various categories; even if the diseases seem different, they should still be discerned. The term "empty damage" implies that it may manifest as one symptom or may result in fatigue for a time; as long as it pertains to the meridians or organs and harms the original qi, it is fundamentally an empty damage condition. As for the differing symptoms of exhaustion and disease, some may present with bone steaming, some with dry coughing, and even with coughing up blood or phlegm, leading to failure in both nutritive and protective qi, resulting in continual decline. This accumulation occurs gradually; when both the root and the branches are exhausted, it is a consequence. However, the emptiness of damage can be found either in the yin aspect or in the yang aspect.[150p]

然病在未深，多宜温补，若劳瘵之虚，深在阴中之阴分，多有不宜温补者。然凡治虚证宜温补者，病多易治；不宜温补者，病多难治。此虚劳若乎有异，而不知劳瘵之损，即损之深而虚之甚者耳。凡虚损不愈，则日甚成劳矣，有不可不慎也。　　虚损两颧红赤或唇红者，阴虚于下，逼阳于上也。仲景曰：其面戴阳者，下虚故也。虚而多渴者，肾水不足，引水自救也。喑哑声不出者，由肾气之竭，盖声出于喉而根于肾。经曰：内夺而厥，则为喑俳。此肾虚也。虚而喘急者阴虚肺格，气无所归也。喉干咽痛者，真水下亏，虚火上浮也。不眠恍惚者，血不养心，神不能藏也。时多烦躁者，阳中无阴，柔不济刚也。[151p]

When the illness is not deep yet, it is advisable to use warming tonics. However, in cases of exhaustion and consumptive disorders, where the deficiency is deep in the yin region, there are many conditions where warming tonics should be avoided. In general, for treating deficiency syndromes, conditions that are appropriate for warming tonics tend to be easier to treat; those that are not suitable for warming tonics are often harder to treat. This deficiency and exhaustion may seem different, but it is important to recognize that the damage from consumptive illnesses is deeply rooted and leads to considerable deficiency.

If the signs of deficiency remain, they will gradually worsen into exhaustion, and one must be cautious about this. If there are two prominent red cheeks or red lips, it indicates a deficiency in the lower part, forcing the yang upward. As Zhang Zhongjing stated, the face displaying yang is due to deficiency below. If there is much thirst, it signifies insufficient kidney water, as the body seeks to replenish itself. Hoarseness or the inability to speak arises from depleted kidney energy, since sound emerges from the throat but is fundamentally rooted in the kidneys. The classics say: when one loses internal vitality, they become mute. This indicates kidney deficiency.

If there is deficiency accompanied by urgent breathing, it is due to yin-deficient lungs, where the qi has nowhere to settle. Dry throat and sore throat indicate a deficiency in true water below and an excess of floating fire above. If one cannot sleep and feels disoriented, it shows that blood does not nurture the heart, causing the spirit to be uncontained. Frequent irritability indicates that there is no yin amidst the yang, and softness cannot assist the hardness.[151p]

易生嗔怒，或筋急酸痛者，水亏木燥，肝失所资也。饮食不甘，肌肉渐削者，脾元失守，化机日败也。心下跳动，怔忡不宁者，气不归精也。经曰：胃之大络，名曰虚里，出于左乳下，其动应衣，宗气泄也。盗汗不止者，有火则阴不能守，无火则阳不能固也。虚而多痰，或如清水，或多白沫者，此水泛为痰，脾虚不能制水也。骨痛如折者，肾主骨，真阴败竭也。腰胁痛者，肝肾虚也。膝以下冷者，命门衰绝，火不归源也。小水黄濇淋沥者，真阴亏竭，气不化水也。足心如烙者，虚火烁阴，涌泉涸竭也。　　凡阳虚之人，因气虚也。阳气既虚，即不能嚏。仲景曰：欲嚏不能，此人肚中寒。故凡以阳虚之证，而忽见嚏者，便有回生之兆。[152p]

Excessive anger arises from a deficiency in water and a dryness in wood, leading the liver to lose its nourishment. A lack of appetite and gradual muscle wasting indicate that the spleen's essence is lost and the transformative mechanism is failing. A racing heart and restlessness signify that the qi is not returning to its essence. It is said: the great network of the stomach is called the "virtual interior," originating below the left breast, responding to clothing and indicating a leakage of vital qi. Continuous night sweats occur when there is fire, preventing the yin from holding, and without fire, the yang cannot be stabilized. When there is a deficiency accompanied by phlegm, whether it resembles clear water or has much white foam, it is due to water overflowing as phlegm, and the spleen is too weak to control water. Bone pain that feels like fractures indicates the kidney governs bones, and true yin is depleting. Pain in the waist and flanks suggests deficiency in both the liver and kidney. Coldness below the knees signifies the gate of life is failing, causing fire not to return to its source. Yellow, cloudy urination indicates true yin depletion and the qi is unable to transform water. A burning sensation in the soles of the feet shows that empty fire is consuming yin, leading to depletion of the bubbling spring.

In general, a person with yang deficiency suffers from qi deficiency. If yang is deficient, one cannot sneeze. Zhongjing said: "If one wishes to sneeze but cannot, this indicates cold in the abdomen." Therefore, whenever symptoms of yang deficiency are present and a sneeze occurs, it signifies a chance of revival.[152p]

　　　　　论脉

　　虚损之脉，凡甚急甚数、甚细甚弱、甚濇甚滑、甚短甚长、甚浮甚沉、甚弦甚紧、甚洪甚实者，皆劳伤之脉。然无论浮沉大小，但渐缓则渐有生意。若弦甚者，病必甚，数甚者，病必危。若以弦细而再加紧数，则百无一生矣。　　《要略》曰：脉芤者为血虚，沉迟而小者为脱气，大而无力为阳虚，数而无力为阴虚，脉大而芤者为脱血，平人脉大为劳，虚极亦为劳，脉微细者盗汗，寸弱而软为上虚，尺弱软濇为下虚，尺软滑疾为血虚，两关沉细为胃虚。《脉经》曰：脉来软者为虚，缓者为虚，微弱者为虚，弦者为中虚，细而微小者气血俱虚。[153p]

Discussion on Pulse

The pulse that is weak and deficient, whether it is extremely rapid and numerous, excessively thin and weak, excessively slippery and smooth, too short or too long, overly floating or sinking, very taut or tight, excessively flowing or solid, all indicate a pulse of labor injury. Regardless of whether it is floating or sinking, large or small, as long as it becomes gradually slower, there will be some vitality. If the pulse is overly taut, the illness will be severe; if it is too rapid, the illness will be perilous. If it is both taut and thin, with added tightness and rapidity, the chances of survival are virtually none.

The "Essentials" states: A pulse that is lacking (or hollow) indicates blood deficiency; one that is sinking, slow, and small indicates loss of qi; a large and weak pulse indicates yang deficiency; a rapid and weak pulse indicates yin deficiency; a large and hollow pulse indicates blood loss; a normal large pulse indicates labor; an extremely weak pulse also indicates labor; a very thin and weak pulse signals night sweats; a weak and soft pulse at the cun (distal) position indicates upper deficiency; a weak and soft pulse at the chi (proximal) position indicates lower deficiency; a soft and slippery pulse at the chi indicates blood deficiency; and with both guan positions sinking and thin, it indicates stomach deficiency. The "Pulse Classic" states: A soft pulse indicates deficiency, a slow pulse indicates deficiency, a weak pulse indicates deficiency, a taut pulse indicates moderate deficiency, and a pulse that is both thin and weak indicates deficiency in both qi and blood.[153p]

　　　　　辨爪

　　凡劳损之病，本属阴虚。阴虚必血少，而指爪为精血之余，故凡于诊候之际，但见其指爪干黄，觉有枯槁之色，则其发肤营气，具在吾目中矣。此于脉色之外，便可知其有虚损之候，而损之微甚，亦可因之以辨也。
　　　　　论治

　　病之虚损，变态不同，因有五劳七伤，证有营卫脏腑。总之，人赖以生者，惟此精气；而病为虚损者，亦惟此精气。气虚者，即阳虚也；精虚者，即阴虚也。凡病有火盛水亏，而见营卫燥，津液枯者，即阴虚之证也。有水盛火亏，而见脏腑寒，脾肾败者，即阳虚之证也。此惟阴阳偏困所以致然。凡治此者，但当培其不足，不可伐其有余。夫既缘虚损，而再去所余，则两败俱伤矣，岂不殆哉？惟是阴阳之辨，犹有不易。谓其阴阳之中，复有阴阳，其有似阳非阳，似阴非阴者，使非确有真见，最易惑人，此不可不详察也。且复有阴阳俱虚者，则阳为有生之本，而所重者，又单在阳气耳。[154p]

Distinguishing Nails

All Diseases of Strain and Injury Originally Belong to Yin Deficiency. Yin Deficiency Must Invariably Lead to Blood Deficiency, and Fingernails Are the Residue of Essence and Blood. Thus, when diagnosing, if one observes the nails to be dry and yellow, feeling a withered appearance, then the vital essence and nourishment of hair and skin are visibly apparent. This indicates the presence of deficiency symptoms beyond just pulse and color, and the severity of the deficiency can also be discerned from it.

Discussion on Treatment

The deficiency and damage of diseases exhibit different transformations, with variations occurring from the Five Strains and Seven Injuries, manifesting in the functions of the nutritive and defensive qi as well as the organs. In summary, what sustains life is solely this essence and qi; and in diseases characterized as deficient and damaged, it is also solely this essence and qi. Deficiency of qi reflects Yang Deficiency; deficiency of essence reflects Yin Deficiency. In cases where there is excessive fire and insufficient water, and one observes the nutritive and defensive qi to be dry, with body fluids depleted, this denotes symptoms of Yin Deficiency. Conversely, in cases of excessive water and insufficient fire, with the organs being cold and the spleen and kidneys failing, this indicates symptoms of Yang Deficiency. This is merely due to the imbalance of Yin and Yang.

When treating these conditions, one should only nourish the deficient aspect and not deplete the excess. If one were to further deplete what is in excess due to existing deficiency, it would result in mutual harm. Would this not be perilous? The differentiation of Yin and Yang is not readily clear. Within Yin and Yang, there exist further distinctions; some may seem Yang but are not, some may appear Yin but are not. Without true discernment, it is easy to fall into confusion, thus this should be carefully examined. Furthermore, there are instances of both Yin and Yang being deficient; in such cases, Yang is the foundation of life, and what is emphasized should primarily be the Yang qi.[154p]

知乎此，则虚损之治，如指诸掌矣。　　阳虚者多寒，非谓外来之寒，但阳气不足，则寒生于中也。若待既寒，则阳已败矣。而不知病见虚弱，而别无热证者，便是阳虚之候，即当温补元气，使阳气渐回，则真元自复矣。盖阳虚之候，多得之忧愁思虑以伤神，或劳役不节以伤力，或色欲过度而气随精去，或素禀元阳不足而寒冷致伤等病，皆阳气受损之所由也。欲补阳气，惟辛甘温燥之剂为宜，万勿兼清凉寒滑之品，以残此发生之气。如生地、芍药、天麦门冬、沙参之属，皆非所宜；而石斛、元参、知、蘗、芩、连、龟胶之类，则又切不可用。若气血俱虚者，宜大补元煎，或八珍汤，或十全大补汤。[155p]

In this context, the treatment of deficiency is like pointing out with fingers. Those with yang deficiency often feel cold, not due to external cold but because the yang energy is insufficient, leading to internal coldness. If one waits until it is already cold, then the yang has already weakened. If one perceives a weakness in the illness without any signs of heat, it is indeed a sign of yang deficiency. One should then warm and tonify the original energy, allowing the yang energy to gradually return, thus restoring the true essence.

The condition of yang deficiency is often caused by worries, excessive thinking that harms the spirit, or irregular labor that exhausts strength, or excessive desire that depletes the essence, or a natural lack of original yang leading to cold-related ailments—these are all reasons for the damage to yang energy. To replenish yang energy, only warm, sweet, and dry herbs are suitable; never combine them with cool, cold, or slippery substances, as those would deplete the emerging energy. Herbs like rehmannia, peony, ophiopogon, and sand ginseng are to be avoided, while those such as dendrobium, scrophularia, and others like phellodendron, coptis, and turtle gelatin must also be strictly omitted. If both qi and blood are deficient, a strong formula like the Great Replenishing Decoction, Eight Treasures Decoction, or Ten Complete Replenishing Decoction is recommended.[155p]

五脏俱虚，宜平补者，五福饮。命门阴分不足者，左归饮、左归丸。命门阳分不足者，右归饮、右归丸。气分虚寒者，六气煎。脾肾阴分虚寒诸变不一者，理阴煎。三焦阳气大虚者，六味回阳饮。气虚脾寒者，一炁丹。胃气虚寒者，温胃饮，理中汤。血虚寒滞者，五物煎。　　阴虚者多热，以水不济火，而阴虚生热也。此病多得于酒色嗜欲，或愤怒邪思，流荡狂劳，以动五脏之火，而先天元阴不足者，尤多此病。凡患虚损而多热多燥，不宜热食者，便是阴虚之候。欲滋其阴，惟宜甘凉醇静之物。凡阴中有火者，大忌辛温，如干姜、桂、附、破故纸、白朮、苍朮、半夏之属，皆不可轻用。[156p]

When there is deficiency in all five organs, it is advisable to use the Wufu Decoction for nourishing. If there is insufficient yin in the Kidney Gate, use the Zuogui Decoction or Zuogui Pill. If there is insufficient yang in the Kidney Gate, use the Yougui Decoction or Yougui Pill. If there is deficiency of qi with chill, use the Liuqi Decoction. For deficiency of yin in the spleen and kidney with various symptoms of cold, use the Liyin Decoction. If there is great deficiency of yang qi in the Sanjiao, use the Liuwei Huayang Decoction. If there is qi deficiency with spleen cold, use the Yiqi Dan. For deficiency of stomach qi with chill, use the Wengwei Decoction or the Lizhong Decoction. For blood deficiency with cold stagnation, use the Wuwu Decoction.

When yin is deficient, there is often much heat, as water does not help fire, and yin deficiency generates heat. This condition is often caused by indulgences in wine and desires, or by anger and evil thoughts, which disturb the fire of the five organs. Those who have a congenital deficiency of primordial yin are particularly prone to this condition. In cases of deficiency leading to excess heat and dryness, hot foods are not advisable, indicating a state of yin deficiency. To nourish the yin, one should only consume sweet, cool, and serene substances. Anything that has fire within the yin is strongly contraindicated, such as ginger, cinnamon, aconite, dried paper mulberry, white and cold atractylodes, and pinellia; these should not be used lightly.[156p]

即如人参、黄芪、枸杞、当归、杜仲之类，是皆阴中有阳，亦当酌宜而用之。盖恐阳旺则阴愈消，热增则水益涸耳。然阴虚者因其水亏，而水亏者又忌寒凉，盖苦劣之流，断非资补之物。其有火盛之甚，不得不从清凉者，亦当兼壮水之剂，相机间用，而可止即止，以防其败，斯得滋补之大法。　　虚损夜热，或午后发热，或喜冷便实者，此皆阴虚生热，水不制火也，宜加减一阴煎。若火在心肾而惊悸失志者，宜二阴煎。若外热不已而内不甚热，但宜补阴，不可清火，宜一阴煎，或六味地黄汤。有元气不足而虚热不已者，必用大补元煎，庶乎久之自愈。　　虚损咳嗽，虽五脏皆有所病，然专主则在肺肾。[157p]

For example, ginseng, astragalus, wolfberry, angelica, and eucommia are all substances that contain both yin and yang, and they should be used appropriately. This is because an excess of yang may further deplete yin, and an increase in heat can dry up water. Those with yin deficiency suffer from a lack of water, and those who are low in water should avoid cold and cool substances, as these are harmful and not nourishing. If there is excessive fire and one must resort to cooling agents, it is also necessary to combine them with tonics for the water element, using them in conjunction as needed, and stopping when appropriate to prevent deterioration. This is the great principle of nourishment.

For conditions of deficiency and night heat, or heat occurring in the afternoon, or when one prefers cold yet feels solid, these all indicate heat arising from yin deficiency, where water fails to control fire, and it is advisable to adjust the formula with a yin tonic. If the fire affects the heart and kidney, leading to palpitations and lack of focus, a stronger yin tonic is recommended. If there is persistent external heat with mild internal heat, one should merely tonify yin and not clear the fire, opting for a basic yin decoction, or Six-ingredient Rehmannia Decoction. If there is insufficient vital energy accompanied by persistent heat, a major decoction to restore the original qi must be used to promote self-healing over time.

For a deficiency-related cough, although all five organs may be affected, the focus is primarily on the lungs and kidneys.[157p]

盖肺为金脏，金之所畏者火也，金之化邪者燥也。燥则必痒，痒则必嗽，正以肾水不能制火，所以克金，阴精不能化气，所以病燥，故为咳嗽喘促咽痛喉疮声哑等证。凡治此者，只宜甘凉至静之剂，滋养金水，使肺肾相生，不受火制，则真阴渐复而嗽可渐愈。火盛者，宜四阴煎加减主之。火微者，宜一阴煎六味地黄汤，或左归饮。兼受风寒而嗽者，宜金水六君煎。贝母丸治嗽最佳。　　虚损吐血者，伤其阴也。故或吐或衄，所不能免。但当察其有火无火，及火之微与甚而治之。凡火之盛者，以火载血上，而脉证之间，自有热证可辨。[158p]

The lungs are considered the organ of metal, and what metal fears is fire, while its destructive influence comes from dryness. When dryness occurs, itching inevitably follows, and with itching comes coughing. This is exactly because the water from the kidneys cannot control the fire, thus affecting the metal; the yin essence cannot transform into qi, leading to dryness and causing symptoms like cough, wheezing, sore throat, voice hoarseness, and other related conditions.

When treating these symptoms, one should use only soothing, cool, and tranquilizing remedies to nourish the metal and water, ensuring that the lungs and kidneys support each other, without being overpowered by fire, which allows the true yin to gradually recover and the cough to improve. If fire is vigorous, one should use a modified Four Yin Decoction. If fire is mild, then a One Yin Decoction or the Liu Wei Di Huang Decoction, or the Left Returning Decoction may be appropriate. For those who have contracted wind and cold along with cough, the Jin Shui Liu Jun Decoction is recommended. The Bei Mu Pill is the best for treating cough.

For those with deficiency leading to hemoptysis, this injures their yin, which can cause either vomiting or nasal bleeding. However, one must assess whether there is fire present and the degree of its severity to treat accordingly. When fire is intense, it carries the blood upward, and there will be distinguishable heat signs between the pulse and symptoms.[158p]

急则治标，此不得不暂用芩、连、栀、蘗、竹叶、童便之属，或单以抽薪饮、徙薪饮之类主之。若阴虚而兼微火者，宜保阴煎，或清化饮，或加减一阴煎主之。血止即当养血，不宜过用寒凉也。若无实火而全属伤阴，则阴虚水亏，血由伤动，而为吐为衄者，此宜甘纯养阴之品，以静制动，以和治伤，使阴气安静得养，则血自归经，宜一阴煎、六味地黄汤，或小营煎之类主之。若阴虚连肺而兼嗽兼血者，宜四阴煎加减主之。若因劳役，别无火证，心脾肾三阴受伤而动血者，宜五阴煎、五福饮、六味地黄丸之类主之。若阴虚于下，格阳于上，六脉无根而大吐大衄者，此火不归源，真阳失守而然，宜右归饮加减主之，或八味地黄汤亦可。此惟思虑劳倦过伤者，多有此证。[159p]

In urgent situations, one must address the symptoms rather than the root cause, and thus, it is necessary to temporarily use herbs like Qín, Lián, Zhī, Yè, bamboo leaves, and童便 (child's urine). Alternatively, one may use formulas such as Chōuxīn drink or Xǐnxīn drink. If there is a deficiency of Yin accompanied by slight Fire, the appropriate remedy is to prepare Bǎo Yīn decoction, or Qīng Huà drink, or modify Yīnyīn decoction to treat the condition. Once the bleeding has stopped, it is essential to nourish the blood without excessively using cold or cool substances. If there is no excess Fire but the Yin is completely damaged, leading to a deficiency of Yin and a loss of water, causing vomiting or nosebleeds, one should use sweet and pure nourishing Yin products to quiet the movement and harmonize the damage. This allows the Yin energy to rest and be nourished, which will help the blood return to normal channels. Formulas such as Yīnyīn decoction, Liù Wèi Dì Huáng Tang, or Xiǎo Yíng decoction would be appropriate. If there is a Yin deficiency affecting the lungs, accompanied by coughing and bleeding, one should use Sì Yīnyīn decoction with adjustments. If bleeding occurs due to overexertion without any Fire symptoms, and all three Yin -- heart, spleen, and kidney -- are harmed and causing bleeding, one should use Wǔ Yīnyīn decoction, Wǔ Fú drink, or Liù Wèi Dì Huáng pill. If there is a Yin deficiency below and the Yang is constrained above, with all six pulse positions weak and leading to severe vomiting and nosebleeds, this indicates that Fire is not returning to its source, and True Yang has lost control. One should use Yòu Guī drink with modifications or Bā Wèi Dì Huáng Tang as suitable alternatives. This condition is commonly seen in those who have been overly burdened by worry and exhaustion.[159p]
