　　骨蒸发热：三岁童便五升，煎取一升，以蜜三匙和之，每服二碗，半日更服。此后常取自己小便服之，轻者二十日，重者五十日瘥。二十日后，当有虫如蜒蚰在身常出，十步内闻病人小便臭者瘥也。台州丹仙观道士张，病此自服，神验。【《必效方》】
　　男妇怯证：男用童女便，女用童男便，斩头去尾，日进二次，干烧饼压之，月余全愈。【《圣惠方》】
　　虚损劳瘵：德生丹。用无病妇人乳三酒杯，将磁碟晒极热，置乳于中，次入麝香末少许，木香末二分，调匀服，后饮浓茶三酒杯，如前晒碟盛人乳，并人胞末一具调服。服毕面膝俱赤，如醉思睡，只以白粥少少养之。【《集简方》】
　　接命丹：治男妇气血衰弱，痰火上升虚损之证。用人乳二杯，香甜白者为佳，以好梨汁一杯和匀，银石器内顿滚，每日五更一服。能消痰补虚，生血延寿，此乃以人补人，其妙无加。【《众妙方》】[258p]

Evaporation Heat of Bone: A three-year-old child’s urine amounts to five liters; boil it down to one liter and mix it with three teaspoons of honey. Take two bowls at a time and repeat after half a day. After this, regularly take your own urine. Light cases recover in twenty days, and severe cases in fifty days. After twenty days, one should expect to see worms like centipedes emerge from the body. If someone nearby can smell the foul odor of the patient’s urine, it indicates recovery. Zhang, a Taoist from the Danxian Temple in Taizhou, cured himself of this illness using this method, which proved effective.

Symptoms of Timidity in Men and Women: Men should use the urine of young girls, and women should use the urine of young boys. Collect the urine, removing the head and tail. Take this twice daily, pressing it between hot cakes, and complete recovery will occur in a month.

Deficiency and Consumption: Use "De Sheng Dan." Take three cups of breast milk from a healthy woman. Heat a ceramic plate until very hot and place the milk in it, then add a little musk powder and two fen (a measure) of sandalwood powder. Mix well and consume this, followed by three cups of strong tea. Afterward, repeat the process with the breast milk and add a proper quantity of powdered human placenta. After consumption, the face and knees will turn red, similar to being drunken and sleepy, and one should nourish oneself with a little plain congee.

Life-Connecting Elixir: This treats men and women with weak qi and blood, and symptoms of phlegm-fire rising due to deficiency. Use two cups of human milk, preferably sweet and white, mixed with one cup of good pear juice. Heat this mixture in a silver container until boiling, and take it at five in the morning daily. It can dissolve phlegm, replenish deficiency, nourish blood, and prolong life—truly a method of supplementing one human with another, unparalleled in its effectiveness.[258p]

　　天灵盖散：追取劳虫。天灵盖二指大，以檀香煎汤洗过酥炙，一气咒七通云：雷公神，电母圣，逢传尸，便须定。急急如律令！尖槟榔五枚，阿魏二分，麝香三分，辰砂一分，安息香三分，甘遂三分，为末，每服三钱，用童便四升，入银石器内，以葱白薤白各二七茎，青蒿二握，桃枝甘草各二茎五寸长者，柳枝、桑枝、酸榴枝各二茎七寸长，同煎至一升，分作二次，五更初调服前药。一服虫不下，约人行十里，又进一服。天明再进，取下虫物，名状不一，急擒入油铛煎之。其虫嘴青赤黄色可治，黑白色难治。然亦可断传染之患。凡修合先须斋戒于远处净室，勿令病人闻药气，及鸡犬猫畜孝子妇人一切污秽之物见之。虫下后，以白粥补之。数日之后，梦人哭泣相别，是其验也。【《上清紫庭仙方》】[259p]

Heavenly Crown Dispersion: To capture laboring worms. The Heavenly Crown is the size of two fingers, prepared by steeping sandalwood in broth and washing before roasting. Recite the incantation seven times: "Thunder Lord, Divine Mother of Lightning, when encountering a transmitted corpse, be sure to stabilize it. Urgently, as commanded!"

Use five sharp betel nuts, two parts asafoetida, three parts musk, one part cinnabar, three parts benzoin, and three parts hollow root, ground into powder. For each dose, take three qian (a weight measurement) mixed with four sheng (a liquid measurement) of child's urine in a silver container. Add two groups of seven green onion and garlic stalks, two handfuls of ephedra, and each of two five-inch long peach branches and licorice. Also add two seven-inch long willow, mulberry, and sour pomegranate branches, and decoct until you have one sheng, dividing it into two doses to be taken before dawn.

If the first dose does not expel the worms, take another after walking ten li (distances). At dawn, take the third dose to remove the worms, which may appear varied. Quickly catch and simmer them in oil. Worms with green, red, and yellow mouths can be treated; those that are black and white are difficult to manage. However, they can help prevent the transmission of infection.

Before performing the procedure, one must observe fasting and purify oneself in a distant clean space, ensuring the patient does not smell the medicine, and that no foul substances from chickens, dogs, cats, devoted sons, or women are present.

After the worms are expelled, replenish with white porridge. A few days later, if one dreams of people weeping and saying goodbye, it is a sign of success.[259p]

　　五劳七伤，吐血虚瘦：用初生胞衣长流水中，洗去恶血，待清汁出乃止，以酒煮烂，捣如泥，入白茯神末，和丸梧子大，每米饮下百丸。忌铁器。【《集验方》】
　　虚损骨蒸：用天灵盖如梳大炙黄，以水五升，煮取二升，分三服，起死神方也。 【《千金方》】　　又方：人头骨炙三两，麝香十两为末，捣千杵，丸梧子大，每服七丸，饮下，日再服。若胸前有青脉出者，以针刺看血色，未黑者，七日瘥。【《备急方》】
　　白凤膏：葛可久云：治久虚发热咳嗽吐痰咳血，火乘金位者，用黑嘴白鸭一只，取血，入温酒量饮，使直入肺经以润补之。将鸭干挦去毛，胁下开窍，去肠拭净，入大枣肉二升，参苓平胃散末一升，缚定，用沙瓮一　，置鸭在内，以炭火慢煨，将陈酒一瓶，作三次入之，酒干为度。取起，食鸭及枣，频作取愈。【《十药神书》】[260p]

Five labors and seven injuries, with symptoms of coughing blood and emaciation: use fresh amniotic fluid in running water to wash away the evil blood, stopping once the clear juice is out. Then, boil it with wine until it dissolves, pound it into a paste, mix it with powdered white poria and make into pills the size of a wutong seed, taking a hundred pills with every rice drink. Avoid iron utensils.

For deficiencies causing bone steaming: use the crown of the head, like a comb, roasted yellow, with five liters of water, boil it down to two liters, and divide it into three doses; this is a method to revive the dead.

Another recipe: roast three taels of human skull, ten taels of musk to powder, pound with a thousand pestles into pills the size of a wutong seed, take seven pills each time, twice a day. If there are blue veins appearing on the chest, use a needle to pierce and observe the blood color; if it is not black, it will heal in seven days.

White phoenix ointment: Ge Kejiu says this treats long-term deficiency, fevers, coughs, phlegm, and coughing up blood. If fire dominates the metal element, take one black-billed white duck, draw blood, and mix it with a moderate amount of warm wine, allowing it to enter the lung channel for nourishment. Prepare the duck by plucking feathers, opening a cavity under the wing, cleaning out the intestine, adding two liters of jujube meat and one liter of powdered ginseng and lily to fill it, securing it. Place the duck in a sand jar and slow-cook it with charcoal, adding a bottle of aged wine three times until the wine is absorbed. Afterward, consume the duck and jujubes frequently for recovery.[260p]

　　虚劳不眠：酸枣仁、榆叶等分为末，蜜丸如梧子，每服十五丸，日再。 【《千金方》，下同】
　　补虚羸：九月十日，取生湿枸杞子一升，清酒六升，煮五六沸，取出细研滤汁，令其子极净，曝令干，捣末和前汁，微火煎，令可丸，酒服二方寸匕，日二，加至三匕，名枸杞煎，亦可丸，服三十丸。　　又方：杏仁三升，内汤中去皮尖两仁，熟捣水研，取七八升汁，以铁釜置煻火上，取羊脂四斤，就釜内磨消，内杏仁汁温之。四五日，色如金状，饵如弹子，日三服。百日肥白易容，人不能识。名夏姬杏仁煎。　　又方：豉一升，蒸三遍，薤白一斤切，以水七升，煮取三升，分三服，小取汗。[261p]

For insomnia caused by虚劳: Grind sour jujube seeds and elm leaves into powder, mix with honey to form pills the size of a walnut; take fifteen pills each time, twice a day.

To replenish weakness: On the tenth day of September, take one liter of fresh, moist wolfberries and six liters of clear wine, boil for five or six bursts, then take out, finely grind, and filter the juice, making sure the seeds are very clean. Expose to dry, then crush into powder and mix with the previous juice, simmering over low heat until it can be formed into pills. Take two teaspoons of this with wine, twice a day, gradually increasing to three teaspoons; this is called wolfberry decoction, which can also be made into pills, taking thirty pills.

Another recipe: Take three liters of apricot kernels, remove the skins and tips from two of the kernels in hot water, and thoroughly mash them to extract seven to eight liters of juice. Place this in an iron pot over a fire, add four pounds of sheep fat and heat until it dissolves, then warm the apricot juice and mix it in. After four to five days, it will take on a golden color and have the consistency of balls; take it three times a day. After a hundred days, one appears plump and fair, unrecognizable to others. This is called summer princess apricot kernel decoction.

Another recipe: Take one liter of fermented soybeans, steam three times, then take one pound of sliced garlic chives, boil with seven liters of water until three liters remain, and divide into three doses to induce a light sweat.[261p]

　　又方：不中水猪肪，煎取一升，内葱白一握，煎令黄，出内盆中。平旦空腹服讫，暖覆，卧至晡时，食白粥，粥不得稀，过三日服补药。方用羊肝一具，羊脊膂肉一条，曲末半斤，枸杞根十斤，以水三斗，煮枸杞取一斗，去滓，细切肝等内汁中煮，着葱豉盐如羹法合煎，看如稠糖，即好食之，七日。禁如药法。　　传尸伏尸皆有虫，令病人仰手掌，以帛覆其上，烧乳香熏其手背良久，手背上出毛长寸许，白而黄者可治，红者稍难，青黑者即死，最验。若熏良久无毛者，即非此证，属劳瘵虚损，宜用参芪温补之药。【《纲目》，下同】[262p]

Another prescription: If the water pig fat is not suitable, take one sheng, and add a handful of green onion whites. Fry until yellow, then pour into a basin. On an empty stomach at dawn, consume it entirely, keep warm, and lie down until evening. Eat white porridge, which should not be too thin, and after three days, take the restorative medicine. The ingredients include one whole sheep’s liver, one strip of sheep’s back meat, half a jin of fermented flour, and ten jins of goji root. Use three dou of water, boil the goji until one dou is left, strain it, finely chop the liver and boil it in the juice, adding green onions, fermented soybeans, and salt as for a soup. When it thickens like syrup, it is ready to eat; continue this for seven days. Follow the medicinal regimen strictly.

For both the corpse and the lying body which have worms, have the patient lay back with their palms open, cover them with a cloth, and burn incense to fumigate the back of their hands for a long time. If hair about an inch long grows on the back of the hand, white and yellow means it can be treated; red is somewhat difficult, and greenish-black indicates imminent death, this is most reliable. If after prolonged fumigation there is no hair, it is not this condition, but related to labor, tuberculosis, or deficiency; it is advisable to use ginseng and astragalus warming restorative medicines.[262p]

　　尸疰鬼疰：用桃仁五十枚研，以水煮取四升，作一服尽，当吐。如病不尽，二三日再服。
　　　　针灸

　　《素问》曰：肝虚，则目(目巟)(目巟)无所见，耳无所闻，善恐，如人将捕之，取其经厥阴与少阳。气逆，则头痛耳聋不聪，颊肿，取血者。　　心虚，则胸腹大，胁下与腰相引而痛，取其经少阴太阳舌下血者。其变病，刺郄中血者。　　脾虚则腹满肠鸣飧泄，食不化，取其经太阴阳明少阴血者。　　肺虚则少气不能报息，耳聋嗌干，取其经太阴足太阳之外厥阴内血者。　　肾虚则胸中痛，大腹小腹痛，清厥，意不乐，取其经少阴太阳血者。　　《灵枢经》曰：三焦并太阳之正，入络膀胱，约下焦，实则闭癃，虚则遗溺。遗溺则补之，闭癃则泻之。　　形气不足，病气有余，是邪胜也，急泻之。形气有余，病气不足，急补之。[263p]

Corpse hauntings: Use fifty peach kernels, grind them, and boil with water to extract four liters; take it all at once and expect to vomit. If the illness does not resolve, take again in two or three days.

Needling and heat therapy

The "Suwen" states: If the liver is deficient, the eyes cannot see, the ears cannot hear, and there is constant fear, as if one is being pursued; address the channels of the jueyin and shaoyang. If qi is rebellious, then there will be headaches and deafness, swelling of the cheeks; draw blood. If the heart is deficient, the chest and abdomen will swell, there will be pain between the ribs and the waist; draw blood from the channels of shaoyin and taiyang under the tongue. In case of transformation of illness, puncture the blood at the xie point. If the spleen is deficient, there will be fullness in the abdomen, rumbling intestines, and diarrhea; food will not digest, draw blood from the channels of taiyin, yangming, and shaoyin. If the lung is deficient, one will have shortness of breath, cannot exhale properly, have deafness and dry throat; draw blood from the channels of taiyin, foot taiyang, and inner jueyin. If the kidney is deficient, there will be pain in the chest, pain in the large and small abdomen, clear pale urination, a lack of happiness; draw blood from the channels of shaoyin and taiyang. The "Lingshu" states: The sanjiao parallels the proper path of the taiyang, enters the bladder, and joins the lower jiao; if it is full, it causes urinary retention, if it is empty, it leads to incontinence. For incontinence, tonify it; for urinary retention, drain it. When the form and qi are insufficient and the pathogenic qi is excessive, then the evil prevails, so drain it urgently. When the form and qi are plentiful and the pathogenic qi is insufficient, then urgently tonify it.[263p]

形气不足，病气不足，此阴阳俱不足也，不可刺之。刺之则重不足，重不足则阴阳俱竭，血气皆尽，五脏空虚，筋骨髓枯，老者绝灭，壮者不复矣。邪之所在，皆为不足，故上气不足，脑为之不满，耳为之苦鸣，头为之苦倾，目为之眩；中气不足，溲便为之变，肠为之苦鸣；下气不足，则乃为痿厥心悗，补足外踝下留之。　　下虚则厥，上虚则眩。虚者引而留之。　　刺有五夺：形肉已夺，是一夺也；大夺血之后，是二夺也；大汗出之后，是三夺也；大泄之后，是四夺也；薪产及大血之后，是五夺也。此皆不可泻。　　《千金方》曰：左手关上阴绝者，无肝脉也。若癃遗溺难言，胁下有邪气，善吐，刺足少阳治阳。　　肝虚目不明，灸肝腧二百壮。[264p]

When the forms and vital energy are insufficient, and the pathogenic energy is also inadequate, both yin and yang are lacking, and it is inadvisable to perform acupuncture. If one were to needle at this point, it would worsen the insufficiency. If the insufficiency worsens, both yin and yang would deplete, leading to a complete exhaustion of blood and energy, leaving the five organs empty and the muscles, bones, and marrow withered. The elderly would face obliteration, and the young would not recover.

Wherever there is disease, there is insufficiency. Hence, if the upper energy is insufficient, the brain is not nourished, resulting in symptoms like tinnitus, headaches, or dizziness. If the middle energy is insufficient, it leads to changes in urination and defecation, and the intestines may produce sounds. If the lower energy is insufficient, it leads to conditions such as weakness, numbness, and heart disorder, requiring supplementation of the exterior and support below the ankles.

When there is deficiency below, there is numbness; when there is deficiency above, there is dizziness. The deficient areas require support and nourishment.

There are five depletions related to acupuncture: the depletion of form and flesh is the first; the depletion of blood after heavy loss is the second; after excessive sweating, it’s the third; after severe diarrhea, it’s the fourth; and after childbirth and great bleeding, it’s the fifth. All these should not be purged.

The "Thousand Gold Prescriptions" states: if the left hand's pulse at the guan (the gate) is weak and the liver meridian is absent, there may be difficulties in urination and defecation, with evil qi beneath the ribs. It’s beneficial to vomit and needle the foot’s shaoyang to treat the yang.

With liver deficiency, if vision is unclear, moxibustion of the liver points should be applied vigorously, two hundred times.[264p]

　　左手关上阳绝者，无胆脉也。若膝疼，口中苦，眯目善畏，如见鬼，多惊少力，刺足厥阴治阴。在足大指间，或刺三毛中。　　胆虚，灸三阴交各二十壮，穴在内踝上一尺。　　左手关前寸口阴绝者，无心脉也。若心下热痛，掌中热，时时善呕，口中伤烂，刺手少阳治阳。　　左手关前寸口阳绝者，无小肠脉也。若脐痹，小腹中有疝瘕，王月即冷上抢心，刺手心主治阴。心主在掌后横文中入一分。　　右手关上阴绝者，无脾脉也。若少气下利，腹满身重，四肢不欲动，善呕，刺足阳明治阳。　　右手关上阳绝者，无胃脉也。若吞酸头痛，胃中有冷，刺足太阴治阴。在足大指本节后一寸。　　右手关前寸口阴绝者，无肺脉也。若短气咳逆，喉中塞噫逆，刺手阳明治阳。　　肺风气痿绝，四肢满胀，喘逆胸满，灸肺腧各二壮。[265p]

If the left hand's vessel closes the yang and is devoid of the gallbladder pulse, there is no courage pulse. If there is knee pain, a bitter mouth, squinting eyes with fear as if seeing a ghost, often startled with little strength, needle the foot's Jueyin to treat the yin. Insert the needle between the big toe or at the third toe.

If gallbladder deficiency, moxibustion on the Sanyin Jiao point at twenty times each, located one foot above the inner ankle.

If the left hand's vessel closes the inch pulse on the front and lacks the heart pulse, there is no heart pulse. If there is heat pain below the heart, heat in the palm, frequent nausea, and ulcers in the mouth, needle the hand's Shaoyang to treat the yang.

If the left hand's vessel closes the inch pulse on the front and lacks the small intestine pulse, there is no small intestine pulse. If there is umbilical obstruction, hernia in the lower abdomen, and cold radiating upward, needle the hand's heart ruler to treat the yin. The heart ruler is located in the horizontal line of the palm, one division in.

If the right hand's vessel closes the yin and lacks the spleen pulse, there is no spleen pulse. If there is shortness of breath with diarrhea, fullness in the abdomen, heaviness in the body, limbs unwilling to move, and frequent nausea, needle the foot's Yangming to treat the yang.

If the right hand's vessel closes the yang and lacks the stomach pulse, there is no stomach pulse. If there is sourness upon swallowing with headache, and cold in the stomach, needle the foot's Taiyin to treat the yin, located one inch behind the big toe joint.

If the right hand's vessel closes the inch pulse on the front and lacks the lung pulse, there is no lung pulse. If there is shortness of breath, reverse coughing, and sensation of obstruction in the throat, needle the hand's Yangming to treat the yang.

If there is wind-qi asthma and fullness of the limbs, with wheezing and fullness in the chest, moxibustion on the lung point at two times each.[265p]

肺腧对乳，引绳度之，在第三椎下两旁，相去各一寸五分。　　右手关前寸口阳绝者，无大肠脉也。若少气，心下有水气，立秋节即咳，刺手太阴治阴。在鱼际间。　　左手关后尺中阴绝者，无肾脉也。若足下热，两髀里急，精气竭少，劳倦所致，刺足太阳治阳。　　右手关后尺中阴绝者，无肾脉也。若足逆冷，上抢胸痛，梦入水，见鬼善魇寐，黑色物来掩人上，刺足太阳治阳。　　肾气虚寒，灸肾腧百壮。对脐两边，向后侠脊相去各一寸五分。　　左手关后尺中阳绝者，无膀胱脉也。病若逆冷，妇人月水不调，王月则闭，男子失精，尿有余沥，刺足少阴经治阴。在足内踝下动脉是也。　　右手关后尺中阳绝者，无子户脉也。病若足逆寒绝产带下无子，阴中寒，刺足少阴经治阴。　　膏肓腧无所不治，主羸瘦虚损，梦中失精，上气咳逆，狂惑忘误。[266p]

The point on the lung is positioned beneath the third vertebra, one and a half inches away on each side. The yang-absolute point at the right wrist's front does not correspond to the large intestine meridian. If there is shortness of breath and water Qì beneath the heart, a cough will occur at the beginning of autumn; needle the Taiyin point on the hand located between the thenar and hypothenar eminence.

The point on the left wrist's back in the middle lacks the kidney meridian. If there is heat in the feet and urgency in the inner thighs, along with depletion of essence and energy from overwork, needle the foot’s Taiyang point to treat the yang.

The point on the right wrist's back in the middle also lacks the kidney meridian. If there is coldness in the feet, causing chest pain and nightmares of falling into water or being haunted by dark entities, needle the foot’s Taiyang point to treat the yang.

When kidney qi is deficient and cold, moxibustion should be applied to the kidney point in the lower back, positioned one and a half inches to either side of the navel and directed backward alongside the spine.

The left wrist's back middle point that lacks the bladder meridian is crucial. In cases of coldness, if a woman has irregular menstruation or a complete loss during her monthly cycle, or if a man experiences sperm loss and excessive urinary dribbling, needle the foot’s Shaoyin channel to treat the yin, which is located below the inner ankle artery.

The point on the right wrist's back middle lacks the meridian serving the uterus. If symptoms are those of extreme cold in the feet leading to complications such as absence of childbirth or leukorrhea, with internal coldness, needle the foot’s Shaoyin channel to treat the yin.

The Gāohuāng point treats all ailments, particularly weakness, deficiencies, loss of essence in dreams, upward counterflow of breath with coughs, and mental disturbances leading to forgetfulness or confusion.[266p]

取穴法：令人正坐曲脊，伸两手，以臂着膝前，令正直，手大指与膝头齐，以物支肘，物令臂得动摇，从胛骨上角，摸索至胛骨下头，其间当有四肋三间，灸中间；依胛骨之里肋间空，去胛骨容侧指许，摩骨肉之表，肋间空处，按之自觉牵引胸户中，灸两胛中各一处，至六百壮，多至千壮，当觉气下砻砻然如流水状，亦当有所下出。若无停痰宿疾，则无所下也。若病人已困，不能正坐，当令侧卧，挽上臂令前，求取穴灸之也。求穴大较，以右手从右[右：原作「左」，据《千金》卷三十针灸下改。]肩上，拄指头表所不及者是也。左手亦然。乃以前法灸之。若不能久正坐，当伸两臂者，亦可伏衣幞上，伸两臂，令人挽两胛骨使相离，不尔，胛骨覆穴，不可得也。所伏衣幞，当令大小常定，不尔，则失其穴也。此灸讫后，令人阳气康盛。当消息以自补养，取身体平复。其穴近第五椎，相准望取之。[267p]

Method of Locating Acupoints: The individual should sit upright with a curved spine, extending both arms, resting the elbows on the knees to maintain an upright posture. The thumbs should align with the knees. Using an object to support the elbows allows the arms to move. Starting from the upper corner of the shoulder blade, feel down to the bottom of the shoulder blade; in between, there should be four ribs with three gaps—apply moxibustion in the middle. Inside the shoulder blade, where the ribs are empty, about a finger’s breadth away from the shoulder blade, rub the surface of the bones and flesh in the empty spaces between the ribs. Pressing here should create a sensation of pulling within the chest. Apply moxibustion at each point between the shoulder blades, either up to six hundred or as much as one thousand times. One should feel energy flowing downward in a continuous manner akin to running water, and there should be some discharge. If there’s no accumulation of phlegm or chronic disease, there will be nothing to discharge. If the patient is too exhausted to sit upright, they should lie on their side, with the upper arm drawn forward, to locate and apply moxibustion at the acupoints. To locate the acupoints, use the right hand to measure from the right shoulder to the extent just beyond where the fingers can reach. The left hand will do the same. Then apply moxibustion as previously mentioned. If unable to sit upright for a long time, they can extend both arms while lying down on a cloth. Ensure the two shoulder blades are pulled apart; otherwise, the shoulder blades will cover the acupoints, making them inaccessible. The cloth used should be a consistent size; otherwise, the points will be lost. After finishing the moxibustion, the individual should feel an increase in yang energy. It’s important to take care of oneself to restore the body's balance. The acupoint is near the fifth vertebra, so align accordingly to locate it.[267p]

　　《济生方》曰：崔丞相灸劳法，《外台秘要》崔相家传方，及王宝臣经验方，悉编载，然皆差误。毗陵郡有石刻最详，予取诸本参校成此一书，比古方极为委曲，依此治人，未尝不验，往往一灸而愈。予在宜城久病虚羸，亦用此而愈。取穴法：先两穴。令患人平身正立，取一细绳蜡之，勿令展缩，顺脚底贴肉坚踏之，男左女右，其绳前头与大拇指端齐，后头令当脚根中心，向后引绳，循脚肚贴肉，直上至曲(月秋)中大横纹截断；又令患人解发分两边，令见头缝，自顖门平分至脑后，乃平身正坐，取向所截一头，令与鼻端齐，引绳向上，正循头缝至脑后贴肉垂下，循脊骨引绳向下至绳尽处，当脊骨以墨点记之【墨点不是灸处。[268p]

The "Jisheng Fang" states: The acupuncture method for labor by Prime Minister Cui, as recorded in the "Wai Tai Mi Yao," along with formulas passed down in the Cui family and those from Wang Baochen's experience, are all compiled here, yet they contain errors. In Piling County, there are stone carvings that are most detailed; I have taken various texts and cross-referenced them to create this book, which, compared to ancient methods, is very precise. Following this method to treat people, I have never found it to be ineffective; often, one treatment leads to recovery. I myself suffered from a long illness and weakness in Yicheng, and I also used this method to recover.

Method for locating acupuncture points: First, identify two points. Have the patient stand upright and level. Take a fine string made of wax and ensure it does not stretch or compress. Place it against the firm, muscular part of the foot, with men on the left and women on the right. The front end of the string should align with the tip of the big toe, and the back end should be at the center of the heel. Pull the string back, following the shape of the calf muscle, all the way up to where it meets the horizontal line across the middle of the knee joint. Then, have the patient part their hair to both sides to expose the scalp seam. From the hairline, divide it equally to the back of the head, and then have them sit straight. For the end of the string that you previously cut, align it with the tip of the nose, and pull the string upward, following the seam of the scalp down to the back of the head, then following the spine, guide the string down until its end. Mark the vertebrae with an ink dot (the ink dot is not the acupuncture point).[268p]

】 又取一绳子，令患人合口，将绳子按于口上，两头至吻；却勾起绳子中心，至鼻柱根下如△，此便齐两吻截断；将此绳展令直，于前来脊骨上墨点处，横量取平，勿令高下；绳子先中折，当中以墨记之；却展开绳子横量，以绳子上墨点，正压脊骨上墨点为正，两头取平，勿令高下，于绳子两头以白圈记，白圈是灸穴。　　以上是第一次点二穴。
　　次二穴，令其人平身正坐，稍缩臂膊，取一绳绕项，向前双垂与鸠尾齐。鸠尾是心岐骨，人有无心岐骨者，至双胸前两岐骨下量取一寸，即是鸠尾也。即双截断，却背翻绳头向项后，以绳子中停取心，正令当喉咙结骨上，其绳两头夹项双垂，循脊骨以墨点记之。【墨点不是灸处。】 又取一绳子，令其人合口横量，齐两吻截断，还于脊骨上，以墨点横量如法，绳子两头以白圈记之，白圈处是灸穴。　　以上是第二次点穴。通前共四穴。同时灸，日别各七壮至二七壮。累灸至一百壮，或一百五十壮为妙。[269p]

Take another rope, instruct the patient to close their mouth, place the rope over the mouth, bringing both ends to the lips; then lift the center of the rope to the root of the nose, forming a triangle, which will ensure both lips are evenly marked. Extend the rope straight, and at the ink mark on the spine, measure horizontally to ensure it is level, without raising or lowering. The rope is folded in half and marked with ink in the center; then lay the rope out flat and align the ink mark on the rope with the ink spot on the spine as a reference point, ensuring both ends are even. Mark the two ends of the rope with white circles, indicating the acupuncture points. This is the first session of acupuncture at two points.

For the second set of points, have the person sit upright, slightly retracting their arms. Take a rope and loop it around their neck, letting it hang down to align with the tailbone. The tailbone is at the heart's acromion; for those without an acromion, measure one inch below the two acromion bones at the chest, which will be the tailbone. Make a straight cut and flip the ends of the rope backward towards the neck, positioning the center to align with the heart, directly over the knot at the throat. The ends of the rope hang down alongside the neck, following the spine to mark it with ink. [The ink mark is not for acupuncture.] Take another rope, instruct the patient to close their mouth and measure horizontally to align with the lips, then return to the spine and measure as before with the ink marks. Mark the two ends of the rope with white circles, indicating the acupuncture points. This constitutes the second session. In total, there are four points. Apply moxibustion simultaneously, seven times each day until twenty-seven times. Accumulate moxibustion to one hundred or one hundred fifty times for optimal results.[269p]

候疮欲差，又依后法灸二穴。　　又次二穴：以第二次量口吻绳子，于第二次双绳头尽处墨点上，当脊骨直上下竖点，令绳中停中心在墨点上，于上下绳尽头，以白圈两穴，白圈是灸穴。　　以上是第三次点两穴，谓之四花。灸两穴各百壮。三次共六穴，各取离日量度讫，即下火，惟须三月三日艾最佳。疾差，百日内慎饮食房室，安心静处将息。若一月后觉未差，复初穴上再灸。　　《丹溪心法》曰：大病虚脱，本是阴虚。用艾灸丹田者，所以补阳，阳生则阴长故也。　　《医学纲目》曰：体热劳嗽，取魄户泻之。　　五劳羸瘦，取足三里。
　　骨蒸，热不可治者，或前板齿干燥，取大椎。　　又法：鸠尾灸二七壮，补之。[270p]

When the sore is about to improve, apply moxibustion to two points according to the previous method. For the second set of two points: measure a string to mark the second section, and at the end of the double string, place an ink dot directly above the spine. Ensure that the center of the string is aligned with the ink dot, and at both ends of the string, use white circles to mark the two moxibustion points. The points above are referred to as the "four flowers" from the third application, with each of the two points receiving a hundred moxa each. In total, there are six points after three applications, measured according to the distance from the sun, after which you apply heat. Ideally, the best time is on the third day of the third month.

If the condition improves, be cautious with diet and lifestyle for a hundred days, maintaining a calm and restful environment. If after a month you feel no improvement, reapply moxibustion to the initial points.

The "Danxi Heart Method" states that a severe illness causing depletion is fundamentally due to yin deficiency. Moxibustion at the lower abdomen is intended to replenish yang, as the rise of yang allows for the growth of yin.

The "Medical Compendium" states that if the body feels heat and exhaustion, one should draw it out through the "Po Gate." For five types of exhaustion leading to emaciation, target the "Zusanli" point.

If there are bone steaming symptoms or heat that cannot be treated, or if there is dryness in the front jaw, target the "Dazhui" point.

Another method: apply moxibustion to the "Jiuwei" point with two sets of seven applications as a supplement.[270p]

　　传尸劳，取涌泉。于第二足指端，量至跟尽折中是穴，针三分，泻六吸。伤寒及劳瘵之证，有血可治，无血必危。凡欲出血，刺入二分，便须弹指。又丰隆治痰，针入一寸，泻十吸。又丹田治气喘，针入三分，补二呼。　　《医学入门》曰：方书云，虚损劳瘵，只宜早灸膏肓穴，此乃虚损未成之际。如瘦弱兼火，亦只宜灸内关、三里以散其痰火。早年欲作阴火，不宜灸。
　　　　导引

　　《道藏经》曰：每庚申夜不睡，守至晓，尸虫不能为害。三守庚申，三尸长绝。每夜叩齿三十六通，左手捧心，呼三尸名。上尸彭琚出，中尸彭瓆出，下尸彭(王乔)出，令不得为害。常以庚申去手甲，丑日去足甲。七月十六日，将所去手足甲烧灰，水和服之，三尸九虫皆灭。　　《古今医统》曰：灭三尸九虫导引法，以两手着头相叉，长气即吐之；坐地缓舒两脚，以两手外抱脚中，疾低头入膝中，两手交叉头上十三通，愈三虫也。[271p]

Transmitting the corpse labor, taking from the spring. At the tip of the second toe, measure to the heel and fold it to find the acupoint, needle three-tenths deep, drain six times and absorb once. For symptoms of cold damage and labor consumption, if there is blood it can be treated, without blood it is dangerous. If you wish to draw blood, pierce two-tenths deep, then must snap your fingers. Additionally, for treating phlegm at Fenglong, insert the needle one inch deep, drain ten times and absorb once. For treating asthma at the Dantian, insert the needle three-tenths deep, supplement with two breaths. The "Medical Primer" states: The formulas say for virtual damage and labor consumption, one should promptly moxibust the Huangkong point; this is during the stage of virtual damage not yet established. If one is weak with heat, it is best to moxibust Neiguan and Sanli to disperse the phlegm heat. In the early years, if one wants to treat Yin fire, do not moxibust.

Guiding and stretching

The "Daoist Scriptures" say: Every Gengshen night, stay awake until dawn, the corpse insects cannot do harm. Guarding through three Gengshen nights, the three corpses will be completely severed. Every night knock your teeth thirty-six times, hold your heart with your left hand, and call out the names of the three corpses. The upper corpse Pengju comes out, the middle corpse Pengci comes out, the lower corpse Peng (Wangqiao) comes out, to prevent them from doing harm. Always on Gengshen remove your hand nails, and on Chou day remove your foot nails. On the sixteenth day of the seventh month, burn the removed hand and foot nails to ashes, mix with water and consume it, and the three corpses and nine insects will all be exterminated. The "Ancient and Modern Medical Compilation" states: The method for exterminating the three corpses and nine insects through guiding involves crossing your hands on your head, exhaling deeply; sitting and relaxing both legs, with both hands embracing the middle of the feet, then quickly bow your head into your knees, crossing your hands on your head thirty times will cure the three insects.[271p]

　　又法：叩齿二七通，取咽气二七，如三百通乃止。为之二十日，邪气并退；六十日病小愈；百日大病除。三尸伏虫去，肌肤光泽。　　《保生秘要》曰：痨者劳也，感于本来不足，兼之后天常耗，七情伤重，色欲越度，精亏气竭，肾中藏火，心君驰荡，火上干肺，肺窍不清，真水不溉，津液炙干，而为痰嗽呕血盗汗，午后骨蒸，上盛下虚，皮焦面白，四肢无力，小水短濇。或元精不固，遗漏为害；或外肾藏缩，浮气为喘。皆虚怯之证，急早行功，免至危险。
　　导引法：掌心无事，任擦搓，早晚摩两胁、肾腧、耳根、涌泉百四十回，固精多效。朝服人乳酒，饮清洁童便，或服循环水，用姜枣以暖脾宫，或用秋石化盐，取其滋阴降火。若虚损不能服参者，宜依方进气取效。虽至危漏底诸药难治者，用好脐带数条，炙燥为末，每服二钱，好酒量意调服，神验也。戒恼怒，绝思欲，忘言守静。若能踵息，起死还生。[272p]

Another method: Knock the teeth fourteen times, take a breath at the throat fourteen times, stopping after three hundred repetitions. Practice this for twenty days, and the evil qi will recede; after sixty days, minor ailments will improve; after one hundred days, major illnesses will be eliminated. The three corpses and hidden worms will diminish, and the skin will glow.

The "Essentials of Preserving Life" states: Tuberculosis is due to fatigue, arising from an innate deficiency combined with constant depletion from external factors. The seven emotions are strongly affected, desires exceed limits, essence is depleted and qi is exhausted, fire is stored in the kidney, the heart is disturbed, fire dries the lungs, the lung orifices are unclear, true water does not nourish, and body fluids become scorched, leading to phlegm, cough, bloody vomit, and night sweats. In the afternoon, there is bone steaming, with excess upward and deficiency downward, skin burns and the face turns pale, limbs are weak, and urination is scant and painful. It could be due to the essence not being secured, resulting in harm; or external kidney contraction causing floating qi, leading to wheezing. All these are signs of deficiency and fear; immediate action must be taken to avoid danger.

Guiding method: With palms open and relaxed, casually rub and friction, morning and evening massage both sides of the ribs, kidney points, ear roots, and Yongquan point one hundred forty times for better retention of essence and multiple effects. In the morning, consume human milk wine, drink clean infant urine, or take circulating water, using ginger and jujubes to warm the spleen. Alternatively, use autumn stone salt to nourish yin and reduce fire. If one is too deficient to take ginseng, it is advisable to follow this method to obtain qi and effect. Even for extremely difficult-to-treat conditions, using a few strips of good umbilical cord, dried to a powder, taking two qian with good wine to adjust, proves effective. Avoid anger, eliminate desires, forget words, and maintain quietude. If one can follow their breath, they might revive from death.[272p]

　　运功，一指归元，三提三咽，念四字咒于分寸，虚虚抱守，妄念返复，持一死字，世事尽归于空。抱守二七，痰涎稍清，运动周天，借督脉，按四时进退，有神功。　　呕红：起念艮，背运行庭归元，合用百日功夫，勿使间断，骨蒸盗汗痰嗽尽愈。　　先顾本源念，复用火烧虫，其虫自不能容，或从口中飞出，人可避之。　　弱病：先于背上念，又向两乳下推开两旁，转至两肾，复上转至头，又下至脐。其沉重者，先脐上念，又升肾水上至顶门，滴下心头，归脐。先念背，顾本源。若身潮热者，或升涌泉，或升肾水，遍身周流，其热自退。[273p]

Cultivate energy, focus the mind on returning to the origin, perform the Three Raises and Three Swallows, chant the four-character mantra with precision. Maintain a state of emptiness and hold onto it, dispelling wandering thoughts repeatedly. Focus on a single 'death' character, and all worldly matters will return to emptiness. By embracing the principles of simplicity, phlegm and saliva will gradually clear, moving through the channels, utilizing the Governing Vessel, adjusting according to the seasons, there will be divine power.

For red vomit: Initiate thought with stalwartness, backtrack to the origin, combine efforts for a hundred days without interruption, and essence, sweat, phlegm, and cough will be entirely healed.

First, focus on the original source; then use fire to burn out worms, which cannot withstand it and may even fly out of the mouth, allowing the person to avoid them.

For weakness and illness: Start by concentrating on the back, then push outward below the two breasts, rotate down to the two kidneys, then up to the head, and again down to the navel. For heaviness, begin by chanting above the navel, then ascend the kidney water up to the crown, dropping down to the heart and returning to the navel. First chant for the back, attending to the original source. If the body feels hot, it may either ascend to the bubbling spring or rise with kidney water, circulating throughout the body until the heat dissipates.[273p]

　　　　医案

　　《儒门事亲》曰：西华束茂之病虚劳寝汗，面有青黄色，自膝以下，冷痛无汗，腹中燥热，医以姜附补之，五晦朔不令饮水，又禁梳头，作寒治之，请于戴人。戴人曰：子之病不难愈，难于将护，恐愈后阴道转茂，子必不慎。束生曰：不敢。戴人先以舟车丸、浚川散，下五七行，心火下降，觉渴，与冰水饮之，又令澡浴，数日间面红而泽。后以河水煮粥，温养脾胃。河水能利小溲。又以活血当归丸、人参柴胡散、五苓散、木香白朮散调之，病大瘥，寝汗皆止，两足日暖，食进。戴人常曰：此本肺痹，当以凉剂。盖水之一物，在目为泪，在皮为汗，在下为小溲。谷多水少为常，无水可乎？若禁饮水必内竭，内竭则燥热生焉。人若不渴，与水亦不肯饮之矣。束生既愈，果忘其戒，病复作。戴人已去，乃殂。[274p]

Medical Case Report

"The Confucian Teachings on Filial Piety" states: The case of Xu Hua Shumo suffered from virtual weakness and excessive sweating during sleep, with a bluish-yellow complexion, cold pain below the knees, and no sweating, alongside a dry heat in the abdomen. The doctor used ginger and other warming herbs to treat him, forbidding him from drinking water for five days and nights, and also prohibited him from combing his hair, treating him for cold symptoms, according to the practices advised by Dai Ren. Dai Ren said: "Your illness is not difficult to cure, but it is challenging to manage afterward. I fear that once you recover, you will neglect proper care and your condition will return." Xu Sheng replied: "I dare not."

Dai Ren first administered pills and herbal mixtures to move the intestines, then allowed him to drink ice water to quench his thirst after the heart's heat was reduced. Dai Ren also recommended bathing, and within a few days, Xu Sheng’s complexion brightened and became moist. Then, he made porridge with river water to nourish the spleen and stomach, as river water can assist in urination. He combined this with herbal formulations like blood-activating Angelica pills, ginseng and Bupleurum powder, Wuling powder, and wood fragrance and white atractylodes powder. The illness substantially improved; sweating during sleep stopped, his feet felt warm daily, and he regained appetite. Dai Ren often said: "This is fundamentally a lung obstruction, and should be treated with cooling remedies." He mentioned that water manifests as tears in the eyes, sweat on the skin, and urine below. Normally, grains are abundant while water is scarce; is it possible to completely avoid water? If drinking is forbidden, it will lead to inner depletion, which gives rise to dry heat. When a person is not thirsty, they also will not drink water. After Xu Sheng recovered, he indeed forgot the restrictions, and the illness recurred. Dai Ren had already left, and he subsequently passed away.[274p]

　　《薛己医案》曰：州同韩用之色欲过度，烦热作渴，饮水不绝，小便淋沥，大便秘结，唾痰如涌，面目俱赤，满舌生刺，两唇燥裂，遍身发热，或身如芒刺而无定处，两足心如烙，左三部脉洪而无伦，此肾阴虚，阳无所附而发于外。盖大热而甚，寒之不寒，是无水也，当峻补其阴。遂以加减八味丸料一斤，内肉桂一两，以水顿煎六碗，冰冷与饮，半晌熟睡，至晚又温饮一碗，诸证悉退。翊日，畏寒，足冷至膝，诸证仍至，是无火也，当补其阳。急以八味丸四剂，诸证顿退。[275p]

The Medical Case of Xue Ji states: A county official, Han Yongzhi, experienced excessive lust, restlessness leading to thirst, continuous drinking of water, frequent urination with dribbling, constipation, expectoration as if it were surging, a flushed face, a tongue full of prickles, cracked and dry lips, a scorching body, sometimes feeling as if there were prickles with an unstable sensation, and feet so hot as if burned. The pulse in the left three positions was rapid and chaotic; this indicated a deficiency of kidney yin, with yang not being anchored, manifesting outwardly. Due to excessive heat and a lack of cooling, it was determined there was no water, and thus, the yin needed to be vigorously replenished. Therefore, a prescription of modified Eight Flavor Pill was prepared with an ounce of cinnamon; it was decocted in water into six bowls, cooled and given to drink. He slept soundly for half the day, and by evening, he drank another warm bowl, which led to the complete alleviation of all symptoms. The next day, however, he felt chilled, his feet were cold up to his knees, and the symptoms returned, indicating a lack of fire; thus, yang needed to be replenished. Urgently, four doses of Eight Flavor Pill were administered, and all symptoms promptly receded.[275p]

　　举人陈履贤色欲过度，孟冬发热无时，饮水不绝，痰涎上涌，遗精不止，小便淋沥，或用四物、二陈之类，胸膈不利，饮食少思，大便不实，余朝用四君子汤加熟地、当归，夕用加减八味丸，更以附子，唾津调搽涌泉穴，渐愈。
　　府庠王以道元气素弱，丙午丁未二年，以科场岁考，积劳致疾，至十二月间，其病盛作，大热，泪出随凝，目赤面黯，扬手露胸，气息沉沉几绝，脉洪大鼓指，按之如无，舌干扪之如刺，此内真寒而外假热也，遂先服十全大补汤。余曰：既服此汤，其脉当收敛为善。少顷熟睡，觉而恶寒增衣，脉顿微细如丝，此虚寒之真象也，余以人参一两，加熟附三钱，水煎顿服而安。夜间脉复脱，余以参二两，熟附五钱仍愈。后以大剂参、朮、归身、炙甘草等药，调理而安。[276p]

Scholar Chen Luxian had excessive lust. In early winter, he experienced persistent fever, constant thirst, a buildup of phlegm, continuous seminal emissions, and frequent, aching urination. He tried remedies such as Siwu and Erchen, but his chest felt oppressed, his appetite was poor, and his bowel movements were unsatisfactory. In the morning, I prescribed Si Jun Zi Decoction with added cooked Rehmannia and Angelica; in the evening, I prescribed modified Ba Wei Pills, along with Aconite. I also used saliva to externally apply to the Yongquan point, and he gradually improved.

Minister Wang had weak vital energy. In the years Bingwu and Dingwei, due to the stress of examination season, he became ill from exhaustion. By December, his illness intensified; he experienced high fever, profuse tears, red eyes, dark complexion, shortness of breath suggesting near collapse, and a markedly strong pulse that felt hollow. His tongue was dry and seemed prickly; this indicated true cold internally and false heat externally. Therefore, he first took the Ten Vitality Decoction. I said: "Since you have taken this, your pulse should become more constricted and favorable." After a brief deep sleep, he awoke feeling an increase in chills, and his pulse turned faint and thin like silk, revealing the true manifestation of deficiency and cold. I administered an ounce of ginseng, three dimes of cooked Aconite, boiled it in water, and he calmed down. During the night, his pulse became weak again. I prescribed two ounces of ginseng and five dimes of cooked Aconite and he improved once more. Later, through adjusting with larger doses of ginseng, Atractylodes, angelica root, and honey-fried licorice, he stabilized.[276p]

　　《医学正传》曰：金儒元，国子生也，年五十余，身略瘦。十年前得内伤挟外感证，一医用发表疏利之剂，十数日后热虽退而虚未复，胸中痞满，气促眩运，召予治，以补中益气汤，间与东垣消痞丸、陈皮枳朮丸等药，调理而安。但病根未尽除而住药，故眩运或时而举不甚重。及至此年，因往杭城受跋涉辛苦，又兼色欲之过，还家眩运大作，历数医皆与防风、羌活、荆芥、南星、半夏、苍朮等去风散湿消痰之剂，病愈重，一日十数次厥去，片时复苏，凡动或转侧即厥不知人事，举家徨徨叫哭，召予治。[277p]

The "Classic of Medicine" states: Jin Ru Yuan, a student at the National University, was over fifty years old and slightly thin. Ten years ago, he suffered from an internal injury accompanied by external afflictions. A doctor prescribed a purging remedy, and while the fever subsided after several days, his weakness did not recover. He experienced chest fullness, shortness of breath, and dizziness. He called upon me for treatment, and I administered a tonifying middle energizing decoction, periodically giving him Eastern Garden's formula for dissipating fullness, and other herbs like dried tangerine peel and zhu ru, to regulate and stabilize him. However, since the root of the disease was not completely eradicated, the dizziness occasionally recurred, though not severely. This year, due to the tough journey to Hangzhou and excessive desires, his dizziness worsened upon returning home. Several doctors treated him with remedies to dispel wind, dampness, and phlegm, including Fang Feng, Qiang Huo, Jing Jie, Nan Xing, Ban Xia, and Cang Zhu, but his condition deteriorated significantly, with fainting episodes occurring over ten times a day. He would regain consciousness briefly, but any movement or turning would induce fainting, leaving his family in despair and calling out for help. They summoned me for treatment.[277p]

诊其六脉，皆浮洪而濡，予晓之曰：此气血大虚证，幸脉不数而身无大热，不死。但恐病愈后，而有数年不能下榻行动。病者曰：只要有命，卧亦甘心。与大补气血之药，倍人参、黄芪，或加附子引经，合大剂，一日三贴；又煎人参膏及作紫河车丸、补阴丸之类间服。如此调理二月余，服煎药二百余贴，丸药三五料，用人参五六斤，其证渐不厥，饮食如故，但未能行动。越五六年，方得起而步履如初。[278p]

Upon examining the six pulses, they were all floating and rapid. I explained that this indicated a significant deficiency of qi and blood, but fortunately, the pulse was not overly rapid and there was no high fever, indicating that the person would not die. However, I feared that after recovering, they might not be able to rise or move for several years. The patient said: "As long as I have life, I am willing to lie down." I prescribed a strong tonic for qi and blood, doubling the amounts of ginseng and astragalus, and possibly adding aconite to help guide the treatment, combining a large dosage for three applications a day. Additionally, I prepared ginseng extract and made pills similar to Ziheche wan and Biyin wan for intermittent use. After regulating the condition for more than two months, with over two hundred applications of decoction and three to five doses of pills, using five to six jin of ginseng, the symptoms gradually improved, with eating and drinking returning to normal, but the patient was still unable to move. After five to six years, the patient was finally able to rise and walk as before.[278p]

　　东旸邑庠邹掌教发大汗，战栗振掉，片时许发燥热，身如火烧，又片时许出大汗如雨，身体若冰冷而发寒战如前，寒后又热，热后又汗，三病继作而昼夜不息。庠生卢明夫作疟证治，不效。召予，诊其右手阳脉数而浮洪无力，阴脉略沉小而亦虚，左三部比右差小而亦浮软。予曰：此阳虚证也。用补中益气汤倍参、芪，减升、柴一半，加尿浸生附子一钱半，炒黄蘗三分，干姜、薄桂各五分，大枣一枚，同煎服。一服而病去三分，二服而减半，四服寒热止而身尚有微汗。去桂、附、干姜一半，服二贴全愈。[279p]

In Dongyang County, a school headmaster named Zou experienced severe sweating, trembling, and shaking. For a while, he felt hot, as if his body were on fire, followed by heavy sweating, then a cold sensation leading to shivering, cycling between hot and cold with sweating, resulting in three ailments that persisted both day and night. The student Lu Mingfu treated his intermittent fever without success. He called for me, and I diagnosed his right hand’s yang pulse as rapid and floating, yet weak, and the yin pulse as slightly deep and small, also weak. The left side was notably worse than the right but still floating and soft. I said, "This is a case of yang deficiency." I prescribed a modified Bu Zhong Yi Qi Decoction, increasing the amount of ginseng and astragalus, reducing the amount of licorice and ramulus cinnamomi by half, adding one and a half qian of urine-soaked aconite, three fen of fried berberine, five fen each of dried ginger and thin cinnamon, and one jujube, to be cooked together and taken. After one dose, his condition improved by a third; after two doses, it reduced by half; and after four doses, the cold and heat ceased, although there was still slight sweating. I then removed half of the cinnamon, aconite, and dried ginger, and after two more doses, he was fully recovered.[279p]

　　《医宗必读》曰：何邑宰令郎虚损形瘁，遗精盗汗，已濒于危，见余拙刻微论药解脉象诸书，遣使聘余。手书恺切，余感其言遂往。比至而病益进矣。简其所服，以四物、知、蘗为主，芩、连、二冬为加减。诊其脉大而数，按之极软。余曰：中气大寒，反为药苦矣。乃以归脾汤入肉桂一钱、人参五钱，当晚得熟寐，居十日而汗止精藏。更以还少丹，兼进补中益气，间服一月而差。
　　少宗伯顾邻初，丙辰年患发热困倦，目昏耳鸣，脚软不能行，大便燥结，手足麻痹，腰胯疼痛。余诊之曰：肾虚不能上交，心虚不能下济，且尺脉迟软，力勉其用八味丸、十全大补汤，加圆眼三十枚。五十余日，精神渐旺，肌肉渐充，致书鸣感。一日，多饮虎骨酒，大便仍结。医者皆云，八味丸非久服之药，十全大补宜去肉桂，反用知母、元参佐之，服之数月，遂致不起。[280p]

In "Essential Readings of Medical Tradition," it is stated: A county magistrate's son suffered from physical depletion, experiencing seminal loss and sweating at night, approaching danger. He discovered my rudimentary writings on medicines and pulse diagnosis, and sent an envoy to invite me. His letter was heartfelt, and I was moved by his words, so I went to see him. By the time I arrived, his condition had worsened. I reviewed the medicines he was taking, which mainly included the Four Substances, along with Anemarrhena and Ephedra as adjustments. Upon diagnosing his pulse, it was large and rapid, yet extremely soft. I said: “Your central qi is greatly cold, which in turn makes the medicine ineffective.” I then prescribed Gui Pi Decoction with an extra dose of cinnamon and five qian of ginseng, advising that he would sleep soundly that night. After ten days, his sweating ceased, and his seminal loss improved. I further prescribed Shao Yao Dan to supplement his central qi invigorating, and after a month of intermittent use, he began to feel better.

In the year of Bingchen, a young cousin of the Grand Secretary first suffered from fever and fatigue, with blurred vision and tinnitus, legs weak and unable to walk, constipation, numbness in his hands and feet, and pain in his lower back. Upon examining him, I said: “The kidney is deficient and unable to ascend to assist, the heart is also deficient and unable to descend to aid.” His pulse was weak and soft. I recommended the Eight-Treasure Pill and Ten Complements Decoction, adding thirty large dates. After over fifty days, his spirit gradually improved, and his muscles began to fill out, leading him to write to express his gratitude. One day, he consumed a large amount of tiger bone wine, but his constipation persisted. Physicians all stated that the Eight-Treasure Pill was not suitable for long-term use, and that the Ten Complements Decoction should exclude cinnamon, instead using Anemarrhena and Asparagus as substitutes. After taking it for a few months, he ultimately fell into a state from which he could not recover.[280p]

　　南都许轮所孙女吐血痰嗽，六月诊之，两尺如烂绵，两寸大而数。余曰：金以火为仇，肺不浮濇，反得洪大，贼脉见矣，秋令可忧。八月初五复诊之，肺之洪者变为细数，肾之软者变为疾劲。余曰：岁在戊午，少阴司天，两尺不应。今尺当不应而反大，寸当浮大而反沉细。尺寸反者死，肺至悬绝十二日死。计其期，当死于十六日。然能食者过期，况十六、十七二日皆金，未遽绝也。十八日交寒露，又值火日，经曰：手太阴气绝，丙日笃，丁日死，言火日也。寅时乃气血注肺之时，不能注则绝，必死于十八日寅时矣。轮所闻之，澘然泪下。以其能食，犹不肯信。果至十八日未晓而终。[281p]

In the southern capital, Xu Lun's granddaughter coughed up blood and phlegm. In June, I examined her and found her pulse to be two inches like rotten cotton, with several two-inch pulses. I said: "Gold and fire are adversaries; the lungs should not be abundant, yet they are swollen. The rebellious pulse is evident; there is cause for concern in autumn." On the fifth day of the eighth month, I examined her again, and the abundance of the lungs changed to a fine and rapid pulse, while the weakness in the kidneys changed to one that was severe and strong. I said: "In the year of Wu Wu, the Lesser Yin governs the heavens; the two-inch pulse does not correspond. Now, the inch should not respond but is instead large; the cun should be floating and large, yet it is sinking and fine. The reversal of the dimensions indicates death; the lungs reaching suspension mean death within twelve days. Calculating the period indicates she would die on the sixteenth day. However, since she can still eat, she has surpassed that time; moreover, both the sixteenth and seventeenth are days of metal, so death is not immediate. On the eighteenth, it transitions to the chilly dew time, which coincides with a day of fire. The scriptures say: 'When the hand Taiyin's Qi is exhausted, the day of Bing is severe; the day of Ding brings death,' referring to the fire days. The hour of Yin is when Qi and blood flow into the lungs; if they cannot flow, then suspension is certain, and she will surely die at the hour of Yin on the eighteenth." Upon hearing this, Lun wept bitterly. Because she could eat, he still did not want to believe it. Indeed, she passed away before dawn on the eighteenth.[281p]

　　汪望洋之孙，年方舞象，发热咳嗽，羸弱头眩，二冬、二母、知、蘗、芩、连，不啻百剂，病势转增。余诊其右脉虚软，乃知脾肺气虚，火不生土之候也。遂用补中益气加五味子、苡仁、姜、桂至三钱，十剂而减，两月乃安。春初又发，令其服补中丸。一年，诸证永不再作矣。
　　刑部主政唐名必劳心太过，因食海鲜，吐血有痰，喉间如鲠，日晡烦热，喜其六脉不数，惟左寸濇而细，右关大而软，思虑伤心脾也。以归脾汤大料，加丹参、丹皮、麦门冬、生地黄二十余剂而证减六七，兼服六味丸三月，遂不复发。[282p]

The grandson of Wang Wangyang, at the age of dancing elephants, suffered from a fever and cough, was weak with dizziness. After two winters, the treatments with several herbs—Zhi, Bo, Qin, Lian—amounted to countless remedies, yet the illness worsened. Upon examining the right pulse, which was weak and soft, it became evident that there was a deficiency of spleen and lung qi, leading to a condition where fire could not generate earth. Consequently, I used a formula to tonify the center and augment qi, adding Schisandra, Job's tears, ginger, and cinnamon to three qian. After ten doses, the condition improved, and it took two months for him to stabilize. At the beginning of spring, the illness reoccurred, so I instructed him to take the Bao Zhong Wan. After a year, all symptoms never returned.

The head of the Ministry of Justice, named Tang Ming, overexerted himself and as a result suffered from food poisoning from seafood—coughing up blood with phlegm, a feeling of obstruction in the throat, daily evening heat, and finding his six pulses not rapid. The left inch pulse was weak and thin, while the right guan pulse was large and soft, indicating that excessive worry had harmed his heart and spleen. I administered a major prescription of Gui Pi Decoction, adding Salvia, Moutan root, Ophiopogon, and raw Rehmannia, giving him more than twenty doses, after which the symptoms reduced by six or seven. Along with taking Liu Wei Wan for three months, he did not have a recurrence.[282p]

　　吴门周复庵年及五旬，荒于酒色。忽然头痛发热，医以羌活汤散之，汗出不止，昏运不苏。余与之灸关元十壮而醒。四君子加姜桂，日服三剂，至三日，少康。分析家产，劳而且怒。复发厥。余用好参一两，熟附二钱，煨姜十片，煎服稍醒。但一转侧即厥，一日之间，计厥七次，服参三两。至明日，以羊肉羹、糯米粥与之，尚厥二三次。至五日而厥定。向余泣曰：已蒙再生，不知有全愈日否？余曰：脉有根蒂，但元气虚极，非三载调摄，不能康也。幸其恪信余言，遵守用药，两月之间，服参四斤。三年之内，进剂六百贴，丸药七十余斤，方得步履如初。亲友众多，议论杂出，若非病人任之专，或久而见疑，服药少怠，未有获生者也。[283p]

At the age of fifty, Zhou Fuan from Wumen sank into a life of indulgence in wine and pleasures. Suddenly, he suffered from headaches and fever, and the doctor treated him with Qianghuo Decoction, leading to continuous sweating and a state of unconsciousness. I administered moxibustion to the Ren channel, awakening him after ten applications. A formula of the Four Gentlemen, with the addition of ginger and cinnamon, was prescribed three times daily. By the third day, he showed signs of minor recovery, but was still distressed from analyzing his estate, causing fatigue and anger that triggered a relapse.

I used one tael of good ginseng, two qian of cooked aconite, and ten slices of ginger, brewing and administering until he showed slight improvement. However, with any movement, he would go into a fainting spell, experiencing seven such episodes in a single day, consuming a total of three taels of ginseng. The next day, I provided him with lamb broth and glutinous rice porridge, yet he still fainted two or three more times. By the fifth day, the fainting ceased. He cried to me, saying, "I have been granted a second life, but I wonder if there will be a full recovery." I replied, "Your pulse has strength, but your vital energy is extremely deficient; it will require three years of careful nurturing for you to fully recover." Thankfully, he trusted my words and adhered to the treatment plan, using four pounds of ginseng over the course of two months. Within three years, he received six hundred acupuncture treatments and consumed over seventy pounds of medicinal pills, eventually regaining his mobility. With many friends and family discussing his case, had he not relied solely on the physician's directives, or had he delayed in taking his medicine, few would have survived.[283p]

　　侍御冯五玉令爱，发热咳嗽已及半载，十月间吐鲜血甚多，一日之内，不过食粥一盏，大肉消陷，大便溏泄，沉困着床，脉来七至。余曰：法在不救，人所共知，若能唯余是听，不为旁挠，可救十中之一。每贴用人参五钱，桂、附各一钱，芪、朮三钱，归、芍二钱，陈皮一钱，日投三贴，约进七十剂，及壮水丸三斤，而后起于床。又三月而饮食如旧。若泥常法而弃之，幽潜沉寃矣。
　　《古今医统》曰：职方郎中游烈，其子妇年十六得病，浑身壮热，咳嗽痰涎，月候不通，饮食减少，不岁余，众医不救。用天灵盖服之，取下虫一枚，如蜈蚣之状，当时钳入沸油鼎中煎之，投于江，遂瘥。
　　一男子三十余岁，患病厌厌，饮食倍多而不生肌，常需肉食，如或稍饥，腹内疼痛倦怠，遂以天灵盖散服之，取下赤小虫无数，内有一虫，其色微紫，大于众虫，头有细毛。自后用药补治遂安，兼进真苏合香丸。[284p]

The daughter of the attendant Yu Feng Wuyue has been suffering from a fever and cough for nearly half a year. In October, she spat out a significant amount of fresh blood. In one day, she consumed only a bowl of porridge, was unable to digest large meats, had loose stools, and was confined to bed, with a pulse of seven beats. I said: The principle is not to save her, which is widely acknowledged. However, if she can solely listen to me and avoid outside distractions, there is a chance to save one in ten. I prescribed three doses daily, using five qian of ginseng, one qian each of cinnamon and prepared aconite, three qian of astragalus and poria, two qian of rehmannia and peony, and one qian of dried tangerine peel, totaling about seventy doses. After three pounds of medicinal paste were taken, she eventually got out of bed. Three months later, her appetite returned to normal. If one were to discard the established methods, she would surely fall into a deep decline.

The "Ancient and Modern Medical Treatise" states: The doctor Zhang Youlie had a daughter-in-law who, at sixteen, fell ill with a high fever, cough, and phlegm, with no relief for a month. Her appetite decreased, and within a year, many doctors were unable to help. They used the crown of the head for treatment, retrieved a worm that resembled a centipede. At that time, it was placed in boiling oil and then tossed into the river, resulting in her recovery.

A man in his thirties, suffering from persistent ailments, had an increased appetite but could not gain weight. He constantly craved meat, and if he felt the slightest hunger, he experienced abdominal pain and fatigue. Thus, he took the crown of the head powder, which resulted in the expulsion of countless small red worms. Among them was one larger worm, slightly purple in color, with fine hairs on its head. Afterward, he used medicine for nourishment and treatment and also took Zhen Su He Xiang pills.[284p]

　　一男子年五十，每日须酒数升，空心未饮则两手与脚并皆振动，得酒一升饮之少减，若至醉则手足不动，俗谓酒疾医之，名振风，累日针灸服药无效。疑其有虫，遂服天灵盖散，取下一物，如乌梅之状，拨之有足，正类蜘蛛，其疾遂愈，不复饮酒。
　　《寓意草》曰：金道宾之诊，左尺脉和平，右尺脉如控弦如贯索，上冲甚锐。余为之骇曰：是病枝叶未有害，本实先拨，必得之醉而使内也。曰：诚有之。但已绝欲二年，服人参斤许，迄今诸无所苦，惟闭目转眄，则身非己有，恍若离魂者然，不识可治与否？余曰：可治。再四令疏方，未知方中之意。归语门人，因请立案。余曰：凡人佳治当前，贾勇以明得意，又助之以曲糵，五脏翻覆，宗筋纵弛，百脉动摇，以供一时之乐，不知难为继也。[285p]

A man of fifty years required several sheng of wine each day; if he did not drink on an empty stomach, both his hands and feet trembled. When he drank one sheng, this tremor slightly diminished, but if he became drunk, his hands and feet would become immobile. It was commonly said that this condition was a sickness caused by alcohol, known as "tremor wind." After several days of acupuncture and medication with no effect, it was suspected that he had worms. He then took a remedy called “Heaven's Crown Powder,” and expelled an object resembling a black plum, which had legs and was similar to a spider. Following this, his illness was cured, and he no longer drank wine.

In "Yuyi Cao," it was noted: "When Jin Daobin diagnosed, the pulse on the left wrist was balanced, while the right wrist's pulse felt taut like a string under tension. The upward surge was notably sharp." I was astonished and remarked, "This illness has not harmed the branches and leaves; it's actually a matter of being stirred internally due to drunkenness." He said, "It is indeed so. However, I have renounced desires for two years and have taken about a jin of ginseng, and until now, I have suffered no grievances. The only issue is that when I close my eyes and turn my gaze, my body does not feel like my own, as if my soul has departed. I do not know if this can be treated." I replied, "It can be treated." After reiterating the treatment plan several times, the meaning of the prescription remained unclear. Upon returning, I spoke to my disciples and requested that a record be established. I stated, "For ordinary people, the right treatment comes easily, and vigorously indulging in pleasure with them can assist in their enjoyment. However, it causes the internal organs to flip and the sinews to loosen, making the hundred pulses sway, merely to provide transient pleasure, without realizing the difficulty of sustaining it."[285p]

尝有未离女躯，顷刻告殒者矣，是病之有今日者幸也。绝欲二年，此丈夫之行，可收桑榆者。但不知能之不为乎？抑为之不能乎？不为者，一阳时生，斗柄常运；不能者，相安于无事而已。夫人身之阴阳相抱而不脱，是以百年有常，故阳欲上脱，阴下吸之，不能脱也；阴欲下脱，阳上吸之，不能脱也。即病能非一，阴阳时有亢战，旋必两协其平。惟大醉大劳，乱其常度，二气乘之，脱离所争，不必其多，即寸中脱出一分，此一分便孤而无偶，便营魄不能自主。洽法要在寻其罅漏而缄固之，断鳌立极，炼石补天，非饰说也。[286p]

There was a woman who had not yet departed from life, and in an instant she passed away; it is fortunate that such a malady has a day like today. After two years of renunciation of desires, this is the conduct of a true man, and he may harvest what he has sown in the twilight of life. But I wonder, can he do nothing in this regard? Or is it that he cannot do anything? If he does nothing, it is like the sun rising and the Big Dipper turning; if he cannot do anything, he merely finds peace in idleness. The male and female energies of a person's body embrace each other and do not separate, which is why there is constancy in a hundred years. The yang wants to rise and escape, but the yin pulls it down, and it cannot detach; the yin wants to descend and escape, but the yang pulls it up, and it cannot detach either. Indeed, the disease may not be singular; the energies may often combat each other, but they must ultimately harmonize. Only through great drunkenness and extreme labor can their regular balance be disrupted. When the two energies take advantage of this chaos, separation occurs. It does not require much; even a small fraction may escape, resulting in a portion that is solitary and unpaired, leaving the essence unable to govern itself. The key to remedy lies in seeking out the gaps and sealing them securely, cutting off the claws and establishing a firm foundation, refining the stone to mend the sky, and this is not mere embellishment of words.[286p]

若不识病所，而博搜以冀弋获，虽日服人参，徒竭重赀，究鲜实益。盖上脱者，妄见妄闻，有如神灵；下脱者，不见不闻，有如聋瞶。上脱者，身轻快而汗淋漓；下脱者，身重着而肉多青紫。昔有新贵人马上扬扬得意，未及回寓，一笑而逝者，此上脱也。又有人寝而遭魇，身如被杖，九窍出血者，此下脱也。其有上下一时俱脱者，此则暴而又暴，不多经见者。其有左右相畸而脱者，左从上，右从下，魂升魄降同例也。但治分新久，药贵引用。新病者，阴阳相乖，补偏救弊，宜用其偏。[287p]

If one does not recognize the source of the illness but searches broadly in hopes of some gain, even if one daily takes ginseng, it will only deplete one’s wealth without yielding real benefits. Those who are in the upper forms of deficiency may perceive illusions like spirits; those in the lower forms are unseeing and unhearing, akin to being deaf and blind. The upper-deficient feel light and are drenched in sweat, while the lower-deficient feel heavy, with much flesh turning blue and purple.

In the past, there was a newly prominent noble who, riding a horse, was full of pride and joy; before he could return home, he laughed and then perished—this is an example of upper deficiency. Conversely, there are those who sleep and encounter nightmare-like experiences, feeling as if beaten, with blood oozing from the nine orifices—this is an example of lower deficiency.

When both upper and lower deficiencies occur simultaneously, this is a severe and sudden case, rarely seen. If deficiencies are skewed side to side, with the left from above and the right from below, it follows the same principle of the soul rising and the spirit descending. However, the treatment varies based on whether the condition is newly developed or longstanding, and the cost of medication is significant. For acute ailments, where yin and yang are in discord, it is appropriate to use remedies that address the imbalance.[287p]

久病者，阴阳渐入，扶元养正，宜用其平。若久病误以重药投之，转增其竭绝耳。引用之法，上脱者，用七分阳药，三分阴药而夜服，从阴以引其阳；下脱者，用七分阴药，三分阳药而昼服，从阳以引其阴。引之又引，阴阳忽不觉其相抱，虽登高临深无所恐，发表攻里无所伤矣。经云：阴平阳秘，精神乃治，正谓此也。善调者，使坎中之真阳上升，则周身之气，如冬至一阳初生，便葭管飞灰，天地翕然从其阳；使离中之真阴下降，则周身之气，如夏至一阴初生，便葽蜩迭应，天地翕然从其阴。是身中原有大药，岂区区草木所能方其万一者耶？[288p]

For those suffering from long-term illness, the balance of Yin and Yang gradually enters the body. It is essential to support the original vitality and nourish the right, which should be accomplished with gentle remedies. If a prolonged illness is treated with strong medicines, it may only worsen the depletion.

In terms of treatment: for those with upward depletion, use seven parts Yang medicine and three parts Yin medicine taken at night, guiding the Yin to support the Yang; for those with downward depletion, use seven parts Yin medicine and three parts Yang medicine taken during the day, guiding the Yang to support the Yin. By continually guiding and guiding again, Yin and Yang will unconsciously embrace each other. Even when one climbs high or descends deep, there will be no fear; even when launching an attack, there will be no harm.

The classics state: "When Yin is even and Yang is hidden, the spirit will be well." This is precisely what it means. A skilled practitioner causes the true Yang in the Kan (water) to rise, resulting in the energy of the whole body feeling as if, at the winter solstice when the first Yang is born, reeds sway lightly in the wind, and heaven and earth harmonize with that Yang. Conversely, causing the true Yin in the Li (fire) to descend, leads to the body's energy feeling like, at the summer solstice when the first Yin is born, cicadas respond in unison, and heaven and earth harmonize with that Yin.

Indeed, within the body exists the ultimate medicine; how could mere grass and wood possibly compare even to one part in ten thousand?[288p]

　　金道宾前案，次年始见而问治焉。今再伸治法：夫道宾之病，真阳上脱之病也。真阳者，父母媾精时一点真气，结为露水小珠，而成胎之本也。故胎在母腹，先结两岐，即两肾也。肾为水脏，而真阳居于其中。在《易》坎中之阳为真阳，即此义也。真阳既以肾为窟宅，而潜伏水中，凝然不动，默与一身相管摄，是以足供百年之用。惟夫纵欲无度，肾水日竭，真阳之面目始露。夫阳者亲上者也，至于露则魄汗淋漓，目中有光，面如渥丹，其飞扬屑越，孰从把握之哉？所为神魂飘荡，三年未有宁宇也。[289p]

Jin Daobin was presented before the case, and the following year I began to inquire about his condition. Now I will outline the treatment: The illness of Daobin is one of the true yang's withdrawal. True yang originates from the mingling of parental essence at the moment of conception, forming a small pearl of vital energy, which becomes the foundation of the fetus. Therefore, while in the mother's womb, it first forms two branches, namely the two kidneys. The kidneys are the water organs, and true yang resides within them. In the "I Ching," the yang within the hexagram Kan refers to this true yang. Since true yang takes the kidneys as its dwelling, it remains hidden within the water, firm and unmoving, silently managing the whole body, thus capable of sustaining life for a hundred years. However, indulgence without restraint leads to the gradual depletion of kidney water, causing the true yang to start revealing itself. Yang is the force that nourishes upward; when it becomes apparent, the spirit sweats profusely, the eyes gleam, and the face appears flushed. Its exuberance is so vigorous that who can grasp it? The spirit wanders, and there has been no peace for three years.[289p]

故每岁至冬而发，至春转剧，盖无以为冬水收藏之本，无以为春木发生之基，以故腰脊牵强，督脉缩而不舒，且眩掉动摇，有风之象，总由自伐其生生之根耳。夫生长化收藏之运，有一不称其职，便为不治之证。今奉藏者少，奉生者更少，为不治无疑矣。而仆断为可治者，以有法治之也。且再经寒暑阴阳，有渐入之机，而验之人事，三年间如处绝域，居围城，莫必旦夕之命，得于惩创者必深，夫是以知其可治也。初以煎剂治之，剂中兼用三法，一者以濇固脱，一者以重治怯，一者以补理虚。缘真阳散越于外，如求亡子，不得不多方图之，服之果获大效。于是为外迎之法以导之，更进而治其本焉。[290p]

Therefore, every year as winter arrives, it manifests, and in spring it becomes more severe. This happens because there is no foundation to store the winter's water, nor a basis for the spring's trees to thrive. Consequently, the waist and spine are strained, the governing vessel contracts and does not relax, leading to dizziness and instability, resembling signs of wind. This all originates from self-harming one’s roots of vitality. The processes of growth, transformation, storage, and flourishing are interconnected; any failure in one aspect serves as evidence of illness. Currently, those who store are few, and those who nurture even fewer, leaving no doubt in the presence of disease. However, I assert that there is room for healing, as there are methods for treatment. Furthermore, after experiencing the changes of cold and heat, yin and yang, conditions gradually emerge, and upon examining human affairs over three years as if in an isolated realm, residing in a besieged city, one cannot predict the day and night of survival; those enduring afflictions will undoubtedly suffer deeply. Thus, I recognize the possibility of healing. Initially, we treat with decoctions, employing three methods within the prescription: one to dispel the cold and rigidity, one to rectify weakness, and one to replenish and stabilize deficiency. True yang disperses outward, just as one searches for a lost child, one must exhaust all avenues, and ingesting this formula indeed yields great effects. Hence, an external approach is employed to guide it, further advancing to treat the root cause.[290p]

治本一法，实有鬼神不觑之机，未可以言语形容者。姑以格物之理明之。畜鱼千头者，必置介类于池中，不则其鱼乘雷雨而冉冉腾散。盖鱼虽潜物，而性乐于动，以介类沉重下伏之物，而引鱼之潜伏不动，同气相求，理通元奥也。故治真阳之飞腾屑越，不以鼋鳖之类，引之下伏不能也。此意直与奠元圭而告平成，施八索以维地脉同符合，撰前案中所谓断鳌立极，早已言之矣。然此法不可渎也，渎则鱼乱于下矣。其次用半引半收之法，又其次用大封大固之法。封固之法，世虽无传，先贤多有解其旨者。[291p]

The fundamental method of governance indeed possesses opportunities unseen by spirits and gods, which cannot be described verbally. Let us explain it through the principle of observing things. For those who raise a thousand fish, they must place certain creatures in the pond; otherwise, the fish will rise and scatter in a thunderstorm. Although fish tend to hide, they naturally prefer movement. By placing heavy bottom-dwelling creatures, the fish are encouraged to remain still, drawn to the same environment, harmonizing principle with the essence. Therefore, in managing the true yang's soaring and leaping, one must not rely on tortoises and soft-shelled turtles to pull them down and make them hide. This notion directly aligns with stabilizing the primordial essence and ensuring peace, employing the eight cables to align with the earth’s veins, as previously discussed in the methods of disrupting shells to establish a great pole. However, this method should not be treated lightly; if it is, the fish will become chaotic below. Next, use a method of half-invitation and half-retrieval; then, further, employ a method of firm sealing and reinforcement. Although the sealing and reinforcing method lacks transmission in the world, many wise sages have elucidated its principles.[291p]

观其命方之名，有云三才封髓丸者，有云金锁正元丹者，封锁真阳，不使外越，意自显然，先得我心之同矣。前江鼎翁公祖案中，盏中加油则灯愈明，炉中复灰则火不熄之说，亦早巳言之矣。诚使真阳复返其宅，而凝然与真阴相恋，然后清明在躬，百年常保无患。然道宾之病始于溺情，今虽小愈，倘无以大夺其情，势必为情所坏。惟是积精以自刚，积气以自卫，积神以自王，再加千日之把持庶乎参天之干，非斧斤所能骤伤者。若以其时之久而难于需耐也，彼立功异域，嚙雪边庭，白首始得生还者，夫独非人也欤哉？前案中以绝欲二年为丈夫行，可收桑榆者，亦早已言之矣。今以药石生之，更不得不以苦言继之。仆不自度量，辄以一苇障狂澜也，其能乎否耶？
[292p]

Observing the names of the medicinal formulas, some call it "Three Talents Fengtong Pill," while others refer to it as "Golden Lock Zhengyuan Elixir." These serve to seal and lock the true yang, preventing it from leaking outward, which is self-evident—first, one must align their heart with this understanding. The sayings from the ancestor Jing Dun in the previous text, that adding oil makes the lamp brighter and adding ash to the furnace keeps the fire alive, have long been stated before.

Indeed, if the true yang can return to its abode and blend harmoniously with the true yin, then clarity and brightness will manifest within oneself, and one can maintain a worry-free existence for a hundred years. However, the illness of Dao Bin begins with indulging in emotions. Although there may be slight recovery now, if one does not guard against excessive emotional attachment, they will inevitably suffer.

One must accumulate essence to strengthen themselves, gather energy to protect themselves, and build spirit to govern oneself. Furthermore, with a thousand days of steadfastness, one could potentially reach the heights like the heavens, impervious to the damage of axes and hatchets. Should one endure the long passage of time, it becomes challenging to persist. Those who attain success in distant lands, weathering snow at the borders and returning grey-haired, are indeed rare.

In the previous text, abstaining from desires for two years is deemed sufficient for a man to achieve longevity, and this has also been previously stated. Now, when using medicinal stones for rejuvenation, one must not avoid speaking harsh truths. I lack self-assessment, yet I attempt to block the raging tide with a single reed. Is this truly feasible?[292p]
